questions.text: A 63-year-old male with a history of stroke and resultant severe oropharyngeal dysphagia develops right lower lobe pneumonia after an episode of vomiting. This type of aspiration pneumonia commonly affects the right lower lung lobe because:

choices.text: The right main bronchus is longer than the left main bronchus
The right main bronchus is straighter than the left main bronchus
The right main bronchus is narrower than the left main bronchus
The right lower lobe receives a richer blood supply than the left lower lobe

questions.solution:
The right main bronchus is more prone to foreign body aspiration than the left main bronchus because the right main bronchus has a larger diameter, is shorter, and is oriented more vertically than the left main bronchus. This fact can be remembered using the mnemonic, "Swallow a bite, goes down the right."
Educational objective:
Aspirated or inhaled particles are most likely to become lodged in the right main bronchus or its branches because this bronchus is shorter wider and more vertically oriented than the left main bronchus.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has been having fainting “spells” for about 2 weeks. During the episodes, his ECG shows a ventricular rate of 25 beats/min and 100 P waves per minute. After about 30 seconds of fainting, a normal sinus rhythm recurs. What is his likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Periodic fainting spells is known as Adams Stokes syndrome

Reason: Fluctuating third degree AV block in hearts with borderline ischemia of conductive system. Complete AV block →Brain cannot remain active for more than 4-7 sec without blood supply →fainting episode → ventricular escape from overdrive suppression occurs in 5-30 sec → rapid recovery from the faint and then to sustain the person.

AV block types:

1. First degree block: prolonged P-Q or P-R interval >0.20, not actual blockage but delay of conduction.

2. Second degree block:

a. Wenckebach or Mobitz type 1: progressive P-R prolongation followed by a dropped beat. Abnormality in AV node.

b. Mobitz type 2: A fixed number of non-conducted P waves for every QRS complex. P-R interval constant. Ex: 3:1, 3:2, 2:1. Abnormality in bundle of His-Purkinje system.

3. Third degree heart block: Complete AV block. SA and AV node dissociation leading to idioventricular rhythm (ventricular escape as Purkinje fibres becomes new pacemaker, 15-40 beats/min).

questions.text: A patient presents with yellowish eyes and skin. He also has itching, pain in the upper right side of the abdomen, and weight loss. Laboratory analysis of urine bilirubin indicates obstructive jaundice. The test of which of the following enzyme will substantiate these findings?
questions.solution:
Option A: ALP

  • ALP (Alkaline Phosphatase) catalyzes the removal of phosphate group from organic phosphate esters at alkaline pH.
  • There are 4 isoenzymes for the ALP enzyme:
    • ALP-I → Intestinal
    • ALP-L → Tissue non-specific, present mainly in the liver, bone, and kidneys
    • ALP-P → Placental Iso enzyme present, also called Regan isoenzyme, increased during pregnancy.
    • GC type (Germ cell type) → Present in Germ cell
  • Very high levels of the enzyme alkaline phosphatase are seen in obstructive jaundice and are considered one of the best enzyme biomarkers for biliary obstruction.
  • ALP is mainly produced in hepatocytes of the liver and osteoblasts of bones.
  • It is present in the canalicular membranes of hepatocytes. When the release of bile is obstructed, causing obstructive jaundice, it increases the translation of ALP mRNA. This causes an increase in ALP, which moves to sinusoids. This can be seen as a high level of ALP in laboratory testing.
  • Increased ALP levels are seen in:
    • The liver diseases mainly biliary obstruction, hepatitis, and cirrhosis.
    • Bone → Paget’s disease, osteoporosis, osteoblastic bone tumor, osteomalacia
    • Hyperthyroidism
  • Decreased ALP is seen in:
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Women taking OCPs and estrogen therapy.

Option B: AST

  • AST is remarkably increased in hepatitis and liver cirrhosis.

Option C: ALT

  • ALT is remarkably increased in Budd-Chiari syndrome and autoimmune diseases of the liver.

Option D: Aminotransferase

  • Aminotransferases increase remarkably as compared to ALP in diseases of hepatocellular origin such as hepatitis, autoimmune diseases of the liver, alcohol-related diseases of the liver, and liver cirrhosis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man, after suffering a heart attack, was put on low-dose aspirin daily by his cardiologist. The purpose of this treatment is to reduce the levels of which one of the following?
questions.solution:
Thromboxanes are synthesized in platelets and upon release cause vasoconstriction and platelet aggregation. Their synthesis is specifically inhibited by low-dose aspirin.

Aspirin is a suicidal inhibitor of cyclooxygenase.

Note: Cyclooxygenase is a suicidal enzyme.

questions.text: The coupling agent between electrical excitation and contraction of a muscle is said to be:
questions.solution:
• The electrical excitation and mechanical contraction are coupled by Ca++. Electrical impulse in muscle —> release of Ca++ in sarcoplasm —> Ca++combines with troponin C —> actin-myosin interaction.
  • Ca++ release occurs as a result of interaction between DHPR (L-type voltage-sensitive Ca++ channel in the T-tubule) and RyR (Ca++-release channel in the membrane of L-tubule).

questions.text:
The following figure shows the force-velocity relationship for isotonic contractions of skeletal muscle

The differences in the three curves result from differences in which of the following?
questions.solution:
The figure shows that the maximum velocity of shortening (Vmax) occurs when there is no afterload on the muscle (force = 0).

  • Increasing afterload decreases the velocity of shortening until a point is reached where shortening does not occur (isometric contraction) and contraction velocity is thus 0 (where curves intersect the X-axis).
  • The maximum velocity of shortening is dictated by the ATPase activity of the muscle, increasing to high levels when the ATPase activity is elevated.
  • Choice A: Increasing the frequency of muscle contraction will increase the load that a muscle can lift within the limits of the muscle, but it will not affect the velocity of contraction.
  • Choices B, C: Muscle hypertrophy, increasing muscle mass, and recruiting additional motor units will increase the maximum load that a muscle can lift, but they will not affect the maximum velocity of contraction

questions.text: All the following statements are true concerning the early embryological development EXCEPT:

choices.text: Zona pellucida is a glycoprotein membrane preventing implantation
Blastocyst attaches to endometrium on day 6
Primordial germ cells are derivative of epiblast
The first germ layer to form is ectoderm

questions.solution: -Endoderm is the first germ layer to develop from the epiblast, followed by mesoderm and lastly ectoderm.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, superior to the piriformis?
questions.solution: The superior gluteal nerve arises from the posterior divisions of the ventral rami of L4 through S1 and leaves the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, superior to the piriformis.

questions.text: The sustentaculum tali projects from the superior surface of which of the following bones?
questions.solution: The shelf-like sustentaculum tali projects from the superior border of the medial surface of the calcaneus and supports the talar head

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman complains of headache for 4 months duration. She is obese and has bilateral papilledema, and her vision is deteriorating. Her opening CSF pressure is elevated; other CSF findings are normal. CT and MRI scans are normal. These signs are due to the result of impairment of CSF egress. The pathology is located at which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Condition - Pseudotumor cerebri (benign intracranial hypertension), seen primarily in young obese women between the age of 20 and 50.
  • Likely due to high pressure within the skull caused by the buildup or poor absorption of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)by Arachnoid villi activity.
  • In this question, CT scan and MRI remain normal, hence the other obstruction locations have been ruled out.
  • Symptoms of pseudotumor cerebri include headache, nausea, vomiting, and pulsating sounds within the head, closely mimic symptoms of large brain tumors.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old male involved in a road traffic accident presents with neck and upper back pain, decreased power and sensation in the upper limb, and fractures of cervical and thoracic vertebrae on X-ray. Typical cervical vertebrae can be differentiated from thoracic vertebrae by all except?


	Has a triangular vertebral canal
	Has foramen transversarium
	Superior articular facet is directed backward & upwards
	Has a small vertebral body
questions.solution:
Option C: Only 3 are correct

  • In this case, the patient has features of cervical and thoracic vertebrae.
  • The cervical and thoracic vertebrae are involved in a patient's pathology.
  • Superior articular facets are directed backward & upwards in both cervical and thoracic regions. Hence it is not a differentiating feature.
  • The first cervical vertebra, or atlas, does not possess a body or a spinous process. Instead, it has anterior and posterior arches. It has a lateral mass on each side with the articular surfaces on its upper surface for articulation with the skull via occipital condyles.
  • The second cervical vertebra has a peglike odontoid process that projects upward from the superior surface of the body.
  • C3-C6 have a small and transversely broad body. Large and triangular vertebral foramen.
  • The thoracic vertebra has a medium-sized and valentine heart-shaped body.
  • Its costal facets are on each side at the posterior superior and inferior posterior corner.
  • It has a small and circular vertebral foramen.

Option A: Only 1 is correct

  • Vertebral foramen is triangular and large in the cervical vertebra. The foramen is small and circular in thoracic vertebra.

Option B: Only 2 and 3 are correct

  • Cervical vertebrae are identified by the foramen transversarium, while thoracic is not.

Option D: Only 3 and 4 are correct​​​​​​​

  • The vertebral body is the smallest in the cervical region. A large vertebral body is present at the level of the thoracic vertebra.
  • So, statement 3 helps in differentiating cervical and thoracic vertebrae.

questions.text: An increase in which of the following parameters will shift the O2 dissociation curve to the left:
questions.solution:
RIGHTWARD SHIFT OF THE OXYGEN-HEMOGLOBIN DISSOCIATION CURVE DURING EXERCISE-

During exercise, several factors shift the dissociation curve considerably to the right, thus delivering extra amounts of O2 to the active, exercising muscle fibers. The exercising muscles, in turn, release large quantities of CO2; this and several other acids released by the muscles increase the hydrogen ion concentration in the musclecapillary blood. In addition, the temperature of the muscle often rises 2° to 3°C, which can increase O2 delivery to the muscle fibers even more. All these factors act together to shift the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve of the muscle capillary blood considerably to the right. This rightward shift of the curve forces O2 to be released from the blood hemoglobin to the muscle at P O2 levels as great as 40 mm Hg, even when 70 percent of the O2 has already been removed from the hemoglobin. Then, in the lungs, the shift occurs in the opposite direction, allowing the pickup of extra amounts of O2 from the alveoli.

questions.text: Among the three cranial nerves shown below, which has the correct pairing?

choices.text: A – Lingual nerve B – Hypoglossal nerve C – Glossopharyngeal nerve
A – Glossopharyngeal nerve B – Hypoglossal nerve C – lingual nerve
A – Glossopharyngeal nerve B – Lingual nerve C – Hypoglossal nerve
A - Hypoglossal nerve B – lingual nerve C – glossopharyngeal nerve

questions.solution:
Option C:  A – Glossopharyngeal nerve B – Lingual nerve C – Hypoglossal nerve

It is the correct pairing of the marked nerves.

  • The lingual nerve is a branch of the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve. It carries a general sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve fibers arise at the level of the medulla oblongata. Its rootlets join to form a nerve that enters the jugular foramen's middle part. It curves medially across the stylopharyngeus muscle during its extracranial course, enters the pharynx through an interval between superior and middle constrictor muscle, and ends by dividing into terminal branches.
  • The nucleus of the hypoglossal nerve is situated in the medulla. Its rootlets are attached in the groove between the pyramid and the olive. It enters the neck through the anterior condylar canal, descends between the internal jugular vein and internal carotid artery, and passes above the hyoid bone in the submandibular region, where it terminates into muscular branches.

Option A: A – Lingual nerve B – Hypoglossal nerve C – Glossopharyngeal nerve

  • It is not the correct pairing of the marked nerves.

Option B: A – Glossopharyngeal nerve B – Hypoglossal nerve C – lingual nerve

  • It is not the correct pairing of the marked nerves.

Option D: A - Hypoglossal nerve B – lingual nerve C – glossopharyngeal nerve

  • It is not the correct pairing of the marked nerves.

questions.text: Fatty acid synthesis is the creation of fatty acids from acetyl-CoA and NADPH through the action of enzymes called fatty. The number of carbon atoms added in fatty acid synthesis is

choices.text: 2 in the first cycle and 4 in the second cycle
4 in the first cycle and 2 in the second cycle
2 in the first cycle and 2 in the second cycle
4 in the first cycle and 4 in the second cycle

questions.solution:
• The First Cycle of FAS Complex 2 C from Acetyl CoA condenses with 2 Carbon atoms of Malonyl CoA, by liberating 1 CO, So 4 Carbon atoms added.
  • In the second cycle to the existing 4 Carbon fatty acyl residue, 2 Carbon is added by Ketoacyl Synthase.

questions.text: Which muscle is responsible for the vocal cord's abduction?
questions.solution:
Option C: Posterior cricoarytenoid muscle

  • The only abductor of the vocal cords is the posterior cricoarytenoid.
  • It is essential in coughing, speaking, sniffing, and respiration.
  • As it is the only muscle that opens the vocal cords. Its paralysis can cause asphyxia.

Option A: Lateral cricoarytenoid muscle

  • Lateral cricoarytenoid muscle and Interarytenoid muscle are adductors of the vocal cords.

Option B: Vocalis muscle

  • Vocalis can tense the vocal cords and plays a role in changing the pitch of voice. It does not abduct the vocal cords.

Option D: Cricothyroid muscle

  • Cricothyroid muscle tenses the vocal cords.

questions.text: Identify the type of muscle shown in the image
questions.solution:
CLASSIFICATION OF MUSCLES BASED ON FASCICULAR ARCHITECTURE

Parallel fasciculi

When the fasciculi are parallel to the line of pull

  • Quadrilateral: Thyrohyoid
  • Strap like: Sternohyoid, sartorius
  • strap-like: Tendinous insertions : rectus abdominis
  • Fusiform: Biceps brachii, digastric etc – ROM in such muscles is maximum

oblique fasciculi:

Fasciculi are oblique to the line of pulll. Muscle may triangular or pennate. This makes the muscles more Powerful though ROM is reduced.

  • Triangular: Temporalis, adductor longus
  • Unipennate: Flexor policis longus, extensor digitorum longus, peroneus tertius, palmar interossei
  • Bipennate: rectus femoris, dorsal interossei, peroneus longus, flexor hallucis longus
  • Multipennate: subscapularis, acromial fibres of deltoid
  • Circumpennate: Tibialis anterior

Spiral/ twisted fasciculi

  • Cruciate – SCM, masseter, adductor magnus

questions.text:
The figure below represents various states of abnormal hydration. In each diagram, the normal state (orange and lavender) is superimposed on the abnormal state (dashed lines) to illustrate the shifts in the volume (width of rectangles) and total osmolarity (height of rectangles) of the extracellular and intracellular fluid compartments.

Which diagram represents the changes (after osmotic equilibrium) in extracellular and intracellular fluid volume and osmolarity in a patient with the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (ADH; i.e., excessive secretion of ADH)?
questions.solution: Excessive secretion of ADH would increase renal tubular re-absorption of water, thereby increasing extracellular fluid volume and reducing extracellular fluid osmolarity. The reduced osmolarity, in turn, would cause water to flow into the cells and raise intracellular fluid volume. In the steady state, both extracellular and intracellular fluid volumes would increase, and osmolarity of both compartments would decrease.

questions.text: An infant presented to the OPD with a history of vomiting and malnutrition. Patient has blue eyes, blonde hair & fair skin. On investigation, Guthrie test was found to be positive. All are true regarding this disease EXCEPT?

choices.text: White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency

questions.solution:
This is Phenyl-ketonuria.

    • Guthrie’s bacterial inhibition test is a screening test for phenylketonuria (PKU), used to detect the abnormal presence of phenylalanine metabolites in blood i.e. Phenyl pyruvate, Phenyl alanine & Phenyl-lactate.
    • FeCl3 detects phenyl alanine levels in urine.

WITH REGARDS TO OTHER OPTIONS

In Phenylketonuria, Phenylalanine is accumulated due to deficiency of enzyme Phenylalanine Hydroxylase. As a result Phenylalanine is not converted to Tyrosine and is responsible for mental retardation in patients. Tyrosine becomes essential in these patients.

CILINICAL MANIFESTATION

  • CNS – Mental retardation, failure to walk and talk, growth retardation, seizures, tremors, microcephaly.
  • Pigmentation - melanin is synthesized from tyrosine. so in PKU melanin is less result in hypopigmentation that cause light skin colour, blue eyes, fair hair

Treatment – low phenylalanine content diet

questions.text: In the central nervous system, the cell that scavenges the debris created after the breakdown of an axon and its myelin:
questions.solution:
Macrophages are responsible for the phagocytosis of various cell debris in the body.

Macrophages in various organs are given special names. eg:

  • Kupffer cells – liver
  • Microglia – brain
  • Osteoclasts – bone
  • Dust cells – lungs.

questions.text: An obese person will generally have a lower basal metabolic rate (BMR) compared to a lean person of the same weight and height. Its because the body of the obese has less amount of:
questions.solution:
Lean body mass is the mass which is not due to fat. Thus, lean body mass corresponds to muscles mainly. This is why,

  • Obese people lower BMR due to more more fat mass compared to a lean person.
  • Elderly people have less BMR, since the muscle tissue gets infiltrated with fat with advanced age.
  • Men have more BMR than women.

Additional information on BMR:

BMR is increased in BMR is decreased in
  • Fever
  • Protein Energy Malnutrition
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Cold environment
  • Addison disease
  • Cushing’s syndrome
  • Starvation
  • Cachexia
  • Obesity

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman with a severe middle ear infection comes to a hospital. On examination, a physician finds that the infection has injured the tympanic nerve. The damaged nerve:

choices.text: Is a branch of the facial nerve
Synapses with fibers in the lesser petrosal nerve
Is a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve

questions.solution:
- The tympanic nerve, or Jacobson's nerve, is a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve, contains preganglionic parasympathetic fibers, and forms a tympanic plexus on the medial wall of the middle ear with sympathetic fibers.
- The tympanic nerve continues beyond the plexus as the lesser petrosal nerve, which transmits preganglionic parasympathetic fibers to the otic ganglion for synapse.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to his primary care physician along with his wife. He seems well; however, his wife is concerned that he has become increasingly forgetful with significant changes in his personality. She explains that he forgets conversations and gets lost in familiar places, and now he has also started forgetting the names of his family members. Recently he has started to become more aggressive and impatient. She says that these symptoms started 2 years back and have worsened. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following cell plays a key role in CNS inflammation in this disorder?
questions.solution:
Option B: Microglia

  • Microglial cells are the smallest glial cells in the CNS that are derived from bone marrow monocytes and enter the CNS after birth.
  • They provide a link between cells of the CNS and the immune system.
  • They proliferate and migrate to the site of a CNS injury and phagocytose neuronal debris after injury. Hence, they are the phagocytic scavenger cells of the CNS that are activated in response to tissue damage.
  • The HIV-1 virus targets microglia in the CNS, and these HIV-infected microglial cells fuse to form multinucleated giant cells.
  • Microglia constitute the innate immune system of the central nervous system and are key cellular mediators of neuroinflammatory processes. They are involved in antigen presentation and immune response generating cytokines in neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer's.
  • "Reactive gliosis" refers to the accumulation of enlarged glial cells, notably microglia and astrocytes, which appear immediately after CNS injury.
  • In Neurodegenerative disorders, particularly Alzheimer's disease, the infiltrates of blood-derived mononuclear cells are absent. Senile plaques that accumulate in CNS in Alzheimer's contain amyloid beta protein. This protein is a peptide that forms insoluble and pathological extracellular aggregates that seem to attract microglia, which then phagocytose and degrade amyloid.
  • Chronic microglia activation is an important component of neurodegenerative diseases, and this chronic neuroinflammatory component likely contributes to neuronal dysfunction, injury, and loss in these diseases.
  • The common cause of dementia in the elderly is Alzheimer's, associated with the following altered proteins: ApoE-2, ApoE-4, APP, presenilin-1, and presenilin-2.
  • There is widespread cortical atrophy, especially in the hippocampus, with an accumulation of senile plaques in grey matter containing an extracellular beta-amyloid core and neurofibrillary tangles.

  • It is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by cognitive decline and difficulty completing activities of daily living. Symptoms include impaired ability to remember new pieces of information, Visio-spatial and language deficits, and behavioral and psychological impairments like aggression, irritability, social isolation, and apathy. MRI Brain shows volume loss in the hippocampus and temporal lobe.

Option A: Astrocytes

  • These are the most common glial cell types in CNS derived from neuroectoderm.
  • They are involved in physical support, repair, extracellular K+ buffer and removal of excess neurotransmitters.
  • They act as a glycogen fuel reserve buffer and are a blood-brain barrier component. They are also responsible for reactive gliosis in response to neuronal injury; however, they do not participate in phagocytosis.
  • Astrocytes marker: GFAP (glial fibrillation acidic protein).

Option C: Oligodendrocytes

  • These cells form myelin for axons in CNS and are derived from neuroectoderm. Each of the oligodendrocyte processes can myelinate individual segments of many axons. It is the predominant type of glial cell in white matter.
  •  They are injured in multiple sclerosis, progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) and leukodystrophies.

Option D: Schwann cell

  • They are the supporting cells of the peripheral nervous system and are derived from neural crest cells. They form myelin for axons in the PNS. Each Schwann cell forms myelin for only a single internodal segment of a single axon. Unmyelinated axons in the PNS are enveloped by the cytoplasmic processes of a Schwann cell.
  • They act as phagocytes and remove neuronal debris in the PNS, unlike microglia that cause phagocytosis in CNS after injury. They also promote axonal regeneration and are injured in Guillain-Barré syndrome.

questions.text: You are posted as a medical officer in a PHC and a mother comes to you with complaints that her 2-month-old baby is lethargic and is not feeding properly for the past few hours. You measure the blood glucose levels which come out to be 32 mg/dl and the baby is given 10% Dextrose bolus @2mg/kg. Which physiological impact can glucose infusion have on electrolytes?
questions.solution: Increase in blood glucose levels acts as a stimulus for insulin secretion. Insulin has an action of shifting Potassium intracellularly [ action which is utilised clinically in Hyperkalemia] . So, repeated glucose infusions might lead to lowering of S. Potassium levels.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, joint stiffness, aggressive behavior, and poor language skills; however, his vision is clear. Increased urinary excretion of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis among the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Option D: Degradation of glycosaminoglycans

  • Coarse facial features and accumulation of heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate in urine suggests mucopolysaccharidosis (MPS) which is due to accumulation of glycosaminoglycan (GAGs) due to absence of lysosomal enzyme in various tissues.
  • General Clinical features of MPS:
    • Coarse facial features -Depressed nasal bridge, frontal bossing
    • Copious nasal discharge
    • Short stature due to growth retardation
    • Clawing of hand
    • Protuberant abdomen – umbilical hernia,
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Corneal clouding
    • Skeletal abnormalities like Dysostosis multiplex due to defective bone formation and Bullet shaped middle phalanx

  

Option A: Mobilization of glycogen

  • The degradative pathway of glycogen is known as glycogenolysis, mobilizes the stored glycogen in the liver and skeletal muscle to release free glucose.
  • In skeletal muscle, glycogen undergoes glycogenolysis and is rapidly metabolized during exercise. In the liver, stored glycogen undergoes glycogenolysis to maintain blood sugar levels in the body.
  • Disorders of glycogen mobilization results in hypoglycemia and exercise intolerance.

Option B: Salvage purine bases

  • Purines resulting from the normal turnover of cellular nucleic acids are not broken down can be transformed into nucleoside triphosphates and used by the body. It is referred to as the salvage pathway for purines. This pathway is catalyzed by adenine phosphoribosyltransferase and hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT).
  • The deficiency of HGPRT results in Lesch Nyhan syndrome causing hyperuricemia.

Option C: Gluconeogenesis

  • It is an incorrect option, as the body synthesizes glucose in a special gluconeogenesis pathway, which requires mitochondrial and cytosolic enzymes. Gluconeogenic precursors include glycolysis and citric acid cycle intermediates, glycerol, lactate, and alpha-keto acids. This process occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Deficiency of the key gluconeogenic enzymes causes hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis.

questions.text: In a preterm baby with respiratory distress syndrome, which of the following lipid would be deficient?
questions.solution:
• Respiratory Distress Syndrome / Hyaline Membrane Disease:
    • Most common cause of respiratory distress in preterm neonate
    • Basic defect: Deficiency of mature surfactat

SURFACTANT COMPOSTION:

  • DPPC (Di-Palmitoyl-Phosphatidyl Choline) or Lecithin:The most important lipid component of surfactant,
  • Phosphatidyl glycerol,
  • Cholesterol,
  • Surfactant proteins: A, B, C, D,
  • The most important surfactant protein:Surfactant protein B.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presented to the clinic by his daughter because of a 3-year history of memory impairment, increased irritability, difficulties in daily activities, and findings of generalized cortical atrophy on MRI, along with the presence of amyloid proteins in various areas of the brain, what is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
PROTEIN MISFOLDING AND DISEASES-

(1) Amyloidosis -

  • Amyloids are used to refer to the altered proteins (with beta-sheets) that accumulate in the body, particularly in the nervous system
  • Alzheimer's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder
  • Accumulation of beta-amyloid.

Other examples of amyloidosis:-

Type Protein Implicated
Primary Principally light chains of immunoglobulins
Secondary Serum amyloid (A (SAA)
Familial Transthyretin; Others:- Apolipoprotein A-1, Cystain C, Fibrinogen, Gelsolin, Lysozyme
Alzheimer's disease Amyloid β peptide
Dialysis - related β2 - microglobulin

(2) Prion disease –

  • Etiology:-Proteinaceous infectious agents
  • No change in 1º structures and post-translation modification
  • Change in 3D structures (major change is the replacement of alpha helix by beta sheets)
  • Can act as a template to convert non-infectious proteins (with cl-helices) to infectious forms
  • Example - Transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSEs) and Creutzfeldt jakob disease in humans.
    • Scrapie disease - sheep
    • Bovine spongiform encephalopathy (popularly known as mad cow disease) in cattle

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is not excreted in the urine in individuals with cystinuria?
questions.solution:
Option C: Leucine

  • Leucine is excreted in urine in cases of MSUD (maple syrup urine disorder)
  • In MSUD there is deficiency of the branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase complex (BCKAD), leading to a buildup of the branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine) and their toxic by-products (ketoacids) in the blood and urine.
  • The buildup of these BCAAS will lead to the maple syrup odor in urine.

Option A, B and D: Cysteine, Ornithine and Arginine

Cystinuria

  • It is one of the most common inherited diseases (Autosomal Recessive).
  • Increased excretion of amino acids in urine:
    • Cystine (25-40 times normal) (most common)
    • Ornithine
    • Lysine
    • Arginine
  • In cystinuria, a specific carrier system in kidney tubules for the reabsorption of amino acids (cysteine, ornithine, lysine and arginine (remember COLA to recall) becomes defective
  • Most common inborn error of amino acid transport
  • Formation of cystine stones in the kidney and urinary tract
  • Cyanide nitroprusside test is positive

Treatment:

  • Restricted ingestion of dietary cystine
  • High intake of fluids
  • Chelating agent Penicillamine (forms complex with cysteine)
  • CYSTINURIA - Part of Garrod's tetrad
  • Cysteine is one of the amino acids which is transported by COLA transporter.
  • Cystinuria results in the loss of cysteine in the urine.

questions.text: In the central auditory pathway, which option represents the correct sequence of structures in the pathway?

choices.text: Cochlear nuclei–superior olive–inferior colliculus via the lateral lemniscus–medial geniculate–auditory cortex
Cochlear nuclei–inferior olive–inferior colliculus via the medial lemniscus–medial geniculate–auditory cortex
Cochlear nuclei–superior olive–superior colliculus via the lateral lemniscus–lateral geniculate–auditory cortex
Cochlear nuclei–inferior olive–inferior colliculus via the lateral lemniscus–lateral geniculate–auditory cortex

questions.solution: Auditory fibers enter the cochlear nucleus. Fibers from the cochlear nucleus pass to the inferior colliculus via the lateral lemniscus. Fibers from the inferior colliculus travel to the medial geniculate nucleus and from there to the primary auditory cortex.

questions.text: A 73 years old male patient came to OPD with a chief complaint of dizziness and on auscultation, heart murmur was noticed. On investigations, ECG revealed 160-degree deviation and chest radiograph showed an enlarged heart but no edema fluid in the lungs, but his pulmonary capillary wedge pressure was normal. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Right axis deviation is seen as the mean electrical axis of the QRS is 1600 which suggests that right side of heart is involved.
  • Pulmonary valve stenosis can lead to enlargement of the right ventricle due to pumping of blood against increased resistance of pulmonary valves. Hence, right axis deviation of heart can occur.
  • Mitral stenosis can cause an increase in pulmonary artery pressure in severe cases due to increased pressure in left atria and can also lead to an increase in pulmonary capillary pressure which is not seen in this patient.
  • Tricuspid stenosis will not affect the right ventricle so option A ruled out.
  • Aortic stenosis will cause left axis deviation of heart so option D ruled out.

questions.text: Twenty years ago, a 65-year-old man underwent vagotomy for his refractory peptic ulcer disease. As a result, which of the following GI motor activities will be affected most?
questions.solution:
Orad stomach accommodation (receptive relaxation) depends exclusively on an intact vago-vagal reflex. Vagal innervation of the GI tract extends from the esophagus to the level of the transverse colon.

Preganglionic fibers from cell bodies in the medulla synapse with ganglion cells located in the enteric nervous system. Distention-induced contraction of GI smooth muscle develops as the result of long (vagovagal) and local (enteric nerves) reflexes.

The importance of long versus local reflex pathways varies along the gut. Secondary esophageal peristalsis, intestinal segmentation, and migrating motor complexes are unaffected by vagotomy.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency room with an acute onset of aphasia and hemiparesis. A CT scan reveals an increase in intracranial fluid. Which of the following solutions will be most effective in reducing intracranial pressure (ICP) following a large hemispheric stroke?
questions.solution: Swelling or edema of the brain with a resultant elevation of ICP occurs with many types of brain injury. Interventions to lower ICP are ideally based on the underlying mechanism responsible for the elevated ICP. In head trauma, stroke, or brain metastases, use of osmotic diuretics to treat cytotoxic edema becomes an appropriate early step. Rapid removal of fluid from the brain can be produced by the administration of a fluid that increases the osmotic pressure difference between the brain and the cerebral vessels. The appropriate solution must have a higher-than-normal osmolarity (ie, >300 mOsm) and be composed of a solute that is impermeable to the blood–brain barrier. Of the solutions listed, only urea and mannitol are hyperosmotic, and of these, only mannitol is impermeable to the blood–brain barrier.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in a positive Trendelenburg sign in the right limb?

choices.text: Difficulty in standing from a sitting position
The left side of the pelvis droops or sags when he attempts to stand with his weight, supported by the right lower limb.
The right side of the pelvis droops or sags when he attempts to stand with his weight, supported just by the left lower limb.
Weakened flexion of the right hip

questions.solution:
Option B: The left side of the pelvis droops or sags when he attempts to stand with his weight supported just by the right lower limb

  • The patient suffered damage to the superior gluteal nerve in the motorcycle accident on the right side
  • Injury involving the superior gluteus nerve leads to characteristic motor loss with paralysis of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles.
  • If the patient is asked to stand on the limb on the injured side, the pelvis will be lowered on the opposite side, indicating a positive Trendelenburg test.
  • The gluteal duct, or the wobbling that results from this injury, is characterized by the pelvis sinking to the unaffected side as the opposite leg is raised.
  • When stepping forward, the affected person leans on the injured side by lifting the healthy limb off the floor. The uninjured limb then swings forward.

 

Option A: Difficulty in standing from a sitting position

  • The extensor muscle of the hip gluteus maximus is responsible for standing from a sitting position and is innervated by the inferior gluteal nerve. This patient has suffered an injury to the superior gluteal nerve; hence the positive Trendelenburg sign

Option C: The right side of the pelvis droops or sags when he attempts to stand with his weight supported just by the left lower limb.

  • The patient suffered an injury on the right limb, so the right superior gluteal nerve is damaged; hence the opposite side the left side will droop or sag when he attempts to stand on the right side. If he stands on the left leg, the right side will not droop

Option D: Weakened flexion of the right hip

  • Hip flexion is done by the quadriceps muscle innervated by the femoral nerve and is not injured in the accident. If it was injured. It would show a loss of extension at the knee

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presented to the clinic with ecchymosis and bloody urine, abdominal distention, fever, loss of appetite, and extreme weight loss. His past 6-month history revealed that he easily got fatigued. He had also been suffering from recurrent epitaxy since past 1 year. Bone marrow aspiration revealed the finding shown in the image. The probable diagnosis of this patient is
questions.solution:
The given image shows Guacher’s cells are seen as large cells with a thin outer border, one or two eccentric nuclei with few cytoplasmic content (arrows).

Gaucher’s Disease

  • Most common Lysosomal Storage Disorder
  • Glucocerebrosidase defect
  • Lysosomes filled with Glucocerebroside
  • No cherry red spot in the macula
  • No mental deterioration (Type I)
  • Hematological features: Pancytopenia, bleeding manifestation
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Bone Pain and Pathological Fractures of long bones
  • X-ray Femur Erlenmeyer Flask Deformity
  • Bone Marrow Biopsy Gaucher cell with Wrinkled paper appearance/crumbled tissue paper appearance.

questions.text: During the preparation of an evening meal, a female medical student dropped a sharp, slender kitchen knife. The blade pierced the first web space of her foot, resulting in numbness along adjacent sides of the first and second toes. Which nerve was most likely injured?
questions.solution:
The medial branch of the deep fibular (peroneal) nerve accompanies the dorsalis pedis artery and innervates the skin between the contiguous sides of the first and second toes.

The saphenous nerve is responsible for cutaneous innervation of the anteromedial aspect of the leg and foot.

The superficial fibular (peroneal) nerve innervates most of the dorsum of the foot, with the exception of the area where sensation was lost (medial branch of deep fibular nerve).

The common fibular (peroneal) nerve gives off a cutaneous branch, the sural nerve, which innervates the lateral aspect of the leg and lateral side of the foot.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the physician with complaints of a painless swelling on her right breast for 2 months. She further explains that the swelling is progressive in nature. The is vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. The patient is diagnosed with breast carcinoma. She was operated and was prescribed tamoxifen. Which of the following is the risk factor of the drug involved in the patient’s pathology?
questions.solution:
Option B: Development of endometrial carcinoma

  • This is a case of breast cancer in which the patient presents with complaints of a painless swelling on her right breast for 2 months.
  • The swelling is progressive in nature.
  • The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities.
  • The patient was diagnosed with breast cancer and was operated on.
  • Breast cancer is one of the most common cancers in women.
  • The patient was prescribed tamoxifen for the treatment of breast cancer.
  • Tamoxifen and toremifene are selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) that are useful for chemoprevention as well as treatment of both early-stage and metastatic breast carcinoma.
  • These increase the risk of endometrial carcinoma.

Option A: Development of bleeding disorder

  • The bleeding disorders are usually caused due to the following drugs:
    • Aspirin
    • Streptokinase
      • Capreomycin

 

Option C: Development of ovarian carcinoma

  • Ovarian carcinoma may be caused by the following drugs
    • Clomiphene citrate
    • Gonadotropins

 

Option D: Development of cervical cancer

  • Cervical cancer is less likely to be caused by drugs.
  • The most common cause of cervical cancer is the human papillomavirus

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the outpatient department due to fatigue, paroxysmal dyspnea, and orthopnea. His past medical history is significant for hypertension for 15 years, for which he takes amlodipine. His family history is insignificant. An ECG reveals left axis deviation, and echocardiogram shows left ventricular hypertrophy. Hypertrophy can occur in cardiac, skeletal and smooth muscles. Which of the following does not represent the example of smooth muscle hypertrophy as an adaptive response to the relevant situation?

choices.text: Urinary bladder in urine outflow obstruction

questions.solution:
Option C: Triceps in body-builders

  • Hypertrophy means excessive growth of the size of individual cells due to over synthesis of structural protein.
  • It can be both physiological and pathological.
  • Examples of physiological hypertrophy include:
  • Uterus during pregnancy
  • Breast during puberty, pregnancy, and lactation
  • Skeletal muscles during exercise
  • Examples of pathological hypertrophy include:
  • Cardiac hypertrophy in hypertensive patients
  • Intestinal hypertrophy before stricture/narrowing.
  • Skeletal, smooth, and cardiac muscles can undergo hypertrophy.
  • The enlargement of the triceps is an example of skeletal muscle hypertrophy (not smooth muscle hypertrophy).

Option A: Urinary bladder in urine outflow obstruction

  • The urinary bladder has a smooth muscle that undergoes smooth muscle hypertrophy due to volume overload, secondary to obstruction.
  • The question is regarding skeletal muscle therefore this is an incorrect option

Option B: Gall bladder in chronic cholecystitis

  • The gall bladder is lined by smooth muscle, which undergoes hypertrophy in response to chronic cholecystitis.
  • The question is regarding skeletal muscle therefore this is an incorrect option

Option D: Uterus enlargement during pregnancy

  • During pregnancy, uterine smooth muscles undergo hypertrophy resulting in a 20-fold increase in the size of the uterus.
  • The question is regarding skeletal muscle therefore this is an incorrect option

questions.text: Content composition of a Single pill (Photograph) is
In a patient, corneal scraping reveals narrow angled septate hyphae. Which of the following is likely etiologic agent?
questions.solution:
Option 1
  • Mucor: Broad aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide angle branching
  • Histoplasma capsulatum: invivo – yeast like form
  • Candida: GPOBYC: Gram positive oval budding yeast cell.
Option 3
  1. Narrow Septate hyaline hyphae with acute angle branching suggest the diagnosis of Aspergillus infection.
  2. Clinical manifestations of Aspergillus:
    • Pulmonary aspergillosis (MC form): Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), Asthma, Extrinsic allergic alveolitis, Aspergilloma (fungal ball) and Chronic cavitary pulmonary aspergillosis.
    • Invasive sinusitis, chronic granulomatous sinusitis, maxillary fungal ball and allergic fungal sinusitis.
    • Keratitis, endophthalmitis & Otitis externa.
    • Others: Endocarditis, brain abscess, skin lesions and onychomycosis.

questions.text: Urine is obtained by a catheter via a suprapubic puncture before autopsy or by puncture of the bladder after evisceration. Around 100-200ml is collected.If less, then the whole quantity will be collected. Which one among the following is a better preservative of urine in visceral packing?
questions.solution:
Option C: Toluene

  • Toluene is better preservative of urine in viscera packing.

Option A/B/D: Concentrated Hydrochloric acid/ Thymol/ Sodium fluoride

  • 1 ml of concentrated hydrochloric acid or 100 mg of thymol or 100 mg of sodium fluoride can be used for 10 ml of urine as a preservative.
  • Toulene is a better preservative compared to the above preservatives.

questions.text: A 44 year old male comes to your clinic with complaints of excessive thirst and excessive urination in the past 2-3 months. Patient sought consult since he had two episodes of bedwetting in the past week. On examination, you notice that the patient had dry skin and also complained of mild constipation. You order fasting, random blood sugar, and ultrasound KUB, all of which turn out to be normal. You fixate on a diagnosis of Diabetes insipidus. You would prefer to give him intranasal desmopressin spray instead of vasopressin since it:-

choices.text: Causes less formation of factor VIII
Is more selective for V2 receptor subtype
Provides greater relief of excessive thirst the patient is experiencing

questions.solution:
Desmopressin is selective agonist of V2 receptors of vasopressin. V2 receptors are present in kidney and on endothelium whereas V1 receptors are present in blood vessels. Therefore,

  • Desmopressin is less likely to cause vasoconstriction than vasopressin.
  • Desmopressin has similar risk of causing hyponatremia due to retention of water.
  • Desmopressin can release of factor VIII and vWF similar to vasopressin.
  • Both desmopressin and vasopressin can provide similar relief of excessive thirst.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female presented to the outpatient clinic with a lump  in her left breast. Her family history includes breast carcinoma in her sister and ovarian carcinoma in her aunt. Physical examination revealed a 2cm fixed solid mass in the upper outer quadrant, and ultrasound revealed a high suspicion of malignancy. The diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma was confirmed by biopsy. Which of the following is a risk factor for breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Option B: Positive Family History 

  • Breast cancer is uncommon in young females, but the risk increases after age 30. 
  • In middle age, triple-negative breast cancer and HER2 mutations plateau, but the risk of ductal carcinoma increase with age. 
  • The most common cause is increased estrogen exposure, which causes breast proliferation. 
  • The common risk factors with relative risks are 
    • Relative risk > 4 
      • Female gender 
      • Advanced age
      • Family history ( > 1 first-degree relative)
      • History of breast cancer
      • High breast density 
    • Relative risk = 2.1 - 4 
      • Moderative penetrance germline mutation 
      • Family history (1 first-degree relative)
    • Relative risk = 1.1 - 2.0
      • Early menarche (< 12 years)
      • Late menopause (> 55 years)
      • Late pregnancy (> 35 years)
      • Absent breastfeeding 
      • Nulliparity 
      • Obesity 
      • Physical inactivity 
      • High alcohol consumption 

Option A: Breastfeeding

  • Breastfeeding reduces the effect of estrogen stimulation on the breast. 
  • Breast cancer risk increases in the absence of breastfeeding. 

Option C: Multiparity 

  • Multiparity reduces the effect of estrogen stimulation on the breast. 
  • Nulliparity raises the risk of breast cancer. 

Option D: Physical activity 

  • Physical inactivity raises the risk of developing breast cancer. 
  • Exercising lowers the overall risk of morbidity.

questions.text: A 40 year old patient presented with chief complaints of hematuria, mild hypertension, proteinuria and symptoms of azotemia. Renal biopsy performed shown below, based on the histological features what is your diagnosis:
questions.solution: By light microscopy the focal and segmental lesions may involve only a minority of the glomeruli and may be missed if the biopsy specimen contains an insufficient number of glomeruli. On electron microscopy both sclerotic and nonsclerotic areas show diffuse effacement of foot processes, and there may also be  focal detachment of the epithelial cells and denudation of the underlying GBM. By immunofluorescence  microscopy IgM and C3 may be present in the sclerotic areas and/or in the mesangium. In addition to the focal sclerosis, there may be pronounced hyalinosis and thickening of afferent arterioles.

questions.text: A 12-month-old boy is brought to his primary care physician for evaluation of oral patches. A review of his medical record indicates a history of recurrent otitis media, pneumonia, chronic diarrhoea and failure to thrive. Family history is non-contributory. Physical examination demonstrates a malnourished child who appears small for his age. Oropharyngeal examination demonstrates scrapable white patches on the tongue but is otherwise unremarkable. Serum electrophoresis reveals low immunoglobulin levels, and a chest x-ray shows an absent thymic shadow.Deficiency of which of the following enzymes is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Adenosine deaminase

  • SCID is the most severe form of primary immunodeficiency and may result from an X-linked recessive defect in the IL-2R gamma chain or an autosomal recessive defect resulting in ADA deficiency. This disorder results in deficient B-cell and T-cells, causing failure to thrive, chronic diarrhoea, thrush, and recurrent infections., This severe form of primary immunodeficiency may result from an X-linked recessive defect in the IL-2R gamma chain (most common) or an autosomal recessive defect resulting in adenosine deaminase (ADA ) deficiency.

 

Option A: Myeloperoxidase

  • Myeloperoxidase is important for intracellular bacterial killing via the catalyzation of hypochlorite from hydrogen peroxide and chloride. Deficiency of this enzyme does present with recurrent Candida infections, but failure to thrive, chronic diarrhoea, and recurrent pneumonia are atypical.

 

Option B: NADPH oxidase

  • A deficiency of NADPH oxidase occurs in chronic granulomatous disease, which results in an inability of phagocytes to produce hydrogen peroxide in their lysosomes. Recurrent abscesses from catalase-positive organisms are a classic clinical feature. Failure to thrive, chronic diarrhoea, and oral thrush are atypical of this condition.

 

Option C: Pyruvate kinase

  • A deficiency of pyruvate kinase is a common cause of chronic hemolytic anaemia.

questions.text: Metoclopramide has the following actions EXCEPT:

choices.text: Prokinetic action is blocked by atropine

questions.solution:
• Metoclopramide is a prokinetic and anti-emetic drug.
  • It acts by blocking D2 and 5 HT3 receptors and stimulating 5-HT4 receptors.
  • D2 receptors are normally inhibitory to the release of ACh. Metoclopramide enhances ACh release by blocking these inhibitory D2 receptors.
  • Due to increased release of ACh, there is increase in gastric motility and LES tone.
  • Prokinetic action can thus be blocked by atropine.
  • Metoclopramide has no effect on colonic motility.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital and was empirically treated with ceftriaxone and amikacin. After a complete evaluation, the infection was found to be due to ESBL Klebsiella. What will be your next step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Continue with the same antibiotic but in a higher dose
Start imipenem in place of ceftriaxone

questions.solution:
Start imipenem in place of ceftriaxone.

1.β-lactamase enzymes are capable of hydrolyzingthe β-lactam rings (the active site) of β-lactam antibiotics; thereby deactivating their antibacterial properties. ESBL is a Class A β-lactamase enzyme.

2.ESBL (Extended-spectrum beta-lactamases)are resistant to all Penicillins and 1st/2nd/3rd cephalosporins and monobactam.

3. But do not affect cephamycins (e.g., cefoxitin and cefotetan) or carbapenems (e.g., meropenem or imipenem).

Option 2: Ceftriaxone and ceftazidime both are cephalosporins. So, cannot be used.

Option 3: We start with carbapenems ie. imipenem as they do not get affected by ESBLs.

Option 4: Amikacin is an aminoglycoside that is not affected by ESBL. Hence, not removed.

questions.text: In a rural village, PHC has arranged a polio vaccine camp for all the village children. You are posted on this duty as an intern. Which of the following OPV vials are usable from the image given below?
questions.solution:
Option B: Only 1, 2

  • We can use vial 1 and vial 2 as the inner square is lighter than the outer circle in both vials.
  • The inner square remains lighter only if the temperature is maintained appropriately.

Option A: Only 1

  • In the above-given image, both vial 1 and vial 2 is usable.
  • The vials are used only if the inner square is lighter than the outer circle.
  • If the temperature is not maintained, the inner square color becomes darker. 

Option C: Only 1, 2, 3

  • Vial 1 and vial 2 can be used as the inner square is lighter than the outer circle. 
  • Vial 3 cannot be used as the inner square is not lighter than the outer circle. 

Option D: Only 3, 4

  • Both vials 3 and 4 cannot be used. 
  • The inner square of both these vials is not lighter than the outer circle.

questions.text: In the nearby image the graph showing competitive antagonism is:

choices.text: Both Graph A+B and Graph A+C

questions.solution:
• GRAPH A
    • Shows the effect of agonist on the receptor
  • GRAPH A+B
    • Shows competitive antagonism where the competitive antagonist causes the parallel shift of agonist DRC with no suppression of maximal response on increasing the dose of agonist.
    • Antagonist has an affinity but intrinsic activity. Therefore no response is produced. By increasing the concenteration of an agonist, the block can be overcome and a parallel shift of agonist DRC with no suppression of maximal response is obtained.
  • GRAPH A+C
    • This represents non-competitive antagonism where the noncompetitive antagonist depresses the maximal response. This is because the agonist and antagonist bind to different sites and there is no competition between them for the binding sites. Therefore even the high agonist concenteration is unable reverse the block

questions.text: A study was undertaken to assess the effect of a drug in lowering serum cholesterol levels. 15 obese women and 10 non-obese women formed the 2 limbs of the study. Which test would be useful to correlate the results obtained?
questions.solution:
• Student’s t- test
    • Paired student’s t- test: comparing means in paired data (in same group of individuals before and after an intervention)

Example: Mean serum albumin level of dengue patients before treatment was 3.6 g/dL and after treatment was 3.2 g/dL; Comparison of mean levels can be done by paired Student’s t-test

    • Unpaired student’s t-test : comparing means in two different group of individuals Example: Mean Hb level of anemia patients was 9.6 g/dl and those of hookworm patients was 7.2 g/dL; comparison of mean levels can be done by unpaired student’s t-test
    • Z- test: Is a variant of student’s t-test which is used when sample size is >30

In the given question, the study to assess the effect of a drug in lowering serum cholesterol levels was undertaken in 15 obese women and 10 non-obese women (2 limbs of the study)

Thus mean lowering of serum cholesterol would be obtained in the two samples, thereby making ‘two-sampled student’s t-test’ as the test of choice.

questions.text: A sheep-rearing farmer has had complaints of fever and weakness for the last one month. There is generalized lymph node enlargement with associated hepatomegaly. Biopsy of the liver shows non-caseating granulomas. These are most likely due to infection with
questions.solution:
• Generalized lymph node enlargement with associated hepatomegaly in a sheep-rearing farmer with biopsy showing non-caseating granulomas indicates brucellosis.
  • Sheep-rearing points to Brucella melitensis as the animals that act as reservoirs for B. melitensis are sheep, goat and camel.

questions.text: HIV (+) patient admitted in medicine ward for opportunistic infection, patient's iv-cannula should be treated with?

choices.text: Disinfect in 1 % hypo chlorite, put in blue bag for destruction/ shredding
Put in Red bag for destruction/ shredding
Disinfect in 5% hypochlorite solution and put in yellow bag
Put in black bag for destruction/ shredding

questions.solution: Disinfect in 5% hypochlorite solution and put in yellow bag for destruction/shedding Intravenous cannula and tubing are included in BMW category 7 (Soiled Waste).

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman has an ovarian tumour removed. The surgical specimen is cystic and 10 cm in diameter. Black hair and sebaceous substances are discovered in the cystic cavity. A range of benign differentiated tissues, including skin, cartilage, brain, and mucinous glandular epithelium, are found on histologic inspection of the cyst wall. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Teratoma

  • Teratomas are benign tumours composed of tissues derived from all three primary germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm.
  • Teratoma originates from totipotential germ cells that are normally present in the ovary and testis and sometimes also found in abnormal midline embryonic rests. 
  • Such cells can differentiate into any of the cell types found in the adult body and so, not surprisingly, may give rise to neoplasms that contain, in a helter-skelter fashion, bone, epithelium, muscle, fat, nerve, and other tissues. 
  • A particularly common pattern is seen in the ovarian cystic teratoma (dermoid cyst), which differentiates principally along ectodermal lines to create a cystic tumour lined by skin replete with hair, sebaceous glands, and tooth structures.

Option A: Adenoma

  • An adenoma is a benign tumour of epithelial origin.
  • An adenoma is applied to benign epithelial neoplasms derived from glands, although they may or may not form glandular structures.

Option B: Chondroma

  • Chondroma is a benign cartilaginous tumour.
  • Chondromas are benign tumours of hyaline cartilage that usually occur in bones of enchondral origin. 
  • They can arise within the medullary cavity, where they are known as enchondromas, or on the surface of the bone, where they are called juxtacortical chondromas. 
  • Enchondromas are the most common intraosseous cartilage tumours and are usually diagnosed in individuals 20 to 50 years of age. 
  • Typically, they appear as solitary metaphyseal lesions of tubular bones of the hands and feet. The radiographic features consist of circumscribed lucencies with central irregular calcifications, a sclerotic rim and an intact cortex.

Option C: Hamartoma

  • Hamartoma is disorganized normal tissue.
  • Hamartomas are disorganized but benign masses composed of cells indigenous to the involved site.
  • The term hamartoma refers to an excessive, focal over-growth of cells and tissues native to the organ in which it occurs. 
  • Although the cellular elements are mature and identical to those found in the remainder of the organ, they do not reproduce the normal architecture of the surrounding tissue. 
  • The line of demarcation between a hamartoma and a benign neoplasm is often unclear since both lesions can be clonal.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with longstanding alcoholic cirrhosis presents with abdominal pain, fever, and an episode of hematemesis. Physical examination reveals jaundice and a markedly distended abdomen. The patient is disoriented and has a coarse fl apping tremor of the hands. Laboratory studies reveal modestly elevated serum levels of AST and ALT (96 and 92 U/L, respectively) and a high serum level of alkaline phosphatase (320 U/L). Prothrombin time is prolonged (20 seconds). The WBC count is 18,000/μL. Shortly after admission, the patient develops coma, adult respiratory distress syndrome, and renal failure (oliguriaand elevated serum levels of BUN and creatinine), leading to death within 3 days. Histologic examination of the patient’s kidney at autopsy would most likely show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Hepatorenal syndrome usually occurs in the setting of cirrhosis and heralds a poor prognosis. The disorder is characterized by features of renal hypoperfusion, including oliguria, azotemia,
and increased levels of serum creatinine. Microscopically, the kidney appears normal. Renal failure is caused by vasoconstriction and hypoperfusion of the kidneys, a combination mediated by various hormones and vasoactive substances, some of which may not be cleared by the cirrhotic liver. Similarly, a kidney from a patient in hepatorenal failure may be successfully transplanted into another person and assume normal functioning. The other choices are associated with direct injury to the renal parenchyma and exhibit characteristic histologic findings.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with a 1-year history of upper truncal obesity and moderate depression. Physical examination shows hirsutism and moon facies. Endocrinologic studies reveal hypokalemia, high plasma corticotropin levels and increased concentrations of serum and urine cortisol. CT scan of the thorax demonstrates a hilar mass. A transbronchial lung biopsy is shown in the image. Electron microscopy discloses neuroendocrine granules within the cytoplasm of some tumor cells. What is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Small cell carcinoma (previously referred to as “oat-cell” carcinoma) is a highly malignant epithelial tumor of the lung that exhibits neuroendocrine features. It accounts for 20% of all lung cancers and is strongly associated with cigarette smoking. Metastases occur early and are widespread.
  • Carcinoid tumors also contain neuroendocrine granules, but the tumor cells are arranged in a distinctive pattern. Moreover, Cushing syndrome is often encountered in patients with small cell carcinoma, but not carcinoid tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes a dose-response curve?

choices.text: Dose Response Curve(DRC) has a sigmoid shape
Area under time and plasma concentration curve signifies the extent of absorption of the drug
Drug dose is plotted on Y-axis
Quantal DRC tells about the effect of drugs on an individual

questions.solution:
Option B: Area under time and plasma concentration curve signifies the extent of absorption of the drug

Dose-response curves:

  • The relationship between the dose of a drug or substance and the measured response. Typically plotted on a graph, the X axis is the drug dose, and the Y axis is the measured response.
  • Plots of dose (or log dose) versus response for drugs (agonists) that activate receptors can reveal information about these agonists' affinity, potency, and efficacy.
  • The following terms are used to describe dose-response relationships:
    • Potency (EC50): The potency of a drug is measured as the concentration required to produce a pharmacological response of a specified intensity. 
    • Not related to efficacy (drugs with a high potency can have a low efficacy) but dependent on affinity.
    • EC50 = the effective concentration required to produce 50% of the maximum possible response (Emax).
    • A left shift of the curve is a sign of decreased EC50 and increased potency, meaning a lower concentration of the drug is needed.
    • EC50 is not to be confused with ED50; ED50 is the median effective dose that produces a desired beneficial effect in 50% of the population.
    • ED50 = 5 mg implies that the administration of 5 mg of the drug achieves the desired effect in 50% of the studied population.
    • The same drug may have different ED50 values based on the indication (e.g., aspirin has different ED50 values for headache and for thromboembolism prophylaxis).

  • Drug efficacy:
    • In pharmacology, “drug efficacy” refers to the maximum effect (Emax) a drug is capable of producing (where increases in dose will not increase effect).
    • The relative efficacy graph illustrates the difference in efficacy between drugs A and B at high drug concentrations.
  • Therapeutic index (TI): a measurement of the safety of a drug 
    • TI = median toxic dose (TD50)/median effective dose (ED50)

  • The greater the therapeutic index, the safer the drug 
  • High therapeutic index: e.g., glucocorticoids, penicillin.
  • Narrow therapeutic index: Drugs with a narrow TI require monitoring (e.g., lithium, theophylline, warfarin, digoxin, and antiepileptic drugs).
  • Therapeutic window: the range of doses that is effective for treating a condition with a minimum of adverse effects
  • The lethal dose (LD50): The dose that is lethal for 50% of the test population in animal experiments

Plasma concentration-time curve:

  • The area under the curve (AUC) tells the extent of absorption.
  • When compared with the AUC of the intravenous route, we get bioavailability.
  • Oral Bioavailability = AUC (oral)/AUC (IV)

The area under the curve of bioavailability graphs

  • The blue line shows the concentration of a substance administered intravenously (IV) over a while, and the red line shows the concentration of a substance taken orally.
  • The ratio of the area under the curve (AUC) of the orally administered substance to the AUC of the IV substance yields a substance's bioavailability (F).
  • Tmax is the time required to attain the maximum plasma concentration (Cmax), which tells the absorption rate. The lower the Tmax, the faster the rate of absorption.
  • Cmax tells the maximum concentration that is obtained by a particular dose.

Option A: Dose Response Curve(DRC) has a sigmoid shape

  • Dose-Response Curve(DRC) has a Hyperbola shape.
  • However, the log Dose Response Curve (log DRC) is a Sigmoid shape.

Option C: Drug dose is plotted on Y-axis

  • While plotting dose-response curves X axis is the drug dose, and the Y axis is the measured response.
  • Slope tells the drug's safety; the more the slope, the less the safety.

Option D: Quantal DRC tells about the effect of a drug on an individual

  • Quantal DRC tells about the effect of a drug on the population.
  • Quantal D-R curves plot the percentage of a population responding to a specified drug effect versus dose or log dose.
  • They permit estimations of the median effective or effective dose in 50% of a population—ED50.
  • They can reveal the range of intersubject variability in drug response
  • A steep D-R curve reflects little variability
  • A flat D-R curve indicates great variability in patient sensitivity to the effects of a drug.

questions.text: An investigation of a missing 25-year-old woman has led the police and the investigating agency to an abandoned bungalow near the edge of the woods. The woman has been rescued alive but had allegedly been sexually and physically assaulted. During the questioning, the police got a lead to excavate the area around the farm shed. They have recovered the bodies of 2 young women, which showed signs of early putrefaction. The police have decided to slap multiple charges against the owner of the bungalow including sexual sadism. What offense is termed as such?

choices.text: Sexual gratification from acts of physical cruelty

questions.solution:
Option A: Sexual gratification from acts of physical cruelty

  • Sadism: Sexual preference disorder that focuses on the infliction of suffering, pain, or humiliation to achieve sexual gratification.

Option B: Having intercourse with an animal

  • Bestiality/zooerasty: Any sexual act with an animal

Option C: Anal intercourse

  • Sodomy: It is anal intercourse between two males (homosexual sodomy) or between a male and a female (heterosexual sodomy). It is also called buggery.
  • Pederasty is intimate sexual relations, especially anal intercourse with a boy outside his immediate family as the passive partner (the boy is known as a catamite, and the man as a pederast).

Option D: Sexual intercourse with dead bodies

  • Necrophilia: A paraphilia whereby the perpetrator gets sexual pleasure in having sex with the dead.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with fatigue, fever, and night sweats. Physical examination revealed marked pallor. Palpation of his sternum demonstrated diffuse Tenderness. Laboratory studies revealed anaemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis. The WBC differential count showed 90% blasts. It came positive for nuclear expression of terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT). A bone marrow aspiration smear is shown below. Which of the following is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia

  • Clinical Features Of Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia:
    • Fatigue/Fever / Petechiae
    • Hepatosplenomegaly/Lymphadenopathy
    • B-ALL are positive for the nuclear expression of TdT.
    • TdT activity demonstrates that a leukemic blast is of lymphoid rather than myeloid lineage.
  • Diagnosis: Acute lymphocytic leukaemia
  • The bone marrow aspiration smear shows typical lymphoid blasts with a high n:c ratio, opened-up chromatin, conspicuous nucleoli and scant cytoplasm.

Option B: Acute myelogenous leukaemia

  • Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) is a blood and bone marrow cancer.
  • It is the most frequent type of acute leukaemia in adults.
  • Signs and symptoms of acute myelogenous leukaemia include:
    • Fever.
    • Bone pain.
    • Lethargy and fatigue.
    • Shortness of breath.
    • Pale skin.
  • A small sample of your bone marrow will be analysed under a microscope to confirm the AML diagnosis. A bone marrow biopsy is what is done in this situation.
  • Chemotherapy is the primary treatment for most AML subtypes, occasionally in conjunction with a targeted therapy medication. A stem cell transplant might follow this.

Option C: Acute promyelocytic leukaemia

  • A large rise in promyelocytes, an immature kind of white blood cell, is a hallmark of the blood malignancy acute promyelocytic leukaemia (APL).
  • Acute promyelocytic leukaemia (APL) symptoms are
    • Bruising easily.
    • Bleeding gums.
    • Bleeding from wounds that are hard to stop.
  • The diagnosis of APML is confirmed by the presence of excessive blast cells in the bone marrow.
  • Non-chemotherapy treatments known as differentiation agents, such as all-trans retinoic acid, are the most crucial medications for treating APL (ATRA). Chemotherapy (chemo) and platelet transfusions are two more possible treatments.

Option D: Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia

  • Signs and symptoms of chronic lymphocytic leukaemia include swollen lymph nodes and tiredness.
    • Lymph nodes in the neck, underarm, stomach, or groin swell painlessly.
    • Weakness or weariness.
    • Below the ribcage, there may be pain or a feeling of fullness.
  • A type of blood test known as a complete blood count is the primary test used to help identify CLL.
  • This is where a laboratory examines a sample of your blood to determine the quantity and appearance of the various blood cells..
  • Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL) that is symptomatic or progressing may be treated with the following:
    • Watchful waiting.
    • Targeted therapy with any of the following drugs:
    • Immunotherapy (lenalidomide) with or without rituximab.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl who is a known case of thalassemia visits to undergo a blood transfusion. Post transfusion, the patient has mildly elevated body temperature and generalized pruritis. Ideally, which of the following should be transfused in children suffering from thalassemia?
questions.solution:
Option C: Saline washed packed RBC

  • Saline-washed RBCs are specially indicated in conditions requiring repeated transfusion.
  • It is advised that washed, leukocyte-poor red blood cells (RBCs) be transfused over 1-2 hours at a rate of 8-15 mL RBCs per kg of body weight.
  • It is preferred in the management of babies suffering from thalassemia and paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria.

Option A: Packed RBC

  • It is generally indicated in patients with very low blood haemoglobin levels, but for those requiring repeated transfusion, the saline-washed form is far safer.

Option B: Platelet-rich plasma

  • Transfusing platelets to a patient with a very low haemoglobin level secondary to thalassemia is not an appropriate option and would not yield any benefit.

Option D: Whole blood

  • It is indicated in the following cases:
    • Massive haemorrhage
    • Coagulopathy
    • Rapid correction of anaemia
