questions.text: A 68-years-old man without a significant past medical history presents with a right testicular swelling that has been painful for several weeks. There is no history of previous trauma, night sweats, fever, or chills. A solid and enlarged testis with a homolateral hydrocele is discovered on scrotal examination. The ultrasound reveals a heterogeneous, enlarged testis with several hypoechoic masses. The serum alpha-fetoprotein (FP) and serum beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) levels are normal in laboratory tests. Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is 294 U/L (125-243 U/L), and Beta 2 Microglobulin is 2.18 mg/L (0.7-1.8 mg/L). CRP (C reactive protein) is 80.2 mg/L (0.8-2.0 mg/L). He also has a low haemoglobin level. The other lab investigations are normal. Which of the following is the most likely testicular tumour seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Option D: Lymphoma

TESTICULAR LYMPHOMA:

  • Testicular lymphomas account for 5% of all testicular neoplasms and are the most common testicular tumour in patients older than 60. Most are diffuse, large B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphomas and disseminate widely, with a high incidence of central nervous system (CNS) involvement.
  • Although an uncommon tumour of the testis, testicular lymphoma-affected patients may present with only a testicular mass, mimicking other, more common, testicular tumours. In most cases, the disease is already disseminated at the time of detection.
  • Most commonly, Testicular tumours were seen in Elderly
  • It is often bilateral
  • The most common testicular lymphomas, in decreasing order of frequency, are diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, Burkitt lymphoma, and EBV-positive extranodal NK/T cell lymphoma
  • It is a Malignant tumour
  • It has a poor prognosis

Option A: Seminoma

  • Seminomas are the most common germ cell tumour, making up about 50% of these tumours. The peak incidence is in the third decade and rarely occurs in infants.
  •  An identical tumour arises in the ovary, where it is called dysgerminoma.
  • Seminomas contain isochromosome 12p and express OCT3/4 and NANOG.
  • Approximately 25% of these tumours have KIT-activating mutations. KIT amplification and KIT overexpression through other unknown mechanisms have also been reported.

Option B: Spermatocytic seminoma

  • In contrast to the classic seminoma described earlier, spermatocytic is a rare, slow-growing germ cell tumour predominantly affecting older men.
  • Though related by name to seminoma, spermatocytic seminoma is a distinctive tumour both clinically and histologically.
  • Spermatocytic seminoma is uncommon, representing 1% to 2% of all testicular germ cell neoplasms.
  • The age of involvement is much later than most testicular tumours: Affected individuals are generally older than age 65.
  • Because it is a slow-growing tumour, it does not metastasize.
  • The prognosis is excellent.

Option C: Yolk sac tumour

  • Also known as endodermal sinus tumour, the yolk sac tumour is the most common testicular tumour in infants and children up to 3 years of age.
  • This age group has a very good prognosis.
  • In adults, the pure form of this tumour is rare; instead, yolk sac elements frequently occur in combination with embryonal carcinoma.

questions.text: A natural disaster is a major adverse event resulting from natural processes of the Earth; examples include floods, hurricanes, tornadoes, volcanic eruptions, earthquakes, tsunamis, storms, and other geologic processes. In this, the disaster causing maximum deaths is:
questions.solution: The natural disaster causing maximum death is Hydrological

questions.text: Avoid which anesthesia medications in a 25-year-old male patient diagnosed with pheochromocytoma, presenting with episodic headache, palpitations, perspiration, blood pressure of 188/92 mm Hg, pulse of 110/min, hematocrit of 50%, and elevated catecholamine levels, with normal renal and liver function tests?
questions.solution:
Option C: Halothane

  • Halothane makes cardiac muscles more sensitive and increases the effect of epinephrine and catecholamine. 
  • Pheochromocytoma patients have elevated catecholamine levels in their blood, which can cause arrhythmia with halothane. 
  • In patients with pheochromocytoma, halothane should be avoided. 
  • Halothane can result in malignant hyperthermia.
  • Susceptibility for malignant hyperthermia is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion​​​​​​​

Option A: Desflurane 

  • Inhaled desflurane is used to cause general anaesthesia. It is also used as maintenance anaesthesia in adults and children after receiving other anaesthetics before and during surgery.
  • Desflurane does not have a significant sensitising effect on the myocardium. 
  • It can cause adverse respiratory reactions, including coughing, laryngospasm, and secretions.

Option B: Fentanyl 

  • Fentanyl is an opioid commonly used to treat chronic pain in patients. 
  • It can cause respiratory depression, urinary retention, drowsiness and confusion.

Option D: Midazolam 

  • Midazolam belongs to the benzodiazepine class and lowers blood pressure. 
  • It can be used to induce anaesthesia in patients with pheochromocytoma.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male presents to the physician by his wife with complaints of recurrent episodes of watery diarrhoea and weight loss for one month. The patient is an IV drug user. The patient is vitally stable. On examination, the patient has multiple bruised veins on his arms and legs. He also has multiple ulcers on his thighs. The doctor suspects HIV infection, for which he sends a sample to the microbiology laboratory for ELISA. The investigation involved in this case, when compared to the western blot technique for diagnosis of HIV infection is?
questions.solution:
Option D: More sensitive, less specific

  • This is a case of HIV infection.
  • ELISA test is more sensitive and less specific when compared to the Western blot technique.
  • ELISA (screening test) is the most frequently used test for detecting both HIV-1- and HIV-2-specific antibodies in the serum.
  • Highly sensitive but less specific.
  • Supplementary or confirmatory tests:
  • These tests are designed for a higher specificity than the screening tests, hence are used as the test of choice to verify the results of screening tests.
  • Western blot, line immunoassay, and immunofluorescence assays are the most commonly used.

questions.text: Autopsy reports of the 25-year-old actor, who had allegedly committed suicide in his farmhouse, revealed petechial hemorrhage around both the orbits and behind the ears. The face appeared congested with minimal bleeding from the nose and mouth. The ligature marks were horizontal, complete around the neck, and were present below the level of the thyroid cartilage. Horizontal ligature marks would be more commonly seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Strangulation:

  • A ligature mark is a well-defined groove, which is slightly depressed and of the same width as that of ligature material.
  • The groove may be narrow at parts due to the folding of the ligature.
  • The furrow is usually horizontally placed across the middle or lower part of the neck, at or below the level of the thyroid cartilage.
  • The mark is transverse, circular and continuous.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hanging:

  • Ligature mark (‘furrow’) Site: Usually above the hyoid bone.
  • Size/shape: Depends on the type of material used.
  • Direction: It runs obliquely, backwards, non-continuous, upwards and towards the point of suspension. Mark is non-continuous because of a gap at the nape of the neck, and hair intervening between ligature material and the skin underneath.

questions.text: Dengue shock syndrome is characterized by the following except:
questions.solution:
• Classical dengue fever (DF)

− Also known as ‘break bone fever’

− Clinical features: high grade fever (biphasic curve) with chills, intense headache, muscle and joint pain, retro-orbital pain, photophobia, colicky pain, abdominal tenderness, skin rash ·

Dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF): severe form of DF, caused by infection with more than one dengue virus type − Incubation period: 4-6 days

− Clinical features: features of DS plus

− Rash less common

− Rising hematocrit value (>20% of baseline)

− Moderate-to-marked thrombocytopenia (< 1 lac/mm3)

− Heptomegaly

− Positive tourniquet test: > 20 petechiae per sq. inch

− Diagnosis of DHF: fever + hemorrhagic manifestations + thrombocytopenia + hemoconcentration of rising hematocrit ·

Dengue shock syndrome (DSS):

− Diagnosis of DSS: DHF + shock [rapid and weak pulse, narrow pulse pressure (<20 mm Hg)/hypotension, cold clammy skin, restlessness]

questions.text: A 24 yrs old AIDS patient develops chronic abdominal pain, low grade fever, diarrhea, and malabsorption. Oocyst demonstrated in stool. Likely cause of his diarrhea is –
questions.solution:
Option 4

  • Clinical feature of Isospora belli: fever, abdomen pain, watery nonbloody diarrhea. Disease is more severe in HIV patients resembling cryptosporidiosis.

questions.text:
(A) True or (B) False about the Factories Act, 1948

A maximum of 4 hours 30 mins of work per day for adolescents
Employment prohibited for age less than 16 years
Adolescents to be declared fit by ‘certifying surgeons’ and will work only between 6 AM to 7 PM
1 Canteen for greater than 250 workers
questions.solution:
According to the Factories Act, 1948:

  • Employment of young persons:
  1. Employment prohibited for age less than 14 years
  2. 15 – 18 years old adolescents to be declared fit by ‘certifying surgeons’; will work only between 6AM to 7PM
  3. Employment prohibited in certain dangerous occupations
  • Hours of work:
  1. A maximum of 4 hours 30 mins of work per day for adolescents
  2. 48 hours per week (9 hrs per day)
  3. Maximum 60 hours per week (including overtime).
  • Health, Safety and Welfare recommendations:
  1. A minimum of 500 cubic feet space per worker
  2. 1 Safety Officer per 1000 workers
  3. 1 Welfare Officer per 500 workers
  4. 1 Canteen for greater than 250 workers
  5. 1 Crèche for greater than 30 women workers

questions.text: Which of the following phase shows high susceptibility to antibiotics?
questions.solution:
1. During lag phase :bacteria adapt themselves to growth conditions. It is the period where the individual bacteria are maturing and not yet able to divide.
  2. The log phase : If growth is not limited, doubling will continue at a constant rate so both the number of cells and the rate of population increase doubles with each consecutive time period. This phase is most susceptible to antibiotics .
  3. The stationary phase: is often due to a growth-limiting factor such as the depletion of an essential nutrient, and/or the formation of an inhibitory product such as an organic acid.
  4. At death phase(decline phase): bacteria die. This could be caused by lack of nutrients, environmental temperature above or below the tolerance band for the species, or other injurious conditions.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of nausea, redness, swelling and pain at the bite site for 4 hours. He further gives the history that he was bitten by a spider while he was parking his car in the garage. He says that he had washed his hand immediately after the bite. He also started to develop tremors till the time he arrived at the hospital. The patient has no history of any chronic illness. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. The spider that has bitten the patient is shown in the image below. The spider involved in this case is known to produce a toxin that causes which of the following?

choices.text: Blocking Active transport of Ach into the synaptic vesicle

questions.solution:
Option A: Excess release of acetylcholine

  • This is a case of spider bite in which the patient presents to the physician with complaints of nausea, redness, swelling and pain at the bite site for 4 hours. He further gives the history that he was bitten by a spider while he was parking his car in the garage. He says that he had washed his hand immediately after the bite.
  • The patient also started to develop tremors till the time he arrived at the hospital.
  • All these symptoms suggest excess acetylcholine release.
  • The spider shown in the image is a black widow spider.
  • The black widow spider produces a toxin which is known as alpha-latrotoxin.
  • It induces a massive release of acetylcholine.

Option B: Decrease the release of acetylcholine

  • The release of acetylcholine can be decreased by: Botulinum toxin

Option C: Inhibits synthesis of acetylcholine

  • The synthesis of acetylcholine can be inhibited by Hemicholinium (HC3) blocks choline uptake (the rate-limiting step in Ach synthesis) and depletes Ach.

Option D: Blocking Active transport of Ach into the synaptic vesicle

  • Active transport of Ach into the synaptic vesicle is Inhibited by vesamicol.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy's body was received by the forensic pathologist for an autopsy. He had succumbed to injuries he had sustained while falling off a tree he was attempting to climb. Examination of the boy's dentition has revealed delayed tooth eruption, enamel hypoplasia, micrognathia, and anterior open bite. In all of the following conditions, dentition is delayed except?
questions.solution:
Option D: Congenital Syphilis

  • In syphilis, teeth may be premature or even present at birth.

Option A/ B/ C: Rickets/ Hypothyroidism/ Malnutrition

  • In ill-nourished children, and especially in rickets, and in hypothyroidism dentition may be delayed.

questions.text: A patient with complaints of burning micturition, frequency and urgency came to the physician. The urine sample was sent for culture in the laboratory, where the technician used CLED media. Why is CLED agar is preferred to MacConkey in the processing of urinary samples?

choices.text: It supports both Gram positive and Gram negative organisms
The growth can be seen in 4 hours
Klebsiella and E.coli can be differentiated easily

questions.solution:
Option A: It supports both Gram positive and Gram negative organisms

CLED agar is preferred to MacConkey in the processing of urinary samples because it supports both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria.

CLED (Cysteine Lactose Electrolyte Deficient) medium:

  • CLED agar allows Staphylococcus and Candida to grow.

  • It enhances the growth of dwarf colonies of coliforms due to the presence of cysteine.

Option B: It prevents swarming of Proteus

  • MacConkey and CLED both prevent the swarming of Proteus.

  • Motility: swarming seen on Blood agar, Nutrient agar.

  • swarming is inhibited by:

    • increasing concentration of agar from 2% to 6%.

    • addition of Boric acid & chloral Hydrate.

    • MacConkey Agar - Produce Non-Lactose Fermenting [NLF] colonies.

Option 3: The growth can be seen in 4 hours

  • MacConkey and CLED both need overnight incubation.

Option 4: Klebsiella and E.coli can be differentiated easily

  • MacConkey and CLED both differentiate between LF (lactose fermenters) and NLF (non-lactose fermenters).

  • Since both contain lactose, both are differential media.

  • Klebsiella and E.coli can be differentiated easily by their colony characters on both media.

questions.text: Random (in Randomization) in a Clinical trial means
questions.solution:
A randomized controlled trial (or randomized control trial is a type of scientific (often medical) experiment that aims to reduce certain sources of bias when testing the effectiveness of new treatments; this is accomplished by randomly allocating subjects to two or more groups, treating them differently, and then comparing them with respect to a measured response. One group—the experimental group—has the intervention being assessed, while the other—usually called the control group—has an alternative condition, such as a placebo or no intervention. The groups are followed under conditions of the trial design to see how effective the experimental intervention wasTreatment efficacy is assessed in comparison to the control. There may be more than one treatment group or more than one control group

RCT
Experimental Group Reference group

Intervention Given

↓

I M Drug Given

↓

70% Reduction of fever

No intervention

↓

I No Drug given

↓

10% Reduction of Fever

questions.text: The initial impression for the examining doctor of the crime scene and the body was that it was a case of gunshot injury. It is yet to be seen if it was self-inflicted or homicidal in nature. There was a visible entry wound at the forehead with an abrasion collar and partial tattooing present. The pooling of blood around the head made it difficult to view the exit wound. The forensic doctor will safely assume that all of the following features will be present as exit wound except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Singeing & smudging

  • Singeing & Smudging are the features of the entry wound; not the exit wound.

Incorrect choices:

Option A: Bigger than the entry wound

  • The wound of exit will be slightly bigger than the wound of entry.

Option B: Everted edges

  • The wound of exit: Through which the tip of the weapon emerges out of the body. It is usually smaller with everted edges.

Option C: Protrusion of soft tissues

  • The exit wound when present, it is in the form of a serrated, irregular laceration with everted margins through which some tissues or bone fragments may be seen protruding.
