questions.text: A 14-year-old tall man has been presented to the clinic to get vaccinated for tetanus after falling in the park. Upon physical examination, the physician notices that he has long arms and legs with huge hands and feet. On further examination, sparse pubic and facial hair are noted along with gynecomastia. The size of his testes was also small. His mother reveals that he also has some learning disabilities. Which of the following chromosomal complement is most likely present in this male?
questions.solution:
Option C: 47, XXY

  • Klinefelter syndrome has an Extra X chromosome, so they are 47 XXY.
  • It mainly affects the male population
  • Some clinical features are:
    • Sparse pubic and facial hairs
    • Hypogonadism [rudimentary testes]
    • Disproportionately long arms and legs.
    • Gynecomastia
    • Small testes
    • Low Intelligence quotient

Option A: Trisomy 21

  • Trisomy 21 (often known as Down's syndrome) is the most frequent chromosomal abnormality.
  • Some clinical features are:
    • A flattened face, especially the bridge of the nose
    • Almond-shaped eyes that slant up
    • Low set ears
    • Small hands and feet
    • A single line across the palm (palmar crease)
    • Short stature
  • Intellectual impairment

Option B: 46, XY

  • In Swyer syndrome, individuals have one X chromosome and one Y chromosome in each cell, which is the pattern typically found in boys and men; however, they have female reproductive structures. 
  • People with Swyer syndrome have female external genitalia and some female internal reproductive structures.
  • These individuals usually have a uterus and fallopian tubes, but their gonads (ovaries or testes) are not functional.
  • Instead, the gonads are small and underdeveloped and contain little gonadal tissue.

Option D: 45, XO

  • Turner's syndrome results from a chromosomal anomaly (45, XO). 
  • In older children and adults with Turner syndrome, short stature and webbing of the neck are commonly seen.
  • The thorax is broad, with increased distance between the nipples.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the hospital with chest pain and respiratory distress. A prominent pansystolic heart murmur and a prominent third heart sound are heard on cardiac auscultation. The patient expires despite intense supportive measures. At autopsy, microscopic findings are as shown in a given image. The mechanism of developing a given disease is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option A: Cross-reactivity with self antigens

  • This patient is affected by acute rheumatic fever, and the image shows “Aschoff body”.
  • It results from the immune response to group A streptococci (Strep. Pyogenes) cross-react with the host tissue.
  • Antibodies directed against streptococcal M proteins cross-react with cardiac autoantigens.
    • In addition, CD4+T cells, which are specific for streptococcal peptides, also react with self-proteins in the heart and produce cytokines that activate macrophages.
    • Therefore, cardiac tissue damage combines antibody and T-cell-mediated responses.
  • In patients with acute rheumatic fever, lesions are found in various tissues.
  • These inflammatory lesions are most pronounced in the heart, called the "Aschoff body".
  • They consist of foci of eosinophilic material surrounded by T lymphocytes, occasionally plasma cells, and bulging macrophages called “Anitschkow cells".
  • These characteristic cells have abundant cytoplasm and round-to-void central nuclei in which the chromatin is arranged in a central, thin, wavy band (caterpillar cells).
  • These lesions are pathognomonic for rheumatic fever.

Option B: inflammation of the endocardium

  • Infective endocarditis is a disease which affects the inner layer of the heart, valvular endothelium, chordae tendineae and mural endocardium.
  • The following pathogens mostly cause it:
    • S. Aures (acute)
    • Viridans streptococci (sub-acute)
  • It causes the following signs/symptoms:
    • Fever
    • New murmur
    • Roth spots
    • Osler nodes
    • Splinter haemorrhages
    • Janeway lesions

Option C: Decrease organ perfusion

  • Decrease organ perfusion and delivery of nutrients cause shock in the patient.
  • These are necessary for normal tissue and cellular function.
  • It is a life-threatening condition if not treated timely.
  • It is caused by dehydration, haemorrhage (hypovolemic shock), sepsis, anaphylaxis, CNS injury (distributive shock), and cardiac embolism (obstructive shock).

Option D: Release of atrial natriuretic peptide

  • The atrial myocytes release it in response to increased blood volumes and atrial pressure.
  • It plays an important role in vasodilation and decreases Na reabsorption at the renal collecting tubule.
  • It dilates the afferent renal arteriole and constricts the efferent arterioles.
  • It promotes diuresis and contributes to the “aldosterone escape” mechanism.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl, vaccination status unknown, presents to the ER with a 5-day history of high-grade fever, sore throat, and difficulty swallowing. Physical examination reveals a swollen neck and right-sided anterior cervical adenopathy. A thick, greyish membrane on the tonsils bleeds with scraping on throat examination. The doctor sent a sample of the scraping for microbiological examination. The following image was seen upon staining. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Diphtheria

  • The patient in question suffers from diphtheria, membranous pharyngitis caused by Corynebacterium diphtheria, a gram-positive club-shaped bacteria that assumes a characteristic ‘Chinese letter’ arrangement when stained.
  • C. diphtheria causes a characteristic series of symptoms in unvaccinated people, initially causing: low-grade fever, sore throat, and slowly progressing to swelling of tonsil and cervical lymph node ‘bull neck’, dysphagia, hoarseness (if the larynx is involved) and airway obstruction if the membrane dislodges and extends to the trachea.
  • Other notable complications include myocarditis and nerve weakness or paralysis.
  • Diagnosis is mainly clinical, but can be confirmed by a throat swab cultured on Loeffler's medium or tellurite plate.
  • Elek test can be done to differentiate toxigenic strains
  • Treatment includes anti-toxin as soon as diphtheria is suspected, and Penicillin G or erythromycin can be used as adjuncts to the anti-toxin.

Option A: Oropharyngeal Candidiasis

  • Candidiasis is caused by the fungus Candida albicans. It is an oval-shaped yeast and a part of the normal flora of the upper respiratory, gastrointestinal and female genital tract.
  • Candida is an opportunistic infection commonly seen in immunocompromised IV drug users and patients with indwelling catheters.
  • Clinical: Oral thrush: a white membrane that can be scraped off without bleeding, vaginitis, chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • Diagnosis: yeasts and pseudohyphae appear gram-positive, visualized using calcofluor white staining

Option B: Epiglottitis

  • Epiglottitis can also present with a sore throat, fever, and dysphagia. It is caused by Hemophilus influenza- a gram-negative encapsulated Cocco bacilli.
  • H. influenza usually causes disease in children aged 6 months - 6years. It may also infect elderly patients with pre-existing lung disease.
  • Diagnosis: H. Influenza can be cultured on chocolate agar in the presence of factors V and X.
  • The vaccine is available for prevention.

Option C: Infectious mononucleosis

  • Infectious mononucleosis, also known as the kissing disease usually seen in adolescents, is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. It presents pharyngitis with enlarged tonsils, tonsillar exudate,  and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy.
  • Diagnosis is clinical but can be confirmed with a monospot, also known as a heterophil antibody test.
  • Treatment is supportive. Penicillins cause an itchy macular rash and should be avoided.

questions.text:
Which of the following is not true about gastrointestinal stromal tumor; GIST?
a. Stomach is the most common site b. Associated with c-KIT mutationc. Histology shows spindle shaped cellsd. High propensity of malignant change

choices.text: If a, b, c are correct
If a and c are correct
If b and d are correct
If all four (a, b, c, & d) are correct

questions.solution:
Ref (Ref: Robbins 9/e p 775
Gastrointestinal stromal tumor is a benign tumor.

questions.text: This drug has activity against many strains of P. aeruginosa. However, when it is used alone, resistance has emerged during the course of treatment. The drug should not be used in penicillin-allergic patients. Its activity against gram-negative rods is enhanced if it is given in combination with tazobactam. Which of the following drugs is being described?
questions.solution:
• Piperacillin can be combined with beta-lactamase inhibitor, tazobactam.

• Vancomycin is NOT effective against pseudomonas.

• All β-lactams except aztreonam are contra-indicated if severe allergic reaction develops to any β-lactam antibiotic.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with a history of schizophrenia for 15 years is admitted to the psychiatry ward with difficulty walking, eye spasms/blinking, protruding tongue, extended neck, agitation, hand tremors, difficulty speaking and repetitive facial movements ongoing for about four weeks and worsening gradually. Her husband mentions that she has been using some medications prescribed by her primary physician. Which of the following drugs are likely to cause these symptoms in the patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Antipsychotics

  • The scenario mentioned above is a case of schizophrenia being managed with antipsychotics, and now the patient has presented with extrapyramidal symptoms, as mentioned.
  • Antipsychotics are known for their extrapyramidal symptoms, including akathisia, rigidity, bradykinesia, tremors, acute dystonic reactions and tardive dyskinesia.
    • First-generation antipsychotics include haloperidol, chlorpromazine, fluphenazine, pimozide and thioridazine.
    • Second-generation antipsychotics include clozapine, olanzapine, aripiprazole, risperidone and quetiapine.
  • EPS are caused by the blockade of dopamine D2 receptors affecting dopamine transmission via the nigrostriatal tract.
    • EPS are managed initially by the dose adjustment of antipsychotics.

Option A: Antidepressants

  • Antidepressants are not the drugs of choice for the management of schizophrenia. Therefore it is least likely that the patient was prescribed some antidepressants in this case.
    • Secondly, the common side effects of antidepressants include hypotension, bone fractures, seizures, teratogenicity, sexual dysfunction and antimuscarinic side effects.

Option C: Antiepileptics

  • Antiepileptics are not the drugs of choice for the management of schizophrenia. Therefore it is least likely that the patient was prescribed some antidepressants in this case.
    • Secondly, common side effects of antiepileptics include hyponatremia, suicidal ideation and bone diseases. EPS are not associated with the use of antiepileptics.

Option D: Antiparkinson drugs

  • Carbidopa and levodopa are antiparkinson drugs not prescribed for the management of schizophrenia.
    • Common side effects include nausea and vomiting, peripheral neuropathy, dyskinesia, impulsive control disorders, compulsive sexual behaviour, pathological gambling, orthostatic hypotension, withdrawal syndrome/Parkinsonism-hyperpyrexia syndrome and psychosis.

questions.text: A chest physician performs bronchoscopy in the procedure room of the outpatient department to make the instrument safe for use in the next patient waiting outside, the most appropriate method to disinfect the endoscope is by –
questions.solution:
Option 1, 2, 3, 4

Glutaraldehyde

  • Mode of action: combine with nucleic acids and proteins and inactivate them, probably by crosslinking and alkylating the molecules.
  • Glutaraldehyde is less toxic, less irritant and less corrosive, hence is best used to sterilize endoscopes and cystoscopes.
  • Glutaraldehyde is especially effective against tubercle bacilli, fungi, and viruses. It can be used for cleaning cystoscopes and bronchoscopes, corrugated rubber anesthetic tubes and face masks, plastic endotracheal tubes, metal instruments, and polythene tubing.
  • It is used as 2% concentration (2% cidex) for 20 min.but may require as long as 12 hours to destroy all spores.
  • It has to be activated by alkalinization before use. Once activated, it remains active only for 14 days.

questions.text: A community medicine student was studying various vectors causing different diseases. Vector shown in the below photograph can transmit all of the following diseases except?
questions.solution:
• Given picture is of Soft Tick.

Soft Tick acts as a Vector for

  1. Q-fever [animals]
  2. Relapsing Fever
  3. KFD (outside India)

questions.text: A neonate was brought to the hospital with complaints of not being able to suck breast milk and excessive crying. The condition was diagnosed as tetanus. Which of the following statement is true about the Elimination of neonatal tetanus in the village?
questions.solution:
Answer

Option A: <1/1000 case rate

  • Neonatal tetanus Elimination criteria (14th July 2016)
    • Rate: < 1 case / 1000 LB
    • Coverage TT > 90%
    • Attended deliveries > 75%
  • In order to be considered eliminated, neonatal tetanus should have a case rate of less than 1 per 1,000 live births (i.e., 1/1000 case rate). This signifies a very low occurrence of neonatal tetanus in the community.

Other

Option B: <0.1/1000 case rate

  • NNT (Neonatal tetanus) elimination: NNT status India
  • NNT free by July 2016
Classification Rate TT coverage Attended deliveries
NNT elimination < 1 / 1000 LB >90% >75%

 

Category Clean wound < 6H Other wounds
A- Complete Course (CC) < 5yrs Nothing Nothing
B- CC; 5-10yrs 1 Dose 1 Dose
C- CC; > 10yrs 1 Dose 1 Dose + TIG
D- No CC/ unknown Complete course Complete course + TIG

Option C: 50-70% delivery in the institution

  • The criterion for NT elimination was set at >75% institutional deliveries.

Option D: 50% delivery by TBA

  • Training traditional birth attendants, and promoting institutional deliveries can reduce the risk of neonatal tetanus.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with long-standing angina pectoris and arterial hypertension dies of spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage. At autopsy, the heart appears globoid. The left ventricle measures 2.8 cm on cross-section (shown in the image). This adaptation to chronic injury was mediated primarily by changes in the intracellular concentration of which of the following components?
questions.solution:
The answer is D: mRNA.

Hypertrophic cardiac myocytes have more cytoplasm and larger nuclei than normal cells. Although the elucidation of the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying the hypertrophic response is still actively pursued, it is clear that the final steps include increases in mRNA,rRNA, and protein.
The muscle cell synthesises more proteins and number of myofilaments increases.

Hypertrophy results from transcriptional regulation.


Diagnosis: Hypertrophic heart disease.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with fever, weight loss, and cough for several days. He is found to be HIV positive, and hepatomegaly is seen on examination. Sputum culture on SDA and staining reveal the fungus shown in the figure below. Which of the following fungus is the causative agent for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Penicillium

  • The image shows brush-like conidiophores.
  • Brush-like conidiophores formed at 25 0C are characteristic of the Penicillium fungus.
  • P. marneffei is the only dimorphic species of the Penicillium fungus.
  • The yeast form is seen as small, oval, 2-4 mm in diameter spherules. The mycelial form produces brick red-colored diffusible pigment.
  • It is an opportunistic fungus and causes infection in immunocompromised patients or individuals with a defective immune system and metabolic diseases like diabetes mellitus.
  • Penicillium causes tuberculosis-like disease involving the liver, spleen, and lungs.

Option A: Aspergillus

  • Aspergillus forms septate hyphae and conidiophores on wet preparations stained with lactophenol cotton blue.
  • Aspergillus fungus forms conidiophores with swollen round vesicles with chains of conidia on elongated cells. These elongated cells are called sterigmata.
  • Tissue sections of Aspergillus fungus show typical dichotomous branching of hyphae at acute angles.
  • Aspergillus is also an opportunistic fungus and causes several clinical syndromes:
    • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis
    • Aspergilloma
    • Invasive aspergillosis
    • Superficial infections

Option B: Absidia

  • Absidia causes an invasive disease called mucormycosis.
  • Spores of Absidia are found in air and dust.
  • Wet preparation shows broad ribbon-like hyphae. Hyphae are readily stained with hematoxylin and eosin and show broad, non-septate hyphae.
  • Under the microscope, broad hyphae ending in sporangium can be seen.
  • Absidia causes invasive diseases and can be treated with intravenous amphotericin B.

Option D: Acremonium

  • Acremonium fungus causes ocular keratitis.
  • Ocular keratitis by Acremonium fungus can be caused by a preceding corneal injury and bacterial infection of the cornea.
  • Under the microscope, Acremonium can be seen as hyaline hyphae, which produce simple awl-shaped erect phialides with inconspicuous collarettes.
  • Conidia of Acremonium are one-celled, hyaline or rarely pigmented, globose to cylindrical, and mostly aggregated in slimy heads at the apex of each phialide.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents in the ER with alcohol intoxication. Twelve hours later, she shows agitation and seizure-like symptoms, along with shakiness and nausea. With a history of alcohol use disorder, her vital signs are stable. What's the mechanism of action of the preferred drug for this situation?

choices.text: Facilitate GABA by increasing the frequency of chloride channel opening
Facilitate GABA action by increasing the duration of chloride channel opening

questions.solution:
Option A: Facilitate GABA by increasing the frequency of chloride channel opening

  • The clinical scenario describes withdrawal symptoms.
  • Long-acting benzodiazepines are used to treat withdrawal symptoms.
  • Benzodiazepine works by increasing the opening frequency of chloride channels.
  • Alcohol and benzodiazepines are central nervous system (CNS) depressants that stimulate GABA and inhibit glutamate receptors.
  • Chronic use leads to the downregulation of the GABA receptor and upregulation of the glutamate receptor.
  • Thus, sudden cessation causes glutamate-mediated overexcitation of the CNS.
  • The above symptoms usually appear within 2 days of stopping alcohol.
  • Severe alcohol withdrawal can be potentially fatal due to delirium tremens and seizures.
  • It requires early recognition and treatment with long-acting benzodiazepines.
  • Chlordiazepoxide: It's a drug of choice for an alcohol withdrawal condition called Delirium Tremens.

 

 

 

Option B: Facilitate GABA action by increasing the duration of chloride channel opening

  • Barbiturates work by increasing the opening time of the chloride channel.

 

Option C: 5HT antagonist

  • 5HT antagonists are serotonin inhibitors.
  • Atypical antipsychotics work by inhibiting 5HT receptors.

 

Option D: 5HT agonist

  • 5HT agonists are serotonin receptor stimulators.
  • They are used in the treatment of migraines and anxiety.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman dies after a short illness beginning in the late stages of labor. At autopsy, blood vessels in the lungs contained fetal debris (e.g., squamous cells, vernix, mucin), as did other vessels of multiple organs. Review of the clinical history reveals that she had become acutely ill with dyspnea, hypotension, and seizures, and a chest radiograph had demonstrated evidence of pulmonary edema. This was all followed by prolonged hemorrhage from the vagina and generalized bleeding from multiple other sites. The changes that were found within multiple blood vessels most likely are
questions.solution: The history is typical of amniotic fluid embolism, one of the major obstetric causes of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Other obstetric complications associated with DIC include retained dead fetus and abruptio placentae (premature separation of the placenta). Nonobstetric causes include neoplasms or tissue damage from infection, immunologic mechanisms, or trauma. Neoplastic causes include tumors of the lung, pancreas, prostate, and stomach, and FAB M3 acute myeloblastic (promyelocytic hyper granular) leukemia. Tissue damage can result from trauma such as lung surgery, from hemolysis or hemolytic transfusion reactions, and from inflammatory causes, such as gram-negative sepsis and immune complex disease

questions.text: The incidence of adenocarcinoma of the esophagus is increasing at a very rapid rate, which is largely the result of the growing prevalence of adenocarcinoma arising in Barrett’s mucosa. Which of the following statement(s) is/are true concerning adenocarcinoma of the esophagus?

choices.text: Barrett’s mucosa with specialized columnar epithelium characterized by veliform folds, lined by secreting columnar and goblet cells has the highest association with carcinoma of the esophagus
Less than 5% of patients with Barrett’s mucosa will harbor adenocarcinoma
Severe dysplasia of Barrett’s mucosa requires frequent reexamination and biopsy
Adenocarcinoma of the esophagus has a less aggressive behavior than squamous cell carcinoma

questions.solution:
• It is estimated that patients with Barrett’s esophagus are 40 times more likely to develop adenocarcinoma than the general population.
  • The true incidence of Barrett’s esophagus in the general population is unknown, but it is estimated that adenocarcinoma arises in up to 8% to 15% of patients with the columnar epithelium-lined esophagus.
  • Of the three characteristic histologic patterns for Barrett’s mucosa, the specialized or intestinal type of metaplasia which is characterized by veliform folds lined by a single layer of glycoprotein secreting columnar cell and mucus-secreting goblet cells has the highest association with carcinoma.
  • Dysplasia occurs to varying degrees in Barrett’s mucosa and is clearly a premalignant lesion. Severe dysplasia is almost always associated with carcinoma in situ and mandates aggressive therapy.
  • As is true of squamous cell carcinomas, esophageal adenocarcinoma has an aggressive biologic behavior that is characterized by frequent transmural invasion and lymphatic spread.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient presents to the outpatient department for a routine health visit. He has no presenting complaints. He works as an accountant in a construction company. He does not smoke but drinks alcohol on social occasions. He has a family history of diabetes mellitus in two successive generations. He has no symptoms suggestive of diabetes. The physician recommends screening for diabetes based on his family history, and the results show fasting blood glucose levels of 250mg/dl. On further workup, the radio Immune Assay of Insulin is normal. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Maturity-onset diabetes of young

  • MODY presents impaired blood glucose levels induced by diminished insulin release due to an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.
  • The onset of MODY is 25 years or younger
  • The beta cell mass is normal, but decreased insulin secretion occurs.
  • It involves mutations in the nuclear transcription factor gene (most commonly Hepatic nuclear factor 1-alpha) that regulates islet gene expression
  • Patients are responsive to sulfonylurea, which causes increased insulin secretion.

Option B: Wolfram Syndrome

  • Wolfram syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition and neurodegenerative disorder leading to childhood-onset- insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus.
  • It also causes:
    • Diabetes insipidus
    • Optic atrophy
    • Deafness.
  • It is a due mutation in a gene named WFSI, which encodes a 100.3 DKa transmembrane protein localized in the endoplasmic reticulum.

Option C: Type 1 diabetes mellitus

  • Type 1 diabetes mellitus has immune-mediated insulinopenia due to reduced beta cell mass.
  • In this condition immune system destroys the beta-pancreatic cell. This is also associated with a mutation in genes associated with T-cell tolerance.
  • Symptoms may include:
    • Extreme thirst
    • Vomiting, upset stomach
    • Dry mouth, blurry vision, and fatigue

Option D: Latent autoimmune Diabetes in adults

  • It is a slow-progressing form of immune-mediated type 1 diabetes mellitus.
  • It leads to a decrease in insulin release because of damage to insulin-producing beta cells in the pancreas
  • The onset is over 30 years of age.
  • It often would not require insulin for several months up to years after diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 14-years-old boy is brought to the hospital with the complaint of fever, malaise, and joint pain. He also experienced difficulties with vision. On examination, multiple skin lesions exist on the face, left arm, and legs. A photograph of the lesion is given below. 



Which of the following are associated with the patient's current condition?


	The eruption is localized
	Ulceration is frequent
	Occurs most commonly in LL leprosy
	Responds to treatment with thalidomide
questions.solution:
Option D: 3 and 4 are Correct

This patient is presented with erythema nodosum leprosum.

Some features of erythema nodosum leprosum:

  • It occurs most commonly in Lepromatous Leprosy and less frequently in borderline lepromatous (BL) leprosy.
  • The mechanism is related o immune complex deposition
  • It may be observed not only in patients under treatment but also in untreated patients.
  • Painful, red plaques and nodules together with areas of erythema and occasionally also purpura and vesicles. Ulceration is rare.
  • The eruption is widespread and is accompanied by fever, malaise, arthralgia, leukocytosis, acute uveitis, orchitis, and glomerulonephritis.
  • This is the only type of reactional leprosy that responds to treatment with thalidomide.
  • Histopathology:
    • PMNs may be scanty or so abundant to form a dermal abscess with ulceration.
    • Foamy macrophages containing fragmented bacilli
    • In some patients, no bacilli remain, and macrophages have a granular pink hue on Wade-Fite staining, indicating mycobacterial debris.

Option A: 2 and 3 are correct

This is incorrect because:

  • Occurs most commonly in lepromatous leprosy, but ulceration is rare
  • PMNs may be scanty or abundant to form a dermal abscess with ulceration

Option B: 1 and 4 are correct

This is incorrect because:

  • This is the only type of reactional leprosy that responds to treatment with thalidomide, but the eruption is widespread.
  • Multiple painful symmetrical skin lesions on the face left arm, and legs can be present.

Option C: only 3 are correct

This is incorrect because:

  • It occurs most commonly in lepromatous leprosy (3), which is correct, but another option (4) claims responses to treatment with thalidomide are also correct.

questions.text: A 55 years old man came with the chief complaint of swelling in upper half of the body, numerous tortuous veins on the anterior chest wall. On examination, Dilated neck veins, Cyanosis, and edema on the face, neck, and upper trunk - Aggravated by supine position as well as by bilateral arm elevation. Patient is a known smoker with a history of 15 pack-years, History of loss of appetite, weight loss & hemoptysis – 1 episode. Which of the following will be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
SUPERIOR VENA CAVA SYNDROME

  • It is one of the Structural-obstructive oncologic emergencies
  • It is the clinical manifestation of superior vena cava (SVC) obstruction, with severe reduction in venous return from the head, neck, and upper extremities.
  • Clinical presentation
    • Dilated neck veins
    • Collateral veins over the anterior chest wall
    • Edema of the face, arms, neck, chest and plethora
    • Cyanosis
    • Aggravated by supine position
    • Pemberton’s sign – Aggravation by bilateral arm elevation
  • Tumors related
    • Lung cancer
    • Lymphoma
    • Metastasis
  • Treatment – usually symptomatic and treatment for malignancy
  • Tumor-lysis syndrome is treatment related oncologic emergencies
  • Hypersensitivity reactions in malignancy patients is usually related to the drugs used in the treatment of the patients.
  • Pulmonary tuberculosis is not associated with the swelling of the upper half of the body
  • Hemoptysis can also be associated with lung malignancies

questions.text: The cleaning of the ear canal may accidentally stimulate X cranial nerve. What is highly likely?
questions.solution:
Irritation of the auricular branches of the vagus in the external ear (by ear wax, syringe, etc.) may reflexly cause cough, vomiting, or even death due to sudden cardiac inhibition. Auricular branch of the vagus nerve is also known as Arnold’s nerve or Alderman’s nerve.

ALSO KNOW, Auricular branch of vagus (CN X), also called Arnold’s Nerve. Tympanic branch of CN IX also called Jacobson’s nerve. Auriculotemporal nerve is a branch of Trigeminal (CN V) nerve Greater Auricular nerve is formed by Spinal (C2/ C3)Nerves.

questions.text: A 37-year-old Rh-negative patient is very concerned about her pregnancy at this age. The dose of anti D gamma globulin given after term delivery in this patient if she delivered an Rh-positive baby is:
questions.solution:
Postpartum prophylaxis in Rh-negative women

Rh anti-D IgG is administered intramuscularly to the mother following childbirth or abortion.

Timing:

  • It should be administered within 72 hrs or preferably earlier following delivery or abortion.
  • Should be given only if the baby born is Rh +ve and Direct Coombs Test done on baby’s blood is negative
  • In case 72 hrs is over, it can be given up to 28 days after delivery to avoid sensitization.

Dose:

  • 300 micrograms following delivery.
  • 50 micrograms following induced abortion, spontaneous abortion, ectopic pregnancy, or CVS in 1st trimester.
  • In case of pregnancy > 12 weeks full dose of 300 mcg should be given

Calculation of dose:

  • 10 microgram Anti-D is required for every 1ml of fetal whole blood in maternal circulation.
  • Volume of fetal blood entering maternal circulation is estimated by Kleihauer-Betke test
  • In this test acid - elution is used to note the number of fetal RBCs per 50 low power fields.
  • If there are 80 fetal RBCs in 50 LPF in maternal peripheral blood film it represents transplacental hemorrhage to the extent of 4ml of fetal blood.

Site of Injection
Anti D–immunoglobulin is best given intramuscularly into the deltoid muscle as injections into the gluteal region often
reach the subcutaneous tissues and absorption may be delayed.

Antepartum prophylaxis in Rh-negative mother

It is given at 28 weeks in all Rh-negative pregnant females with indirect Coombs test negative. Dose = 300 mg = 1500 I/U (single injection).

questions.text: A 38 years old female came to the ER with complaints of lower abdominal pain associated with fever for 24 hours. The patient is on copper IUD contraception for the last 4 years. On examination, lower abdominal and cervical motion tenderness was present. You are suspecting PID in this patient. Which of the following is the most likely organism to be associated with PID in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The organism associated with PID in women who are IUCD users is actinomyces.
  • It has been reported in 7% of IUCD users if the devices is worn for more than 2 years, compared to 1% in non-users
  • This emphasizes the need for strict asepsis during insertion of the device and the need for strict follow up of women wearing these devices.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy, who went on a camping trip in the mountains of Ohio a week ago with his family, is brought to the emergency department because of a headache, rash, and the abrupt onset of high fever for 2 days. The rash began on his palms and soles but spread to his ankles and arms. On physical examination, he has palpable purpura on his wrists and lower legs. The infection is likely caused by?
questions.solution:
Option A: Rickettsia rickettsii

  • This patient’s travel history to mid-western states of the US followed by fever and characteristic rash involving the palms and soles is characteristic of rocky mountain spotted fever.
  • Infections with Rickettsia rickettsii, Treponema pallidum, and coxsackievirus all can cause a rash on the palms and soles.
  • This patient is most likely infected with R rickettsii.
  • The clinical course is typical for Rocky Mountain spotted fever, which is characterized by fever with an abrupt onset and a rash that spreads from the extremities toward the trunk.
  • Palpable purpura is a poor prognostic sign, as it indicates active vasculitis and leakage of blood into the skin.
  • The rash in syphilis and coxsackievirus is typically more gradual and is not typically preceded by travel to endemic areas.

Option B: Treponema pallidum

  • Eruptions are macular rashes and symmetrically distributed, almost always involving the face and forehead (individual lesions tend to be indurated; the colour may vary considerably, most often presenting as a subdued red rather than a bright red lesion)

Option C: Coxsackievirus

  • Vesicles surrounded by a thin halo of erythema eventually rupture and form superficial ulcers with a grey-yellow base surrounded by an erythematous rim.
  • The exanthem can be macular, vesicular, or papular. The lesions are non-pruritic and typically not painful.

Option D: Disseminated Histoplasmosis

  • Characteristic lesions include nodules, papules, plaques, ulcers, vesicles, pustules, abscesses, and generalized dermatitis.
  • Less commonly, exfoliative erythroderma, necrotizing vasculitis, cellulitis, panniculitis, petechiae, purpura, and ecchymosis can be seen.

questions.text: A Young lady comes to gynecology OPD with mild erosion of cervix and on pap smear, dysplasia was noted. The patient was sent for a Colposcopy for further evaluation. The features in the colposcopy that suggests malignancy are all except:
questions.solution:
Abnormal findings on colposcopy indicative of dysplasia are:

  • Aceto white epithelium: Dysplastic epithelium turns white after the application of acetic acid and is called aceto white epithelium.
  • Leukoplakia or hyperkeratosis: It is an area of white, thick epithelium that is appreciated prior to application of acetic acid and may indicate HPV infection/ Keratinizing CIN, Keratinzing carcinoma, Chronic trauma from the diaphragm, pessary, and radiotherapy.
  • Mosaicism or punctuation: Reflecting abnormal vascular pattern of surface capillaries.
  • Atypical vessels: With bizarre capillaries in a corkscrew, comma shape, or sphagetti like configuration. (They suggest early stromal invasion).

questions.text:
Consider the following statements and choose the correct answer?
Statement 1:-Fluid restriction and not medication is the best for management of asymptomatic hyponatremia with serum Sodium less than 120 mEq/L, in patients of cirrhosis with oedema.
Statement 2 :- Conivaptan decreases B.P. and increases risk of variceal bleeding and so relatively contraindicated in cirrhotics with hyponatremia.

choices.text: Statement 1 is wrong and Statement 2 is correct
Statement 1 is correct and Statement 2 is wrong

questions.solution:
Fluid restriction and not medication is the best for management of asymptomatic hyponatremia with serum sodium less than 120 mEq/L and in patients of cirrhosis with edema.

Asymptomatic hyponatremia will respond to fluid restriction.

Symptomatic hyponatremia with neurological implications must be corrected at a rate of 4-8mEq/L over 24hours with 3% Hypertonic saline
Conivaptan decreases B.P. and increases risk of variceal bleeding and so relatively contraindicated in cirrhotics with hyponatremia

Conivaptan acts on V IA and V2 receptors. V IA stimulation is associated with vasoconstrictive, mitogenic, and possibly platelet aggregative effects. Conivaptan causes inhibition of VIA receptors and is beneficial for patients with CHF with concomitanthypertension and atherosclerotic disease.

In contrast, the very same effects derived from V IA inhibition can be harmful for hypotensive patients or cirrhotic patients with dilated splanchnic beds and variceal bleeds.

Further dilatation of the splanchnic bed and interference with platelet aggregation by V IA inhibition could exacerbate variceal bleeding.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male was referred to your emergency department, who presented with history of sudden loss of hot and cold sensation when taking a shower, followed by a progressive instability and weakness of his lower extremities. He also complained of diplopia, dim vision, and circumoral numbness. The patient had history of acute dysentery for which he was taking antibiotics last week. Neurologic symptomatology began a few days later. What is the most common cranial nerve involved in causing ophthalmoparesis in such patients?
questions.solution:
The above clinical history & features lead to the suspicion of Guillain-Barre syndrome.

  • The most common cranial nerve involved in GBS is the 7th cranial nerve involvement, BUT the question was regarding cranial nerve involvement causing ophthalmo-paresis in G.B.S.
  • Hence the Answer is a 6th cranial nerve.
  • Remember the number 7-6-3 as cranial nerves involved in G.B.S.
  • Ophthalmoparesis may be observed in up to 25% of patients with G.B.S. Limitation of eye movement most commonly results from asymmetrical palsy associated with cranial nerve VI. Ptosis from cranial nerve III (oculomotor) palsy also is often associated with limited eye movements.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old male presents in the clinic with the complaint of rash for the past 3 days. Examination reveals numerous hypopigmented, macular, scaly lesions over the trunk, as shown in the picture.



Which of the following statements is most likely true regarding this rash?

choices.text: Selenium sulfide is used for the treatment
Wood's lamp examination shows branching septate hyphae
The causative organism also causes vulvovaginitis

questions.solution:
Option B: Selenium sulfide is used for the treatment

  • Selenium sulfide is used for the treatment of pityriasis versicolor.

Pityriasis versicolor:

  • Pityriasis Versicolor is characterized by the development of spreading, hypopigmented, scaly macular lesions most commonly involving the trunk region. Malassezia spp. is the causative organism, which is a yeast-like fungus. The infection remains confined to the stratum corneum.
  • Risk factors affect hot and humid weather.
  • Microscopic examination of the lesions’ scrapings reveals round yeasts with filaments, also referred to as ‘spaghetti and meat-ball’ appearance.
  • Treatment includes topical application of selenium sulfide and/or administration of systemic antifungal agents in resistant cases.

Option A: Trichophyton is the infecting organism

  • Trichophyton belongs to the class of dermatophyte fungi, which are commonly implicated in the development of tinea infections (tinea capitis, tinea corporis, tinea cruris, tinea pedis, etc.).

Option C: Wood's lamp examination shows branching septate hyphae

  • Branching septate hyphae are associated with dermatophyte infection.

Option D: The causative organism also causes vulvovaginitis

  • Vulvovaginitis is caused by Candida albicans which belong to the class of dimorphic fungi.
  • Candida albicans is also associated with the development of oral and esophageal thrush and candidemia in immunocompromised patients

questions.text: Metabolic acidosis is a clinical disturbance characterized by an increase in plasma acidity. The most common cause for hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis is GI loss (eg, diarrhea, laxative use). Which of the following condition is associated with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension?

A 72-year-old man presented to the emergency room with dyspnea and thoracic pain after vomiting. On examination, he was tachycardic & hypotensive. CT scan revealed pneumomediastinum, left collapsed lung, and loculated pleural effusion. Crepitus was heard over the mediastinum. A left intercostal chest tube was inserted with food drainage. Which of the following is the most common site of tear of the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Lower end of the Esophagus

  • The clinical history & features are suggestive of Boerhaave syndrome, also known as spontaneous oesophageal rupture.
  • The most common site of tear is at the lower end of the oesophagus.

Boerhaave syndrome:

  • Boerhaave syndrome is defined as a transmural rupture of the distal oesophagus.
  • Sudden rise in intraluminal oesophageal pressure produced during vomiting or severe retching due to neuromuscular incoordination causing failure of the cricopharyngeus muscle to relax and is presented as severe retrosternal chest pain and mediastinal emphysema, crepitus heard over the mediastinum.
  • It is associated with overindulgence in food and alcohol.
  • At the left posterolateral wall of the lower third of the oesophagus, 2-3 cm proximal to the gastroesophageal junction, along the longitudinal wall of the oesophagus common site of rupture is in the subdiaphragmatic or upper thoracic area.

Option B: At a gastroesophageal junction.

  • Mallory Weiss syndrome is the non-transmural rupture at the gastroesophageal junction due to vomiting, retching or coughing. Longitudinal lacerations appear in the gastroesophageal junction.
  • Instrument perforation(iatrogenic) typically occurs in the hypopharynx or at the gastroesophageal junction.

Option C: Upper oesophagus.

  • The upper oesophagus is not the common site of rupture in Boerhaave syndrome.

Option D: Mid oesophagus.

  • The mid oesophagus is not the common site of rupture in Boerhaave syndrome.

questions.text: A previously healthy 53-year-old man presents to the causality after he became acutely obtunded and had a seizure after a marathon. Immediately endotracheal airway was established and mechanical ventilation was started, the patient’s sodium level was 115 mEq/dL. His head CT reveals diffuse cerebral edema with effacement of sulci without cerebral herniation. Which therapy is most appropriate?

choices.text: 1 L of normal saline bolus followed by 100 mL/hr
Initiation of desmopressin therapy and then administration of hypertonic saline
Hypertonic (3%) saline targeted at increasing sodium 1–2 mM/hr

questions.solution:
• Exercise-associated hyponatremia is an important clinical issue at marathons and other endurance events.
  • Patients with acute hyponatremia, such as this patient, present with symptoms that can range from headache, nausea, and/or vomiting, to seizures, obtundation, and central herniation
  • Patient with chronic hyponatremia, present for >48 hours, are less likely to have severe symptoms.
  • Treatment of acute symptomatic hyponatremia should include hypertonic 3% saline (513 mM) to acutely increase plasma Na+ concentration by 1–2 mM/hr to a total of 4–6 mM.
  • This modest increase is typically sufficient to alleviate severe acute symptoms, after which corrective guidelines for chronic hyponatremia are appropriate.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with small amounts of urinary leakage in the past 1 year. Her incontinence occurs only during coughing or sneezing. She has been advised of some pelvic floor exercises, but she was not relieved. Which of the following surgeries may be useful in this condition?
questions.solution:
Stress incontinence – involuntary escape of urine with the increase of abdominal pressure.

Treatment of stress incontinence
Conservative Surgical

1) Pelvic floor muscle training

2) Bio feedback therapy

3) Drugs

4) Paraurethral implants

1) Kelly's plication

2) Bursch colposuspension

3) MMK procedure

4) Transvaginal sling

5) Trans obturator sling

6) Laparoscopic suspension of bladder neck

Types stress incontinence according to the cause

  • Type I: Incontinence due to loss of posterior urethrovesical angle alone.
  • Type II: Incontinence due loss of posterior urethrovesical angle as well as urethral hypermobility
  • Type III: Incontinence due to intrinsic sphincter deficiency (ISD)

Other options

  • Le Fort: surgery for vaginal proplapse for older women unfit for a vaginal hysterectomy
  • Manchester: uterine conservative surgery for prolapse
  • Posterior colporhaphy: done along with vaginal hysterectomy for posterior compartment tightening

questions.text:
Match List I with List II and select the correct answer using the code given below the lists:



List I (Emergency drugs) 
List II (Clinical condition)


A. Amiodarone
1. 1st-degree heart Block


B. Adenosine
2. Atrial fibrillation


C. Digoxin
3. Ventricular tachycardia


D. Atropine
4. Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia



Code: A B C D
questions.solution:
Amiodarone Ventricular tachycardia Prolongs the APD of the current generated due to re-entry or automaticity. This results in the decrease in firing frequency of the ectopic focus and helps in termination of arrhythmia.
Adenosine P.S.V.T Prolongs AV nodal delay and re-establishes the superiority of SA node.
Digoxin Atrial fibrillation Digoxin acts on AV node and slows the conduction of impulses generated from ectopic focus down to bundle of HIS. Hence it is used for rate control and also useful for management of concomitant CHF
Atropine Ist degree heart block Atropine increases firing of the sinoatrial node (atria) and conduction through the atrioventricular node (AV) of the heart by blocking the action of the vagus nerve. It is not useful for Mobitz II and third-degree heart block.

questions.text: A 31-year-old male patient suffering from psoriasis since early childhood was admitted to the Department of Dermatology due to the exacerbation of skin lesions, with pustular eruption involving almost the whole body surface. Treatment of choice for this condition to be?
questions.solution:
The given patient is case of Generalised Pustular Psoriasis
? Most cases of GPP (Generalised Pustular Psoriasis) require systemic therapy.
? Retinoids → TOC
? Response to high doses of acitretin (1 mg/kg/day) is rapid and lower doses of 0.5–0.75 mg/kg/day, sufficient to maintain control.
? Acitretin > Methotrexate
? Other drugs used are Cyclosporine, Colchicine, Razoxane, Dapsone
? TNF-antagonists, and Basiliximab, an antibody directed at the IL-2 receptor, rapidly control acute GPP.
Systemic steroids are C/I in psoriasis.
Indications of Systemic steroids in Psoriasis
? Impetigo Herpetiformis
? Acute erythrodermic psoriasis
? Acute generalized pustular psoriasis
? Unstable Psoriasis
? Severe cases of Psoriatic arthritis

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presented with complaints of 2 episodes of hematemesis. Initial investigations revealed Hb of 7.2g/dl. She was advised to have a UGI endoscopy done. Which of the following finding on upper GI endoscopy indicates the most negligible chances of re-bleeding after hematemesis episodes?
questions.solution:
Option B: Clean-based ulcer

  • Most patients with hematemesis have a re-bleed within the next 3 days of an episode.
  • UGIE is diagnostic and prognostic as a clean-based ulcer has the slightest chance of re-bleeding, while the visible bleeding vessel has the highest chance.
  • Endoscopic intervention is indicated in active bleeding, non-bleeding visible vessel, and active bleeding or visible vessel exposed after adherent clot removal.
  • These are ulcers with a clean base or with flat blood spots.

 

Option A: Adherent clot on the ulcer

  • An adherent clot is called a red, maroon, or black protuberance greater than 3 mm in diameter that could not be dislodged by forceful irrigation with water.
  • It is typically seen as a barium-filled ulcer crater's smooth or irregular filling defect.
  • Granulation tissue or debris in the ulcer may produce similar findings.
  • Symptoms may include sudden, severe pain in the belly (abdomen), usually in the upper abdomen.

 

Option C: Gastric ulcer with AV malformation

  • An arteriovenous malformation (AVM) is an abnormal tangle of blood vessels connecting arteries and veins, which disrupts normal blood flow and oxygen circulation.
  •  Arteries are responsible for taking oxygen-rich blood from the heart to the brain. Veins carry the oxygen-depleted blood back to the lungs and heart.
  • An AVM occurs when arteries in the brain connect directly to nearby veins without having the usual small vessels (capillaries) between them.
  • The exact cause of cerebral AVM is unknown. However, evidence suggests a genetic cause.

 

Option D: Visible bleeding vessel

  • There are four commonly used endoscopic techniques in treating a bleeding ulcer: injection therapy, thermal coagulation, endoscopic clipping, and, most recently, hemostatic powders that are sprayed onto the bleeding ulcer.
  • An endoscopy procedure may help to see if and where GI is bleeding and the bleeding's cause.
  • In upper GI bleeding, an IV drug known as a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) is given to suppress stomach acid production.
  • Severe internal bleeding is life-threatening. Perforation or serious bleeding may require surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 64-year-old assistant hair stylist undergoes a vaginal hysterectomy under spinal anesthesia. Bleeding occurs when an attempt is made to separate and exclude the right ureter from the operating field. After a short interval, a respiratory arrest occurs and intubation was instituted. What is the most likely cause of respiratory arrest during this procedure under spinal anesthesia?

choices.text: Centrally induced mechanism secondary to decreased cardiac output
Diffusion of anesthetic to the level of the pons

questions.solution:
• Spinal anesthesia induces venous vasodilation because of sympathetic blockade.
  • Venous pooling can seriously impair venous return.
  • It is the sympathetic blockade and not somatic nerve blockade that is responsible for the vasomotor and respiratory changes.
  • It is important to ensure that volume depletion is corrected before spinal anesthesia because venous return and hence cardiac output are diminished.
  • These changes are aggravated by keeping the head up

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is admitted with bleeding from esophageal varices. Investigation reveals that he has an occlusion of the portal vein. There is no evidence of liver cirrhosis. Which test will most likely reveal an underlying pre-disposing factor for this condition?

choices.text: Coagulation tests to include antithrombin III

questions.solution: Antithrombin III counteracts excess thrombin formation. The excess of thrombin facilitates the conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin. Portal vein thrombosis will lead to portal hypertension but not hepatic congestion, as seen in Budd-Chiari syndrome. Portal vein thrombosis may occur in cirrhosis, trauma, in patients on contraceptive tablets, and in those who have an increased propensity for thrombus formation. It is also a direct complication of periumbilical infection in the neonate

questions.text: While doing a pelvic examination of a pregnant woman in labour, the doctor finds that the fetal head is placed such that the occiput is placed anteriorly, 45 degrees to left of midline of maternal pelvis. Which of the following is the engaging diameter in the fetus in such position?
questions.solution:
The occiput placed anteriorly, 45 degrees to left of midline of maternal pelvis is suggestive of LOA that is left occipito-anterior position

Diameters Measurement in CM (Inches) Attitude of The Head Presentation
1. Suboccipito-bregmatic 9.5 cm (3 ¾’’) Complete flexion Vertex
2. Suboccipito-frontal 10 cm Incomplete flexion Vertex
3. Occipito-frontal 11.5 cm Incomplete flexion Vertex
4. Mento-vertical 14 cm (5 ½”) Deflexed head/ military position Brow
5. Submento vertical 11.5 cm Incomplete extension Face
6.Submento-bregmatic 9.5 cm (3 ¾’’) Complete extension Face

questions.text: A doctor posted in ICU and came to ENT OPD on April 2020 with loss of smell and taste for 3-4 days. There is no history of trauma. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Swab to RT-PCR

Covid-19 (Novel Coronavirus) (SARS-COV 2)

Clinical presentation- respiratory symptoms; fever; cough; shortness of breath; breathing difficulties; fatigue; sore throat; loss of smell and taste

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the clinic with increased weight gain and fatigue. She delivered a baby five months ago with no prenatal complications. Initially, she considered it average postpartum weight gain, but her health continued to deteriorate with an increase in fatigue by every day. Physical examination shows swelling in the neck, dry skin, and brittle nails. Lab shows an increase in TSH and a decrease in T3 and T4. Which of the following statements is irrelevant to the diagnosis of this patient?

choices.text: Glucocorticoids are almost always helpful as a treatment option

questions.solution:
Option D: Glucocorticoids are almost always helpful as a treatment option

  • A female with complaints of weight gain, fatigue, brittle nails, dry skin and increased neck swelling after pregnancy mostly suffers from postpartum thyroiditis.
  • It is a self-limiting disease and resolves itself.
  • No steroid use is advised.

Option A: It is self limiting disease

  • A female with complaints of weight gain, fatigue, brittle nails, dry skin and increased neck swelling after pregnancy mainly suffers from postpartum thyroiditis.
  • The lab values are also consistent with the diagnosis.
  • The patient first develops thyrotoxicosis, followed by hypothyroidism and then resolution.
  • it is a self limiting disease

Option B: It is associated with thyrotoxicosis

  • Thyrotoxicosis means an increase in the number of circulating thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) in the body due to any condition.
  • In postpartum thyroiditis, initially, thyrotoxicosis occurs due to the preformed thyroid hormones during the breakdown of the thyroid gland, which causes hyperthyroidism in the body.
  • This clinical state is followed by hypothyroidism, leading to a euthyroid state.

Option C: It is associated with hypothyroidism

  • Hypothyroidism occurs due to the depletion of thyroid hormone in the body.
  • It is a brief state.
  • It eventually leads to a euthyroid state. ​​​​​​​

questions.text:
Match the structures and where they are found in:





Hofbauer cells
Peg cells
Folds of Hoboken
Langhans cells



a. Umbilical cord.
b. Chorionic villi of placenta.
c. Cytotrophoblastd.
d. Fallopian tube
questions.solution:
Structure Seen in
Nitabuch's membrane It is the zone of fibroid degeneration where trophoblast and decidua meet. Seen in the basal plate of the placenta.
Folds of Hoboken Umbilical cord
Wharton's jelly Connective tissue of the umbilical cord
Peg cells Fallopian tube
Langhans cells Cytotrophoblast
Hofbauer cells Phagocytic cell seen in the connective tissue of chorionic villi of placenta

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented to your hospital with complaints of altered sensorium followed by seizure for one day. He had a history of chronic alcohol intake for about 25 years. He used to take around 750 ml of country-made alcohol daily. MR imaging showed low signal intensity in T1WI in the central portion of genu, body, and splenium of the corpus callosum suggesting demyelination. Your most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Marchiafavabignami disease:

  • It is a rare neurological complication of long-term alcohol use.
  • It is characterized by epilepsy, ataxia, dysarthria, hallucinations, and intellectual deterioration. The pathophysiology is the demyelination of the corpus callosum, optic tracts, and cerebellar peduncles.

Wernicke’s encephalopathy:

  • It is an acute neurological complication characterized by the following symptoms (pneumonic GOA): G: Global confusion O: Ophthalmoplegia, usually 6th nerve palsy (second most common is 3rd nerve palsy) causing, horizontal nystagmus and gaze palsy) A: Ataxia

Korsakoff’s syndrome:

  • It is the chronic neurological complication of long-term alcohol use.
  • It is characterized by impaired recent memory, anterograde amnesia (inability to form new memory), retrograde amnesia (inability to recall old memories), and confabulations (making of false stories to fill memory gaps, which is unintentional). The anterograde amnesia is much more prominent than the retrograde amnesia

questions.text: A homeless man is admitted unresponsive after being found by the police on a park bench. He has no external signs of injury. An esophageal temperature probe records his core body temperature to be 34 °C. Which of the following management options is least likely to be routinely indicated in this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Warmed peritoneal lavage

  • ‘Active core rewarming methods’ are the reserve of severe hypothermia or hypothermia in high-risk patients (i.e. in conjunction with other injuries) and would not, therefore, be indicated in this scenario.

Hypothermia

Hypothermia is classified into :

  • mild (35–32°C),
  • moderate (32–30°C) and
  • severe (less than 30°C).

Clinical features:

  • Decreased consciousness, decreased respiratory rate and decreased heart rate.
  • Cardiac output also falls proportional to the severity of hypothermia, and a patient who initially lacks any signs of life may make a full recovery with appropriate supportive therapy.
  • The main cause of death is cardiac arrhythmia; the myocardium becomes increasingly irritable a temperature of 33°C and patients are at particular risk of fibrillation.
  • Because of this, all hypothermia patients require cardiac monitoring and should be rewarmed using 'passive external warming techniques', including blankets, external heat sources and warmed IV fluids.
  • The possibility of confounding causes of unresponsiveness should not be overlooked, and evidence of alcohol, drug use or sepsis should be excluded.
  • Hypoglycemia is another cause of reduced responsiveness that also frequently occurs secondary to hypothermia; therefore, blood glucose monitoring and IV dextrose should be initiated as standard.
  • Such techniques include warmed peritoneal lavage, warmed pleural lavage, warmed bladder irrigation, arteriovenous rewarming and cardiopulmonary bypass.
Hypothermia Temp Cardiac Neurologic response EKG/Other
Mild 90-95°F Excitation response (HR, BP, RR) Shivering Mild confusion  
Moderate  86-90°F Slowing of all physiologic functions, negative inotropic effect Cessation of shivering, worsening ataxia, loss of papillary reflex  EKG changes (Osborn waves)
Severe <86°F Dysarrhythmia (Bradycardia > AF > VF > Asystole) Pupils fixed/dilated Cold Diuresis, bronchorrhea, absent gag

Option A: Cardiac monitoring

  • Cardiac monitoring is required due to the effect of hypothermia on the heart

Option C: Warmed intravenous fluids

  • In case of hypothermia, warm IV fluid administration is advised

Option D: Intravenous dextrose

  • Hypoglycemia can occur due to hypothermia.
  • This can be managed with intravenous dextrose.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man complains of recurrent episodes of syncope. He believes that episodes occur when he turns his head too quickly. The last episode occurred when he was shaving. Which of the following is not helpful in the diagnosis of this patient?

choices.text: Carotid sinus massage with ECG monitoring
CT spine and base of brain

questions.solution:
· Holter recording can pick up any arrhythmia which could be causing syncope.

· The patient is probably having carotid sinus hypersensitivity leading to syncope. It is diagnosed by performing Carotid sinus massage with ECG monitoring and all resuscitative equipment.

· CT cervical spine and base of the brain can pick up vertebrobasilar insufficiency which could lead to syncopal attacks.

· Dix Hallpike maneuver is used for diagnosis of BPPV which presents as vertigo and dizziness on the sudden turning of the head. However, syncope is not a presentation and hence this test is unlikely to help in diagnosis.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman was admitted to the hospital after one day of shortness of breath and 2 weeks of dull chest pain, and a non-purulent productive cough. On the first night, after four hours of sleep, the patient was awakened for the second time; she promptly sat up in bed, looked at her right arm, and yelled, “There’s blood all over my arm!”. The resident physician examined her arm and saw only a clean IV placement. The physician reassured her that there was nothing there, the patient sat still and allowed herself to be evaluated. She showed no signs of a formal thought disorder or of delusion, and she denied any hallucination apart from feeling and seeing blood on her arm; Speech was organized normally and neurological exam was normal. This could probably be:
questions.solution:
This case shows that even with no history of prior psychiatric or neurologic disorders, patients in the hospital can have quite striking hallucinations upon awakening. Given the high prevalence of hypnopompic hallucinations among normal persons, it is no surprise many clinicians tend to disregard isolated incidences such as the one described.

  • Hypnogogic hallucination - occur while going to sleep.
  • Hypnopompic hallucinations - occur while getting up from sleep
  • Jactatio capitis nocturna or rhythmic movement disorder is a neurological disorder characterized by involuntary movements, usually of head and neck, before and during sleep.

HOW TO REMEMBER: think of moving your head on plugging in audio jack and nocturna implies it occur at night.

  • In reflex hallucinations, stimulus in one modality results in the development of hallucination in another modality

questions.text: A 20-year-old previously healthy swimmer is admitted for new-onset severe fatigue and left upper abdominal pain. She was treated two days ago in hospital for presumed typhoid fever with cefotaxime. Her family or past medical history is insignificant except for recurrent typhoid fever. She is a non-alcoholic and non-smoker. Her blood pressure is 120/85 mmHg, and her heart rate is 120 bpm. Physical examination reveals a palpable spleen. The stool is negative for heme. Lab investigations show haemoglobin of 5 g/dL with normal total lymphocyte count (TLC) and platelets. A peripheral blood smear reveals IgG antibodies and an excess of spherocytes. Which of the following do not cause a similar type of condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Infectious mononucleosis

This patient’s recent medication history with the lab values mostly suggests autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) due to the development of warm immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibodies as a consequence of cefotaxime exposure.

Autoimmune haemolytic anaemia (AIHA):

  • It is idiopathic normocytic anaemia, where the body’s immune system produces autoantibodies directed against its own RBC that attack and destroy RBC.
  • These autoantibodies bind to RBC cell surface antigens and cause them to clump
  • A warm antibody (IgG) hemolytic anaemia is the most common form of AIHA.
  • Another form of AIHA is cold (IgM) antibody hemolytic anaemia.
  • Infectious mononucleosis is associated with cold (IgM) AIHA.
  • Autoantibodies generally react at temperatures > 37° C.
  • Hemolysis occurs primarily in the spleen, resulting in splenomegaly.
  • The autoantibodies production may occur due to:
    • Spontaneously
    • SLE, lymphoma, CLL
    • Drug exposure: alpha-methyldopa, high-dose penicillin, cephalosporins, quinidine.
  • Coombs test is the best investigation to diagnose AIHA.

Option A: SLE

  • SLE is an autoimmune disease that is associated with AIHA.

Option B: α-Methyldopa ingestion

  • This drug can also cause the development of autoantibodies to RBC, resulting in AIHA.

Option C: Quinidine

  • Quinidine exposure can also cause AIHA by producing antibodies against RBC.

questions.text: As per the recent guidelines of Resuscitation what to be done if asystole is not responding to two consecutive doses of epinephrine, what will be the next step?

choices.text: Vasopressin is the second line drug

Osteosarcoma

  • MC bone tumor in children occurring in 2nd decade metaphyseal tumor –distal end of the femur.

questions.text: A child can make a 3 cube tower at the age of:
