questions.text: A patient presented with a history of blunt trauma to the chest and abdomen. On USG examination in M mode, the following finding is seen. What could be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Pneumothorax is a serious potential consequence of blunt thoracic trauma and, if misdiagnosed, it may quickly become life-threatening.
  • On M mode of USG, classical signs for the gray scale imaging are seen:
    • seashore sign: normal lung sliding
    • Barcode/stratosphere sign: pneumothorax

questions.text: Young female comes in with primary amenorrhea with normal breast, normal pubic hair. USG reveals absent uterus and cervix with short vaginal pouch and ovaries. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mullerian agenesis:

  • Congenital absence of both uterus and vagina is referred as Mullerian agenesis or Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome.
  • In classic Mullerian agenesis, patients have a shallow vaginal pouch. In addition, the uterus, cervix and upper part of the vagina are absent.
  • Typically, a portion of the distal fallopian tubes are present. In addition, normal ovaries are present, given their separate embryonic origin.
  • Most patients with Mullerian agenesis have only small rudimentary Mullerian bulbs without endometrial activity
  • Surgical excision of symptomatic rudimentary bulbs is required. With Mullerian agenesis, traditional conception is impossible, but pregnancy may be achieved using sophisticated technology involving oocyte retrieval, fertilization and implantation into a surrogate.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl was referred to the emergency room with a significant vaginal hemorrhage, originating from a wide laceration of the posterior fourchette, and a negative history of accidental trauma. The mother noticed blood in her underwear, and also noticed that when giving the child a bath, something did not look right in her vaginal area. No significant medical or surgical history was noted. What should be the first line of management?

choices.text: Inform police before starting the treatment

questions.solution: The first priority in management of a case trauma is airway maintenance.Ensuring an adequate airway is the first priority in the primary survey of trauma.

questions.text: A patient being operated under GA is paralysed, is on ventilator. Sudden appearance of cleft in the plateau phase of capnogram. What does this signify?
questions.solution:
• The cleft described here is known as curare cleft.
  • It signifies that the person returns of spontaneous ventilation

  • In Malignant hyperthermia, the EtCO2 begins to rise in capnogram

  • In CO2 rebreathing, the baseline of CO2 elevates

  • Partial obstruction of ET tube presents with shark fin pattern

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the outpatient department for her yearly evaluation. She has no active complaints but is concerned about her chances of a brain bleed. She has had a history of recurrent renal stones for 5 years and an episode of pyelonephritis a year ago. She has a family history of renal disease and brain bleeding due to the ruptured berry aneurysm. Which of the following is not an associated feature of a berry aneurysm?

choices.text: Aneurysms >7 mm in size and at the top of the vertebral artery have the highest chances of rupture.
Prior intracranial haemorrhage increases the risk of subsequent haemorrhage.
It presents as a thunderclap headache.
The most common site is the junction of the anterior communicating artery with the anterior cerebral artery.

questions.solution:
Option A: Aneurysms >7 mm in size and at the top of the vertebral artery has the highest chances of rupture.

  • Saccular cerebral aneurysms/berry aneurysms are the most common cause of non-traumatic subarachnoid haemorrhage.
  • Risk factors for rupture of berry aneurysm include: 
  • Family history increases the risk of rupture
  • Prior intracranial haemorrhage increases the risk of subsequent haemorrhage.
  • Aneurysm >10 mm
  • Uncontrolled hypertension
  • It presents as the ‘worst headache of life’/thunderclap headache, nausea, vomiting, loss of consciousness, and stupor.
  • Physical examination reveals nuchal rigidity.
  • Non-contrast CT scan of the brain shows hyperdensity in the region of bleed.
  • Most of the aneurysms are found: 
    • At the junction of the anterior communicating artery with the anterior cerebral artery (30% to 35%),
    • At the junction of the posterior communicating artery with the internal carotid artery (25%-30%)
    • The middle cerebral artery bifurcation (20%)
  • The annual risk of rupture for aneurysms less than 10 mm in size is approximately 0.1%, and for aneurysms more than or equal to 10 mm in size is approximately 0.5–1%.
  • The mortality rate due to rupture of berry aneurysms is between 25—50%.

Option B: Prior intracranial haemorrhage increases the risk of subsequent haemorrhage.

  • Patients with a history of previous bleeding due to berry aneurysm rupture have a higher risk of another rupture.

Option C: It presents as a thunderclap headache.

  • Berry aneurysm rupture results in a thunderclap/worst headache of life.

Option D: The most common site is the junction of the anterior communicating artery with the anterior cerebral artery.

  • The junction of the anterior communicating artery with the anterior cerebral artery accounts for 30%-35% of cases of berry aneurysm rupture.

questions.text: Which of the following is single dose drug of choice for trachoma?
questions.solution:
Azithromycin

Epidemiology

  • •10 % of population when is suffering from trachoma is called its epidemic.

Rx

SAFE

  • S : Surgery
  • A : Antibiotic Prophylaxis
  • F : Facial Cleanliness
  • E : Environment Cleanliness
  • DOC : azithromycin, 1g

Other options : Tetracycline Ointment (1 %) four times in a day for 6 weeks

questions.text: A known case of invasive ductal carcinoma was referred to your hospital from a private clinic for further evaluation and management. You admitted the patient to the medical ward and ordered all the routine tests and scans. Which part would you scan first if you are suspecting a metastasis from its primary tumor :
questions.solution:
Metastases occur after breast cancers acquire their own blood supply (neovascularization) which occurs approximately at the 20th cell doubling

Thereafter, cancer cells may be shed directly into the systemic venous blood to seed the pulmonary circulation via the axillary and intercostal veins of the vertebral column via the Batson plexus of veins, which courses the length of the vertebral column

These cells are scavenged by natural killer lymphocytes and macrophages

Successful implantation of the metastatic foci from breast cancer predictably occurs after primary cancer exceeds 0.5 cm in diameter, which corresponds to the 27th cell doubling

60% of the women who develop distant metastases will do so within 60 months of treatment

Tumour size and nodal status remain, powerful predictors of late recurrences,

Common sites of involvement in order of frequency are bone, lung, pleura, soft tissues, liver, and brain. Brain metastasis is more likely to be seen in triple receptor-negative breast cancer

Treatment involves palliative chemotherapy or hormone therapy depending on the receptor status

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy has been complaining of headaches, ignoring objects on the sides for four months. His grades at school are good.On examination, his visual acuity is diminished in both eyes. Visual charting showed significant field defects. A CT scan of the head showed a suprasellar mass with calcification. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Craniopharyngioma

  • The given scenario suggests the diagnosis of craniopharyngioma.
  • CRANIOPHARYNGIOMA
    • Derived from Rathke’s pouch
    • They have a bimodal distribution occurring predominantly in children, in adults between 55 and 65.
    • Presents with increased intracranial pressure, including headache, vomiting, papilledema, and hydrocephalus. Symptoms result from compression of adjacent structures, especially the optic chiasm.
    • Calcification occurs in all pediatric and roughly half of adult craniopharyngiomas.
    • Treatment involves transcranial or transsphenoidal surgical resection followed by postoperative radiation of the residual tumour.
    • The most frequent postoperative complications include diabetes insipidus and hypothalamic injury, with 5% to 10% mortality. Visual loss and cognitive impairment from basal frontal injury are common complications.
    • Treatment requires medical optimization before surgical resection because there is adrenal cortical insufficiency; hydrocortisone coverage should be given first perioperatively.

Option A: Astrocytoma

  • Astrocytoma is cancer that can develop in the spinal cord or brain.
  • The astrocytes that sustain nerve cells are the sites of astrocytoma where it develops.
  • Signs and symptoms of astrocytoma are dependent on the location of the tumour.
  • Nausea, headaches, and seizures are the symptoms that can be due to astrocytomas in the brain.

Option C: Pituitary adenoma

  • Pituitary adenomas are the tumours of the pituitary gland that are benign.
  • In these circumstances, headache is often characterized by constant, unilateral or bifrontal aching (ipsilateral to the tumour). In some cases, the midface is the specific location of pain (either because of involvement of the second division of the trigeminal or secondary to sinusitis).
  • A pituitary adenoma will occur in roughly 1 in 10 people during their lives.
  • Some pituitary adenomas secrete an excessive amount of one or more hormones.
  • The most frequent signs are double vision or vision loss, headaches, and hormone dysfunction, in which impotence, loss of menstrual cycle, weight gain and fatigue are included.

Option D: Meningioma

  • A meningioma is a tumour arising from the meninges: The membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord.
  • Symptoms:
    • Changes in the vision, such as blurriness or seeing double
    • Headaches that worsen with time
    • Hearing loss or ringing in the ears
    • Memory loss
    • Loss of smell

questions.text: After birth, a newborn receives vaccinations as per the NIS guidelines. After a few days, she developed ulceration at one of the vaccination sites. The mother eventually brought the baby to the hospital after she developed a fever. On examination, it was found that she suffered osteitis. What is the most likely vaccine responsible for the current presentation?
questions.solution:
Option B: BCG

  • Bacillus Calmette–Guérin vaccine is a vaccine primarily used against tuberculosis.
  • Side effects of the BCG vaccine
    • Local ulceration
    • Discharging sinus
    • Axillary lymphadenitis
    • In immunocompromised pt → Disseminated infection, osteomyelitis, and scrofuloderma are seen.

Option A: Hepatitis B vaccine

  • Side effects:
  • Swelling, tenderness, redness, warmth, or a hard lump where the shot was given.
  • Low fever.
  • Nausea.
  • Loss of appetite.
  • Headache.
  • There is one extremely rare but serious side effect. About 1 out of every 600,000 doses of the hepatitis B vaccine will cause a severe allergic reaction, called anaphylaxis, with symptoms including mouth swelling, difficulty breathing, low blood pressure or shock.

Option C: Measles vaccine

  • The MMR vaccine is very safe. Most side effects are mild and do not last long, such as the area where the needle goes in, looking red, swollen and feeling sore for 2 to 3 days.
  • Side effects:
  • Sore arm from the shot.
  • Fever.
  • Mild rash.
  • Temporary pain and stiffness in the joints, mostly in teenage or adult women who did not already have immunity to the rubella component of the vaccine.

Option D: IPV

  • Polio vaccines are vaccines used to prevent poliomyelitis.
  • Two types are used: an inactivated poliovirus given by injection and a weakened poliovirus given by mouth.
  • Side effects are very uncommon with the polio vaccine. They are usually very mild and go away within a few days.
  • Side effects: Redness/swelling/tenderness at the injection site, fever, irritability, and tiredness

questions.text: A thirty years old G2P1L1 female presents to your clinic with the complaint of intermittent jaundice. He says she has had jaundice for the past four years, and it comes and goes on its own. She had episodes of jaundice during each pregnancy, which used to start in the late second trimester. In between pregnancies, there was minimal or no jaundice. Initial investigations show conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Further investigations reveal that she has an MRP2 transporter defect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Dubin Johnson syndrome

  • Dubin-Johnson syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder.
  • It occurs due to a defect in the multidrug resistance-associated protein 2 (MRP2) protein.
  • Multidrug resistance-associated protein 2 (MRP2), an ATP-dependent canalicular membrane transporter.
  • This protein is encoded by a gene known as ABCC2 Gene, which is mutated in Dubin-Johnson syndrome.
  • Dubin-Johnson syndrome is characterized by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with mild jaundice.
  • Triggering agents/conditions: Pregnancy, Oral contraceptive pills and illness.
  • Kernicterus is absent, with a liver biopsy showing black pigmentation.

Option A: Menke’s disease

  • Menkes disease is an X-linked recessive disorder,
  • It is caused by mutations in genes coding for the copper-transport protein ATP7A.
  • This leads to copper deficiency.

Option C: Familial intrahepatic cholestasis

  • Familial intrahepatic cholestasis causes progressive liver disease, typically leading to liver failure.
  • It is not associated with MRP-2 defect.

Option D: Benign recurrent intrahepatic cholestasis

  • Episodes of liver dysfunction called cholestasis characterize benign recurrent intrahepatic cholestasis.
  • It is not associated with MRP-2 defect.

questions.text: A 60-year-old laborer is pyrexial and undergoes abdominal USG. A 10 cm hypoechoic, well-defined cyst is seen in the left lobe of the liver. It contains a smaller cyst within it and a small amount of calcification within the cyst wall. What is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
• Ultrasound and CT scans are the investigations of choice for hydatid.
  • The CT scan shows a smooth space-occupying lesion with several septa. An ultrasound of the biliary tract may show abnormality in the gall bladder and bile ducts.
  • Hydatid infestation of the biliary system should then be suspected.
  • Ultimately, the diagnosis is made by a combination of good history and clinical examination supplemented by serology and radiological imaging techniques.
  • MRI, CT, and ultrasound reveal well-defined cysts with thick or thin walls. When older cysts contain a layer of hydatid sand that is rich in accumulated protoscolices, these imaging methods may detect this fluid layer of different density. However, the most pathognomonic finding, if demonstrable, is that of daughter cysts within the larger cyst (as mentioned in the question).
  • This finding, like eggshell or mural calcification on CT, is indicative of E. granulosus infection and helps to distinguish the cyst from carcinomas, bacterial or amebic liver abscesses, or hemangiomas.
  • In contrast, ultrasound or CT of alveolar hydatid cysts reveals indistinct solid masses with central necrosis and plaque-like calcifications.
  • A specific diagnosis of E. granulosus infection can be made by the examination of aspirated fluids for protoscolices or hooklets, but diagnostic aspiration is not usually recommended because of the risk of fluid leakage resulting in either dissemination of infection or anaphylactic reactions.
  • Rx - Albendazole therapy followed by surgical excision (with or without instillation of cysticidal agent).

questions.text: A patient has primary open-angle glaucoma in his right eye. His visual acuity was 10/90; despite being on timolol, pilocarpine, and acetazolamide, the IOP remains 20 to 24mmhg. A subsequent visual field test showed further field loss progression in this eye. Which one of the following is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Argon laser trabeculoplasty

  • This is a case of medically refractory open-angle glaucoma. In this case, surgery is commonly undertaken to arrest visual field loss.
  • Laser trabeculoplasty, both argon laser trabeculoplasty(ALT) and selective laser trabeculoplasty (SLT) types is used to increase aqueous outflow facility through the trabecular meshwork (TM) to lower intraocular pressure (IOP) in cases of ocular hypertension and glaucoma.
  • This is the best treatment choice for this patient.

Option A: Seton Placement

  • It is done in cases of refractory glaucoma where trabeculectomy has failed.

Option B: Trabeculectomy

  • Trabeculectomy is a filtering surgery where an ostium is created into the anterior chamber from underneath a partial thickness scleral flap to allow for aqueous flow out of the eye. The aqueous flows into the subconjunctival space, usually leading to an elevation of the conjunctiva, referred to as a filtering bleb.
  • Trabeculectomy is performed for treatment of glaucoma inadequately controlled by maximally tolerated medical therapy. But, better choices like laser trabeculoplasty are available.

Option D: Addition of apraclonidine

  • This is a medically refractive open-angle glaucoma case. In this case, Surgery is commonly undertaken to arrest visual field loss.
  • So, this is the wrong option.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true with respect to Cushing Disease?

choices.text: Pituitary microadenomas are often large and superficial within the gland itself
The treatment of choice for hypercortisolism due to a pituitary adenoma in women of childbearing age is transsphenoidal total hypophysectomy
Patients who fail to remit with both surgery and radiation to the pituitary require either medical or surgical adrenalectomy
The long-term recurrence rate after resection of an ACTH-producing pituitary microadenoma is approximately 40%

questions.solution:
Pituitary microadenomas secreting ACTH may be very small and are often located deep within the gland itself. If the tumor is not evident on opening the dura, incisions must be made into the gland and internal exploration carried out. If no tumor is identified, then a decision must be made as to whether to resect all or a portion of the gland. If the endocrine evidence is convincing for pituitary origin and the patient has no desire to have children, then total hypophysectomy is warranted. If the petrosal sinus sampling clearly indicates laterality then appropriate hemiresection of the gland may be done.

About 75% of patients have microadenomas as the source of ACTH secretion. The postoperative remission rate in these patients is 88% to 96%, and the long-term recurrence rate appears to be no more than 5%. 10% to 20% of patients who undergo exploration have macroadenomas, and the postoperative remission rates in these patients have been reported to be from 33% to 61%. Most of these patients require postoperative radiation therapy. Patients who fail both surgery and radiation require either surgical adrenalectomy or medical suppression of adrenal function

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman neuro-fibromatosis II patient comes to the E.N.T. department with a 3-week history of intermittent episodes of dizziness. The episodes last for hours and are characterized by the sensation that the room is spinning. The patient also reports that she has started using her cell phone with her left ear because she hears better on that side. She has experienced intermittent ringing and fullness in her right ear. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 76/min, respiration is 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/76 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There is horizontal nystagmus to the right. M.R.I. revealed the below image. Which of the following audio-metric test is a reliable indicator in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: B.E.R.A.

  • The above given is a case of vestibular schwannoma.
  • The best audiometric test for vestibular schwannoma is B.E.R.A.
  • Brainstem-evoked response audiometry (B.E.R.A.) is very useful in the diagnosis of retro-cochlear lesions. In the presence of the VIIIth nerve tumour, a delay of > 0.2 ms in wave V between two ears is significant.
  • Vestibular Schwannoma is a benign tumour of abnormally proliferative Schwann cells, which covers the lateral portion of the vestibular nerve in the internal acoustic meatus.
  • Earlier name - acoustic neuroma (obsolete now).
  • Most common benign tumour of the cerebellopontine angle. (C.P. angle)
  • Usually unilateral but bilateral in neurofibromatosis II.
  • Site of origin:
    • Inf. vestibular nerve in IAC (60-90%) → most common.
    • Sometimes sup vestibular nerve.
    • Rarely from the cochlear nerve.
    • Arises from Schwann cells in the myelin sheath.
  • Clinical features:
    • SNHL - slow & progressive (most common presentation).
    • Tinnitus.
    • Vertigo/dizziness (not prominent).
  • Signs:
    • Earliest: Loss of corneal reflex (due to 5th nerve involvement).
    • Hitzelberger sign: Loss of sensory supply by the facial nerve in the posterosuperior wall of the external auditory canal.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Gadolinium-enhanced MRI→ (initial investigation of choice).
    • The best test for acoustic neuroma is B.E.R.A.
    • The most diagnostic finding suggestive of acoustic neuroma on B.E.R.A. has increased interaural latency of wave V of > 0.2 ms.
  • Treatment:
    • Large tumour– surgical excision.
    • Small tumour
      • Old patient, slow-growing tumour - serial M.R.I. every 6M.
      • A young patient with a fast-growing tumour - gamma knife excision.
      • Approaches for surgical excision.
      • When there is no hearing present: Translabyrinthine approach.
      • If hearing present: Middle cranial fossa approach (limited access).
      • Retro sigmoid /suboccipital approach: The tumour is sent for histopathology after Sx excision.
        • Anatomy A cells: More common
        • Densely packed cells with small spindle-shaped nuclei.
        • Anatomy B cells: Loosely arranged, vacuolated pleomorphic cells.

Option A: Speech Audiometry

  • Speech audiometry shows poor speech discrimination, and this is disproportionate to pure tone hearing loss. Roll-over phenomenon, i.e., reduction of discrimination score when loudness is increased beyond a particular limit, is most commonly observed.

Option B: Age-wise hearing assessment

  • This test is usually done on children.
  • This test is done at the age starting from 6 months to 10 years.
  • Adults get their hearing test every 10 years until the age of 50 and then every 3 years after 50 years of age.

Option D: Pure tone audiometry

  • Pure tone audiometry will show sensorineural hearing loss, more marked in high frequencies.
  • It determines the type, degree, and configuration of hearing loss.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man is being treated for pulmonary emphysema. He is admitted with labored breathing at rest with marked use of accessory muscles. Arterial blood gas analysis revealed:
pH 7.33
PaCO2 64 mm Hg
PaO2 50 mm Hg
HCO3 34 mEq/L
What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Since the patient with emphysema presents with respiratory distress and muscle fatigue, on clinical grounds he is probably having respiratory acidosis.

  • pH of blood =7.33, interpretation is acidosis
  • pCO2 is 64 mm Hg (average of 40 mmHg), interpretation is increased pCO2 which explains the acidosis.
  • HCO3 is increased and indicates compensation (N = 22-26 mEq).
  • The diagnosis is compensated respiratory acidosis. The next step is to find out acute versus chronic compensation.
  • The rule to be followed for acute compensation is for every 10 mm Hg rise of pCO2, HCO3 rises by 1 mEq.
  • The rule to be followed for chronic compensation is for every 10 mmHg rise of pC02, HC03 rises by 4mEq or more.
  • Since the rule mentioned just above this statement is mathematically satisfied, the diagnosis is chronic compensated respiratory acidosis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a known history of uncontrolled diabetes presents to the physician with complaints of severe persistent earache, greenish discharge from the ear, and headache for 3 months. He is otherwise vitally stable and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. Otoscopy reveals granulation tissue at the cartilage bone of the external auditory canal. Which of the following dehiscence in the external auditory canal leads to the spread of infection in this case?
questions.solution:
Option A: Fissures of Santorini

  • This is a case of malignant otitis externa. Malignant external otitis (MEO) is an infection that affects the external auditory canal and temporal bone.
    • The causative organism is usually pseudomonas aeruginosa, and the disease commonly manifests in immune deficiency patients.
    • The infection begins as external otitis that progresses into osteomyelitis of the temporal bone (Lateral skull base osteomyelitis).
    • The spread of the disease outside the external auditory canal occurs through the fissures of Santorini (two vertical fissures in the anterior portion of the cartilage of the external auditory meatus, filled with fibrous tissue) and the osseocartilaginous junction.

Option B: Notch of Rivinus

  • It is a defect in the upper tympanic part of the temporal bone, filled by the upper portion of the tympanic membrane.

Option C: Petro-tympanic fissure

  • It is a fissure in the temporal bone that runs from the temporomandibular joint to the tympanic cavity.

Option D: Foramen of Huschke

  • It represents a developmental defect in the anteroinferior aspect of the bony external auditory meatus.

questions.text: A chest x-ray of a 1-year-old female patient reveals a prominent main pulmonary artery segment and normal pulmonary vascular markings. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• Patients with pulmonic stenosis may have a dilated main pulmonary artery segment due to poststenotic dilation but will not have increased pulmonary vascular markings because there is no left-to-right shunting of blood.
  • Choice a and d will have increased pulmonary vascular markings.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female primigravida gives birth to an infant at the gestational age of 39 weeks, and the baby's birth weight is 1500 grams. The cry is delayed and weak. On examination, reflexes are sluggish, and on the U/S brain, no solid or cystic lesion was seen. Mild hydrocephalus dilated all four brain edema grade 2 parenchymal and IVH, including the germinal matrix. Grade 2 intracranial hemorrhage is ruled out. At a CT scan of the brain, extensive white matter edema involving the subcortical regions of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes caused effacement of the right lateral ventricle. No hemorrhagic density is identified. Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy involving the frontal, parietal, and temporal regions. Which part of the brain is most commonly affected?
questions.solution:
Option B: Parasagittal area

  • According to signs and symptoms, the case mentioned above is of Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy and the area mainly involved the parasagittal site.
  • Part of the brain most commonly involved in term neonates with HIE is the Parasagittal area.
  • In preterm neonates- Periventricular area.
  • The most common cause of seizure in newborns is Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy
  • The most common type of neonatal seizures: Subtle seizures

Option A: Periventricular area

  • The severity, duration, and level of brain development of hypoxia all affect the pattern of brain injury.
  • Preterm newborns with mild to moderate HI damage develop periventricular leukomalacia and germinal matrix haemorrhage.

Option C: Basal ganglia

  • The brain's basal ganglia, cerebral cortex, and watershed regions are typically damaged in HIE. However, PVL can also occur.
  • The term "PVL" refers to damage to the brain's white matter close to the lateral ventricles, which are found in the top part of the brain.

Option D: Hippocampus

  • The hippocampus and cerebellum showed the most severe histopathologic brain damage, followed by the cortex, and the brainstem showed the least harm.

questions.text: Identify the fundus photo and corresponding optical coherence tomography picture
questions.solution:
MACULAR HOLE

•Retinal layers are missing at macula

• Causes: Idiopathic > Trauma, post CME

• Vitreomacular traction is cause of Macular hole . (tangential forces are more important than horizontal forces)

• Internal limiting membrane peeling & vitrectomy surgery are done for treatment. Stem cells trial has been done for macular hole closure

BERLINS EDEMA WITH CHERRY RED SPOT- Red spot in midst of a pale retina (c.f Bull's eye retinopathy, where the red glow of fundus is maintained)

GYRATE ATROPHY

•AR inheritance pattern
