The hyperpigmented area of fovea is surrounded by paler macula. See the rest of the fundus seems to be of normal orange glow

questions.text: A patient came to the OPD with projectile vomiting and a history of morning stiffness. On fundus examination, there is disc edema in both eyes. Which of the following is not a correct statement for this patient?

choices.text: Intra cranial tension would be increased
Visual pathway obstructive lesion is suspected
Optic atrophy is seen in early stages

questions.solution:
Papilledema

- Disc edema a/w increased ICP

Symptoms

- Projectile vomiting

- Morning Headache

- Transient blurring of vision

Sign

- Dilation and tortuosity of vessels

- Blurring of disc margins

- Elevation of Disc

- Late stages optic atrophy & Corpora amyalacea

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension

- Papilledema with increased IOP with no intracranial space-occupying lesion

- Causes: Weight gain, OCP, Hypervitaminosis A, Hypovitaminosis D, Blood dyscrasia, hyperthyroidism, salicylate intoxication

Rx

- Treatment of the cause and oral acetazolamide

- Is an indication of termination of pregnancy

- Ventriculoperitoneal shunt can be done to decrease IOP

questions.text: While playing football an 18-year-old boy was hit on the nose and developed a deviation of nose. O/E, the septum has not deviated. Which of the following statements about the patient is true?

choices.text: He should be taken up for open reduction one week later
He should be taken for closed reduction as soon as overlying edema subsides
Septoplasty should be done in the same sitting

questions.solution: • Since the septum has not deviated, he is most likely having a Chevallet fracture. Hence he should be managed by closed reduction as soon as overlying edema subsides which generally takes around 5 – 7 days.

questions.text: 21 years old male came to the hospital with injury sustained to the wrist while riding a bicycle. X-ray of the wrist is depicted here. Which of the following bone is fractured?

A 4-year-old girl is brought to the ENT clinic by her parents with the complaint of abnormally muffled voice since birth. She was born full term and has normally achieved her developmental milestones. On examination, there is no sign of respiratory distress. Laryngoscopy reveals a thin membrane with a concave posterior border between the vocal cords. Which of the following is the most common site of the above pathology?
questions.solution:
Option B: Glottis

  • The above clinical and laryngoscopy findings are typical of the laryngeal web.
  • Laryngeal web occurs due to incomplete canalization of the larynx during can result in a congenital laryngeal web.
  • The combination of a weak cry since birth and recurrent croup in infancy should always raise suspicion of a laryngeal web.
  • Most laryngeal webs involve the anterior glottis, joining the vocal cords along a variable part of their length, producing a varying degree of respiratory obstruction and dysphonia.
  • Below is a laryngoscopy image of the glottis narrowed by a laryngeal web.

Option A: Supraglottis

  • Most laryngeal webs involve the anterior glottis.
  • Supraglottis is not a usual site of the congenital laryngeal webs.

Option C: Subglottis

  • Most laryngeal webs involve the anterior glottis.
  • Subglottis is not a usual site of the congenital laryngeal webs.
  • Subglottis can be affected by congenital subglottic stenosis (without a web).

Option D: Trachea

  • Although the trachea is also involved in many congenital anomalies, congenital webs are usually a part of laryngeal pathologies.
  • The common congenital anomalies of the trachea include tracheomalacia, tracheal rings, and trachea-esophageal fistula.

questions.text:
(A) True or (B) False about HELLP syndrome

HIgh-dose steroid therapy with dexamethasone is C/I as it slows fetal improvement
Most common symptoms are epigastric or right upper quadrant pain, nausea and vomiting
Criteria for the diagnosis includes Bilirubin > 1.2 ml/dl; Platelet <100 x 10 3 /mm 3; Absent plasma haptoglobin
Most common cause of maternal death in HELLP syndrome is hemorrhagic shock
questions.solution:
HELLP syndrome

  • It is a variant of severe preeclampsia, comprising of Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, and a Low Platelet count.
  • Regardless of the blood pressure, these cases are at increased maternal and fetal risk.
  • common symptoms are epigastric or right upper quadrant pain, nausea and vomiting.
  • The hallmark of the disorder is micro-angiopathic hemolysis leading to elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase level and fragmented red blood cells on peripheral smear.

Criteria for the diagnosis of HELLP syndrome

Hemolysis

  • Burr cells, schistocytes in the blood smear
  • Bilirubin > 1.2 ml/dl
  • Absent plasma haptoglobin

Elevated liver enzymes

  • SGOT (AST) > 72 IU/L
  • LDH > 600 IU/L

Low platelet count

  • Platelet <100 x 10 3 /mm 3

Management

  • It is an obstetric emergency and should be managed by Immediate termination of pregnancy in maternal interest
  • High-dose steroid therapy with dexamethasone hasten the fetal improvement.
  • Supportive treatment in the form of platelet transfusion, fresh frozen plasma and plasmapheresis may be required.

Extra Edge:

  • Overall most common time of occurrence of HELLP syndrome – Antepartum (between 28-36 weeks).
  • Most common cause of maternal death in HELLP syndrome – Abruptio placentae and DIC

questions.text: A 7-month-old infant was brought to you with a history of hypotonia, seizures, failure to thrive & growth retardation. He is noted to have the appearance of the characteristic sparse, fragile, kinky hair and hypo-pigmented skin. Initial investigations revealed anaemia & neutropenia. A probable diagnosis of Menke’s kinky (Steely) hair disease was made. Which of the following results would usually be seen in such patients?
questions.solution:
Option A: Low copper levels.

  • Menkes disease is an X-linked recessive disease that occurs due to a mutation in the ATP7A gene leading to defective Menkes protein.
  • The defective Menkes protein causes abnormal absorption and transport of copper.
  • Low copper levels lead to decreased lysyl oxidase activity, as copper is an essential enzyme cofactor.
  • The decreased activity of lysyl oxidase causes defective collagen production, leading to various clinical features.

Clinical Features

  • Progressive cerebral degeneration, growth retardation.
  • Hypotonia, seizures.
  • Hypo-pigmented skin and hair.
  • Sparse, brittle, kinky hair.
  • Scurvy-like bone changes.
  • Anemia and neutropenia.
  • Failure to thrive.
  • Pili torti, trichorrhexis, and monilethrix may occur.

Other options

Option B: Low zinc levels

  • Low zinc levels do not cause Menkes disease.
  • Symptoms of low zinc levels include delayed wound healing, suppressed immunity, male hypogonadism, hair loss, and loss of taste and smell.

Option C: Low iron levels

  • Low iron levels do not cause Menkes disease.
  • It causes iron deficiency anaemia as fatigue, conjunctival pallor, koilonychia and pica.

Option D: Low ceruloplasmin levels

  • Low ceruloplasmin is seen in Wilson’s disease and not in Menkes disease.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is admitted for asymptomatic renal stones. She received extensive resection of the small intestine due to strangulating obstructive ileus 7 years ago. She has a strong family history of renal stones. A plain film of the kidney, ureter, and bladder and a CT scan revealed bilateral renal stones (right 4 mm, left 10 mm). Which of the following could have predisposed the patient to develop urolithiasis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Short bowel syndrome

  • Malabsorptive condition that arises secondary to the removal of significant segments of the small intestine.
  • Most common causes are Mesenteric infarction, Crohn's disease, tumours, and radiation enteritis
  • It usually appears when there is less than 200 cm of small bowel
Changes seen in Terminal Ileal Resection
  • Unabsorbed fatty acids bind with calcium. Increased concentration of free oxalates (oxalates bind with calcium normally and therefore escape without intestinal absorption)- Free oxalates are absorbed- Oxalate kidney stones
  • Vitamin B12 Malabsorption- Megaloblastic anaemia.
  • Bile salts Malabsorption-watery diarrhoea
  • Decreased bile salts in the bile−
    • Cholesterol gall stones
    • Steatorrhea and Malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins

Option A: Family history of renal stones

  • Kidney stones develop more frequently in individuals with a family history of kidney stones than in those without a family history; however, little information is available regarding whether the increased risk is attributable to genetic factors, environmental exposures, or some combination
  • This patient has a history of small bowel resection, which predisposes him to kidney stones

Option C: Strangulating obstructive ileus

  • Strangulated bowel obstruction is defined as ischemia and infarction of an obstructed loop of the bowel because of the compromised blood supply.
  • The disease itself has no association with the development of kidney stones. However, bowel resection performed as a result of it predisposes to kidney stones.

Option D: Prolonged hospitalization and bedridden

  • The risk factors for kidney stones include metabolic diseases, small bowel resection, recurrent urinary transactions, dehydration, and poor dietary habits.
  • Prolonged hospitalization is not a risk factor for kidney stones.

questions.text: The patient, an 8 months old baby, was identified as a female baby since birth; but, some senior members of their family raised confusion regarding the sex differentiation of the child. On examination, there was enlarged clitoris or micropenis, bifid scrotum or labioscrotal fold, and separate presence of urethral and vaginal orifices. The right testis was found in the middle of the right inguinal canal and the left testis was found near the deep inguinal ring. The probable cause for this ambiguity is:
questions.solution:
• In a female most common cause of ambiguous sex is congenital adrenal hyperplasia.
  • In fact, cases of ambiguity of sex, detected at birth are due to adrenogenital syndrome (congenital adrenal hyperplasia) unless proved otherwise.
  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder (if any couple has had one affected child, the subsequent baby has a 1 in 4 chance of having the same disability).

questions.text: A 54-year-old Malay, para 5, was seen with complaints of per vaginal bleeding of twenty days duration following twelve weeks of amenorrhea. Ultrasonography confirmed gestational trophoblastic neoplasia. The criteria for diagnosing GTN in this patient are all except:

choices.text: Plateau levels of b-hCG for 4 weeks

questions.solution:
Criteria for diagnosis of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia

  1. When 4 consecutive hCG values are plateau D1, D7, D14, D21 (± 10% of previous value)
  2. 3 consecutive hCG values are rising (> 10% of previous value) D1, D7, D14
  3. b-hCG level remains above normal even after 6 months of evacuation
  4. Histological criteria for choriocarcinoma

questions.text: A 35-year-old lactating woman who was a known case of deep vein thrombosis in her left calf came to your clinic for consultation. The patient is currently on heparin and is scheduled to begin a 6 weeks course of warfarin therapy. The patient wants to know whether she can breastfeed her baby. What is the advice that you will give to this patient?

choices.text: Patient may continue breastfeeding at her own risk
Patient can breastfeed her baby after 6 weeks course of warfarin is over
Patient should breastfeed her baby only if her INR is at <2.5
Warfarin is not a contraindication for breastfeeding; so she can breastfeed her baby

questions.solution:
Warfarin is contraindicated in the first trimester of pregnancy as it can lead to Contradi syndrome comprising of microcephaly, optic atrophy, nasal hypoplasia, and chondrodysplasia punctata. It can also lead to IUGR, abortions, and IUD.

But warfarin is absolutely safe during lactation as an extremely minute quantity of it is excreted in breast milk.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a known case of Hemochromatosis, cirrhosis, and portal hypertension was brought to ED with altered mental status. The attendant describes that the patient has been confused for the last 3 days, with no h/o melena or hematemesis. For chronic ascites, diet control and spironolactone are given regularly. He had an episode of variceal bleed in the past, for which he was put on propranolol, and no episodes have been seen since then. On examination, he is not well oriented to time and place but oriented to person. He is afebrile, vitals are stable, but ascites, and asterixis, are notable. His laboratory investigation shows haemoglobin of 10.1mg/dl, Creatinine of 1.4 mg.dl, and Blood urea nitrogen of 45 mg/dl. On paracentesis, clear fluid with 800 WBC (40% neutrophils) was seen. Which of the following is a false statement regarding this condition?

choices.text: Clinical features are abdominal pain, fever, leucocytosis and altered mental status

questions.solution:
Option A: Ascites is preceded by infection

  • SBP- a severe complication of ascites characterized by spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid without an intra-abdominal source.
  • Fluid is a transudate due to cirrhosis protein is <2.5 g/dl.
  • Patients with ascites may present with
    • Fever
    • Altered mental status
    • Abdominal pain or discomfort
    • Elevated WBC count
  • Bacterial translocation - gut flora traversing the intestine into mesenteric lymph nodes, leading to bacteremia and seeding of the ascitic fluid.
  • MC organisms - E. coli and other gut bacteria.
  • Absolute neutrophil count >250/mL. Bedside cultures should be obtained when ascitic fluid is tapped
  • Diagnosis: Ascitic tap having neutrophil count >250/μL is diagnostic
  • Treatment: Cefotaxime (best drug)
  • Prophylaxis:
    • Required in a patient with an episode(s) of SBP or who had recovered.
    • Once-weekly dosing of antibiotics.

Option B: Clinical features are abdominal pain, fever, leucocytosis and altered mental status

  • Patients with ascites may present with
    • Fever
    • Altered mental status
    • Abdominal pain or discomfort
    • Elevated WBC count

Option C: Ascitic fluid protein of 1 gm/dl

  • Fluid is a transudate due to cirrhosis protein is <2.5 g/dl.

Option D: Common organisms are Gram-negative organisms

  • MC organisms - E. coli and other gut bacteria.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman weighing 50 kg comes to the Burn Institute 1.5 hours after a flame burns her head, trunk, and limbs. The total burnt area is 50% TBSA (total body surface). How much lactate Ringer's solution have to be infused for fluid resuscitation in this patient in the first 8 hours of injury?
questions.solution:
Option B: 5 litres

Resuscitation formulas      
Formula Crystalloid volume Colloid Volume Free water
Parkland 4 mL / Kg per % TBSA None None
Brooke 1.5 mL/Kg per % TBSA burn 0.5 mL/Kg per % TBSA burn 2.0 L
Galveston (Pediatric) 5000 mL/m2 burned area + 1500 mL/m2 total area None None

Parkland Formula: Calculates fluid to be replaced in the first 24 hours.

24 hours fluid requirement = 4 ml × Body wt. (kg) × % BSA (Burn Surface Area)

24 hours fluid requirement = 4 ml × Body wt. (kg) × % BSA (Burn Surface Area)

  • Half in 1st 8 hours
  • Next half in the subsequent 16 hours

From the given question:

% BSA= 50 %

Body wt. (kg) = 50 kg

  • 4 × 50 × 50 = 10,000 ml

In the first 8 hours = 5 litres of Ringers lactate.

Option A: 2 Litres

  • According to the Parkland formula, the fluid given is calculated according to body weight, and 50 per cent is given in the first 8 hours and remaining in the next 16 hours. In the given scenario, the total fluid to be given is calculated to be 8 litres, out of which only 4 litres should be given in the first 8 hours. 2 litres of fluid would not replenish the fluid loss. Thus intravascular volume would not be maintained.

Option C: 7 Litres

  • The principle of fluid resuscitation is to maintain intravascular volume to provide sufficient circulation to profuse end organs and should be given according to the Parkland formula. In the given scenario, the total fluid to be given is calculated to be 8 litres, of which only 4 litres should be given in the first 8 hours.

Option D:  8 Litres

  • According to the Parkland formula, the fluid given is calculated according to body weight, and 50 per cent is given in the first 8 hours and remaining in the next 16 hours. In the given scenario, the total fluid to be given is calculated to be 10 litres, out of which only 5 litres should be given in the first 8 hours. The Risk of injury complications and mortality increases in individuals receiving higher resuscitation fluid quantities.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a one-day history of colicky epigastric pain and vomiting. She also reported two days of constipation and not passing flatus. Se had no previous medical history, denied any previous biliary symptoms, no history of cholelithiasis, and no previous abdominal surgery. She was hemodynamically stable and afebrile on presentation. Examination revealed a soft abdomen with moderate distension and epigastric tenderness; however, no rebound tenderness or guarding was noted. Routine blood tests were unremarkable. CT of the abdomen demonstrated the findings shown in the image. Your probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Obstruction of the intestinal lumen from a gall stone carries the misnomer gall stone ileus which is, in fact, a mechanical blockage

For this to occur, there must be a biliary enteric fistula which allows stone migration into the intestinal tract, and this results in air entering the biliary tree (pneumobilia)

The blockage can occur anywhere in the small intestine but occurs most commonly in the distal ileum . Patient presents with clinical evidence of mechanical small bowel obstruction. Plain radiographs demonstrate air fluid levels consistent with small bowel obstruction

Pneumobilia, which may be identified only by CT scan is a ubiquitous finding because the fistula that permitted a stone to pass into the duodenum allow air into the gall bladder and biliary tree

Exploration and enterotomy are required to relieve the obstruction

Rigler’s triad for gall stone ileus

  • Small bowel obstruction
  • A gallstone outside the gallbladder
  • Air in the bile ducts

questions.text: A 9-year-old male child presents to the outpatient department for being restless and hyperactive for six months. He also does not listen to the chapters taught at school and disturbs other students; he also shows less interest in playing. On examination, the child cannot stay still and shows excessive physical movements. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: ADHD

  • In this case, a child presents to the outpatient department for being restless and hyperactive for 6 months. His mother gives the history that his teacher complains that he does not listen to the chapters taught at school and disturbs other students; he also shows less interest in playing. On examination, the child is unable to stay still for any amount of time and shows excessive physical movements. The scenario suggests that the child has attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.
  • Attention, deficit hyperactivity disorder, is one of the most common neurodevelopmental disorders of childhood, and its onset is before the age of 12. In this disorder, a child might have trouble focusing on something or excess movements that are not fitting to the setting.
  • Common features include lack of concentration, impulsivity and hyperactivity.
  • In some cases, children also show destructive and aggressive behaviour. Such children take risks in activities without thinking about their personal safety or the safety of others.

Pharmacotherapy

  • Stimulants
    • Methylphenidate, dexmethylphenidate
    • Amphetamines
    • Modafinil
  • Non stimulants
    • Atomoxetine
    • Bupropion
    • Clonidine, Guanfacine
    • Venlafaxine

Option A: Cerebral palsy

  • It is a group of movement and posture disorders causing activity limitation due to non–progressive disturbances that occur in the developing fetal or infant brain.
  • Cerebral palsy usually presents developmental delay, seizures, microcephaly, and speech abnormalities,  and imaging shows periventricular leukomalacia.

Option C: Mania

  • A specific period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally and persistently increased goal-directed activity or energy, lasting at least 1 week and present most time of the day, nearly every day.
  • It is associated with inflated self-esteem or grandiosity, decreased need for sleep, more talkative than usual, flight of ideas, and distractibility (that is, attention too easily drawn to irrelevant external stimuli).

Option D: Delirium

  • It is cerebral dysfunction of the brain that results in confusion.
  • This disorder presents fast in a few hours or days and is usually temporary. It has 3 types hypoactive, hyperactive, and mixed.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with a complaint of acute pain in the abdomen for the past 12 hours. On examination, there is severe tenderness in the right iliac fossa. The patient denies any history of tuberculosis. On CBC, neutrophil count appears to be raised. The X-ray of the abdomen did not show any evidence of bowel obstruction. An ultrasound abdomen is performed. What is the probable diagnosis referring to the image given below?
questions.solution:
Option A: Acute appendicitis with fecalith

  • The probable diagnosis referring to the patient's symptoms and the radiological imaging would be acute appendicitis with fecalith.
  • Ultrasound shows a non-communicating dilated tubular structure with hyperechoic foci (showing post-acoustic shadow).

  • It is difficult to diagnose appendicitis simply in radiology. Plain radiography is infrequently able to give the diagnosis. However, it is useful for identifying free gas and may show an appendicolith.
  • On ultrasonography, a peristaltic, non-compressible, dilated appendix (>6 mm outer diameter) can be seen in thin patients in case of appendicitis.
  • Hyperechoic appendicolith with posterior acoustic shadow and distinct appendiceal wall layers implies the non-necrotic (catarrhal or phlegmon) stage.
  • Loss of wall stratification with necrosis signifies (the gangrenous) stage.
  • Echogenic prominent perichaetial and periappendiceal fat is also visible.

Option B: Acute appendicitis with lipoma

  • Torsion of the vermiform appendix with a mesoappendiceal lipoma is a rare condition.

Option C: Acute appendicitis

  • In the case of appendicitis, no facility (hyperechoic shadow) is visible in the appendix.

Option D: Ascariasis

  • Intestinal ascariasis appears as individual worms, each seen as a longitudinal tubular structure on a contrast enema.
  • If the alimentary tract of the worm is empty, the worm may appear as a filling defect. If its alimentary tract is distended, the worm appears in parallel bands.

questions.text: A male patient, aged 43, presented for treatment with complaints tracing back a year ago to a traumatic work-related event involving mutilation of the distal phalanges of his right-hand fingers. All of the following can be seen in this case of PTSD, EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
It is a simple question if we understand the differentiation between neurotic and psychotic illness.

PTSD is a neurotic disorder
Hallucinations are a psychotic symptom
Depression is the only illness that comes under neurotic illnesses but can develop psychotic symptoms .
PTSD is characterized by:
? A.Intrusive symptoms- Re experiencing trauma in form of flashback, vivid dreams, nightmares
? B.Avoidance
? C.Arousal symptoms- Hypervigilance, insomnia, exaggerated startle response ,Emotional numbing and Anhedonia .
Symptoms must last for 1 month to diagnose as PTSD.
NOTE: Neurotic patients- judgement ,insight and contact with reality is intact unlike in psychotic disorders.

questions.text: A 10-years-old girl came to the hospital with complaints of polyarthritis associated with fever. ECG reveals 1st-degree heart block. 3 weeks ago, the patient got symptoms of sore throat which were not treated efficiently. The patient also gives a family history of rheumatic heart disease. You are suspecting Rheumatic heart disease in this patient. Which of the following criteria are included under the major category in the criteria used in this patient?
questions.solution:
• This is a classic case of rheumatic heart disease.
  • The above-mentioned patient comes under Moderate risk category of Jones criteria
  • The most recent revision of the Jones criteria requires the clinician to determine if the patient is from a setting or population known to experience low rates of ARF.
  • For that group, there is a set of “low-risk” criteria; for all others, there is a set of more sensitive criteria.

A. For All patient Populations with Evidence of Preceding Group A Streptococcal infection
Diagnosis: initial ARF 2 Major manifestations or 1 major plus 2 minor manifestations
Diagnosis: Recurrent ARF 2 major or 1 major and 2 minor or 3 minor
B. Major Criteria
Low-risk populationsc Moderate and high-risk populations
Carditisb Carditis
  • Clinical and/ or subclinical
  • Clinical and/ or subclinical
Arthritis Arthritis
  • Polyarthritis only
  • Monoarthritis or polyarthritis
  • Polyarthralgiab
Chorea Chorea
Erythema marginatum Erythema marginatum
SC nodules SC nodules
C. Minor Criteria
Low-risk populationb Moderate and high-risk population
POlyarthralgia Monoarthralgia
Fever (≥ 38.5° C) Fever (≥ 38° C)
ESR ≥ 60 mm in the first hour and or CRP ≥ 3.0 mg/dLb ESR ≥ 30 mm/h and/ or CRP≥ 3.0 mg/dLb
Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (Unless carditis is a major criterion) Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (Unless carditis is a major criterion)

questions.text: A 54-yrs-old woman undergoes a laparotomy because of a pelvic mass. At exploratory laparotomy, a unilateral ovarian neoplasm is discovered that is accompanied by a large omental metastasis. Frozen section diagnosis confirms metastatic serous cystadenocarcinoma. The most appropriate intraoperative course of action is: -

choices.text: Excision of the omental metastasis and ovarian cystectomy
Excision of the omental metastasis and unilateral oophorectomy
Omentectomy, total abdominal hysterectomy, and bilateral salpingo oophorectomy

questions.solution:
The patient in the question has advanced stage ovarian malignancy (stage IIIC) MANAGEMENT OF OVARIAN EPITHELIAL CANCER

EARLY Low risk Stage 1A, 1B, low grade Surgical staging
High risk Stage 1C, high grade Surgical staging + adjuvant chemotherapy
ADVANCED Stage II, III, IV Maximal cytoreduction + adjuvant chemotherapy

STEPS OF COMPREHENSIVE SURGICAL STAGING

  • Vertical midline incision
  • Ascitic fluid for cytology
  • If no ascites: take peritoneal washings
  • Biopsy of suspicious lesions and diaphragm
  • Omentectomy
  • Retroperitoneal lymph node evaluation

IMPORTANT POINTS

  • Maximal cytoreduction: means removal of entire pelvic tumor + resection of metastasis
  • Optimal debulking: less than 1 cm of residual lesion
  • Fertility sparing surgery (unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy): Stage 1A with low grade, Bordeline tumors
  • Neo adjuvant chemotherapy: Stage III and IV with massive ascites, massive pleural effusion, unresectable tumor. It increases chances of optimal debulking

questions.text: A 28-year-old male had an irrational fear of open spaces or places where reaching a secure or safe base is difficult. This patient present condition is commonly associated with?
questions.solution:
Agoraphobia:
? An irrational fear of open spaces or places where reaching a secure or safe base is difficult
? Commonest phobia encountered in clinical practice
? More common in women than men and onset in early adulthood
? Panic disorder is commonly associated with agoraphobia
? Can cause significant dysfunctionality
? The individuals suffering from agoraphobia might become overly dependent on their phobic companion(s) – handful of people whom they trust.
HOW TO REMEMBER: Agoras roam in open spaces . Agoras are mostly men. Agoras are old. Opposite is found in agoraphobia.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with keratitis and severe pain in the eye came to the hospital, and Acanthamoeba keratitis was suspected. History and physical examination were made. Out of these, which is not a risk factor for Acanthamoeba keratitis?
questions.solution:
Option D Squamous blepharitis

  • Squamous blepharitis is not a risk factor for acanthamoeba keratitis. It occurs due to dandruff on the head.

Option A: Extended wear contact lens

  • Risk factors include contact lens wear. It is thought that over 80% of Acanthamoeba keratitis appears in contact lens wearers.

Option B: Exposure to dirty water

  • Risk factors include corneal trauma and exposure to dirty water.
  • It is thought that over 80% of Acanthamoeba keratitis appears in contact lens wearers.

Option C: Corneal trauma

  • Risk factors include corneal trauma.
  • It is thought that over 80% of Acanthamoeba keratitis appears in contact lens wearers.​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a history of fever, altered sensorium and purpuric rash for two days. On examination, the patient is found stuporous. He has a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg and extensive palpable purpura over the legs. Which of the following would be the most appropriate initial choice of antibiotic?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ceftriaxone

  • The clinical features are suggestive of Meningococcal sepsis.
  • Usually, asymptomatic nasopharyngeal colonisation
  • Early symptoms
    • Fever, headache and myalgia accompanied by vomiting and abdominal pain.
    • Non-blanching rash (>80%), if present, may appear to be early in the course until petechiae or purpuric lesions develop.
    • Purpura fulminans occur in severe cases with multiple large purpuric lesions and signs of peripheral ischemia.
  • Late symptoms
    • Meningitis (30% -50%)
    • Septicemia (20%)
  • Empirical antibiotic therapy for suspected Meningococcal disease consists of a third-generation cephalosporin such as ceftriaxone or cefotaxime.

Option A: Vancomycin

  • Vancomycin can be used to treat penicillin- and cephalosporin-resistant S. pneumonia.

Option B: Penicillin G

  • Ceftriaxone and cefotaxime are the best initial antibiotics for meningococcal meningitis.
  • Penicillin G is the antibiotic of choice for susceptible strains of meningococcal meningitis.

Option C: Ciprofloxacin

  • Fluoroquinolones like ciprofloxacin are not adequate to treat meningococcal meningitis

questions.text: A 37-year-old P2L2 woman presents to the gynecologist with pain in lower abdomen and dysmenorrhea. On a pelvic scan there is a complex ovarian cyst 4 x 5 cms in size with ground glass appearance. She is a chronic smoker, using combined contraceptive pills, menstrual cycles coming at intervals of 20 days since menarche. A cystectomy is done and histology reveals endometrial glands and hemorrhage. Which of the following in the patient's history is a risk factor for her condition?
questions.solution:
• A history of congestive dysmenorrhea, ovarian cyst and HPE of endometrial glands is suggestive of endometriosis.
  • Protective factors against the development of endometriosis include
    • Multiparity
    • Lactation
    • Tobacco exposure in utero
    • Diet high in vegetables and fruits.
  • Risk factors for endometriosis:
    • Infertility
    • Early age at menarche
    • Shorter menstrual cycle length
    • Polymenorrhea
    • Nulliparity
    • Mullerian anomalies
    • Prior use of contraception or intrauterine device (IUD), or smoking is not associated with increased risk of endometriosis

questions.text: 8 years old boy sustained a fracture to the hand while playing with his sister. In which of the following condition, the Triangular relation of the elbow is maintained?
questions.solution:
• Triangular relation of elbow includes medial epicondyle, lateral epicondyle and tip of olecranon.
  • The relationship is destroyed by dislocations of elbow.
  • It is maintained in supracondylar fracture of Humerus (occurs above elbow joint)

questions.text:
Which of the following statement(s) is/are true concerning the role of antibiotics in wound care?
A. Systemic antibiotics are indicated for all open wounds
B. Topical antibiotics are highly efficacious than systemic antibiotics in controlling infection
C. An indication for systemic antibiotic administration is a granulation tissue bacterial count > 105 organisms/gram of tissue
D. Silver sulfadiazine is useful only for the management of burns
E. Antibiotic treatment of acute wounds must be based on organisms suspected to be found within the infected wound and the patient’s overall immune status
questions.solution:
• The role of antibiotics in wound care is controversial.
  • All open wounds are colonized with bacteria.
  • Only when surrounding tissue is invaded (cellulitis) are systemic antibiotics clearly indicated.
  • Antibiotics may also be useful in other situations such as when granulation tissue has a high bacterial count (> 105 organisms/gram tissue), or in the case of reduced resistance to bacteria such as in a diabetic foot ulcer.
  • The routine use of systemic antibiotics for chronic wounds should be avoided to reduce the development of resistant bacterial strains within the wound.
  • Topical ointments are frequently used
    • The topical vehicle may help keep the wound moist and the bacterial count in the wound may be lowered as the result.
  • Silver sulfadiazine,
    • Use- burn care, chronic wounds.
    • broad spectrum of activity,
    • lack of relevant drug-resistant plasmids in bacteria,
    • low cost
  • Systemic antibiotics given are broad spectrum (not specific )thus at risk of developing resistance while use of topical antibiotic based on culture would be specific for the microbe

The role of antibiotics in wound care is controversial

Antibiotics should be used only when there is an obvious wound infection. Most wounds are contaminated or colonised with bacteria. The presence of a host response constitutes an infection and justifies the use of antibiotics. Signs of infection to look for include erythema, cellulitis, swelling and purulent discharge. As the organisms proliferate to high wound counts (>105organisms per gram of tissue) they may penetrate into viable tissue, invade blood vessels and cause a systemic infection . This is an indication for antibiotic administration. Indiscriminate use of antibiotics should be avoided to prevent the emergence of multidrug resistant bacteria

Antibiotic treatment of acute wounds must be based on organisms suspected to be found within the infected wound and the patient’s overall immune status

When a single specific organism is suspected, treatment may be commenced using a single antibiotic

Conversely, when multiple organisms are suspected, as with enteric contamination or when a person’s immune function is impaired by diabetes, chronic disease or medication, treatment should commence with a broad spectrum antibiotic or several agents in combination

Antibiotics can also be delivered topically as part of irrigations or dressings although their efficacy is questionable

Silver sulfadiazine

  • Silver sulfadiazine is the most commonly used topical antibiotic
  • Broad antibacterial spectrum and hence in addition to treatment of burn wounds , it is also used in the treatment of other chronic wounds
  • Primarily used as prophylaxis against burn wound infections rather than treatment of existing infections
  • Inexpensive, easily applied and has soothing qualities
  • Painless on application
  • Fair to poor eschar penetration
  • It is not significantly absorbed systemically and thus has no metabolic side effects
  • Mild inhibition of epithelialization
  • May leave black tattoos from silver ion
  • Transient leukopenia may develop in 3 to 5 days which resolves spontaneously
  • Destroys skin grafts and is contraindicated on burns or donor sites in proximity to newly grafted areas
  • True allergic reactions to the sulfa component of silver sulfadiazine are rare, and at-risk patients can have a small test patch applied to identify a burning sensation or rash

questions.text: What is the name of this instrument?
questions.solution:
OVUM FORCEPS

→ Commonly used in gynecologic surgeries

Uses

→ Remove placental fragments

→ Small endometrial polyps

→ Removing stones from gall bladder during extraction

ALLIS TISSUE FORCEP

→ Long straight forceps blade-prevents crushing of the tissue

→ Tip - Curved / angulated

→ Alternate teeth / groove at the end of tip-provides firm grip and prevents slippage of the tissue

How to use this instrument?

Should be applied from the inner aspect of skin & subcutaneous tissue

Uses

→ Hold skin & S/C tissue flap for retraction – (excision of LN, Sebaceous cyst, lipoma)

→ Tough tissue- Fascia & aponeurosis approximation during suturing.

→ Thyroidectomy & Neck dissection

→ To hold the cut margins of skin

→ Laparotomy – retract skin margins

→ Bladder neck operations – hold the neck of bladder

BARCOCK’s TISSUE FORCEPS

→ Terminal part – curved

→ Fenestration to accommodate delicate structures

→ Non-traumatic instrument

Uses

→ Appendectomy-to hold the appendix

→ Gastrectomy-to hold the cut margins

→ Fallopian tube

→ Ureter- during pyelolithotomy & ureter lithotomy

→ Spermatic cord during hernia surgery

→ Resection & Anastomoses

→ Hold the cut edges of SI/LI

→ Suprapubic cystolithotomy

→ Use to hold cut edges of bladder

Duval Lung Holding Forceps

→ Blade-Straight

→ Tip-Broad, Triangular with fenestration
Presence of ridges & grooves

Uses- To Grasp lung tissue during lobectomy & pneumonectomy

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy was admitted to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain and hepatosplenomegaly. His complete blood count showed pancytopenia. The consultant attending ordered a bone biopsy, which revealed histiocytes with a wrinkled paper appearance. What could be the most likely diagnosis of the case mentioned above?
questions.solution:
Option B: Gaucher disease

  • The given scenario implies Gaucher disease, which is characterised by glucocerebroside buildup in lysosomes.
  • Gaucher's disease is the most common lysosomal storage disorder (LSD).
  • It is an autosomal recessive disease.
  • It occurs due to glucocerebrosidase deficiency, which causes glucocerebroside to build up inside the lysosomes of cells.
  • The patient usually presents hepatosplenomegaly, bone aches, pathologic fractures, bruising (thrombocytopenia), and anaemia.
  • Neurological characteristics may or may not exist.
  • On an X-ray of the long bone, Erlenmeyer flask deformity may be visible.
  • Bone marrow contains Gaucher cells, lipid-laden macrophages that have cytoplasm with a typical histologic appearance of "wrinkled tissue paper" when stained with periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain.

Option A: Niemann Pick disease

  • Niemann-Pick disease is a deficiency of Sphingomyelinase, resulting in progressive neurodegeneration and foam cells (lipid-laden macrophages).
  • Distinguishing features include hepatosplenomegaly and a "cherry-red" spot on the macula.

Option C: Langerhans cell histiocytosis

  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is characterised by the monoclonal proliferation of antigen-presenting cells (APC).
  • A Birbeck granule component called langerin (CD207) is expressed in almost all LCH patients. It is believed that Birbeck granules, a hallmark of LCH, are elements of the endocytic recycling process.

Option D: Hereditary spherocytosis

  • Hereditary spherocytosis (HS) is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a defect in proteins that interact with the RBC membrane skeleton and plasma membrane.
  • Small, round RBCs characterise it with no central pallor, elevated MCHC and increased osmotic fragility.
  • Splenomegaly and gallstones are common presentations.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman in her second pregnancy has had one live birth and no abortions are seen for prenatal care at 24 weeks gestation. Her family history reveals that her mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus. On investigation, her fasting blood glucose was 190 mg/dl. The antidiabetic drug of choice for this patient would be:
questions.solution:
Insulin: is the drug of choice for the management of DM/GDM in pregnancy as it does not cross the placenta.

  • Patient should be advised self-checking of Glucose levels.

Indication for starting insulin in pregnancy:

  • If FBS is more than 95 mg/dL or if 1 hour postprandial value is more than 140 mg/dL or 2 hour postprandial value is more than 120 mg/dL.
  • Dose = 0.7 to 1 units per kg/day in divided doses.
  • Rapid acting insulin NPH (aspart and lispro), and intermediate-acting insulin are safe in pregnancy.
  • The total daily requirement of insulin = 2/3 in the morning + 1⁄3 at Night such that

– Morning dose = 2⁄3 NPH + 1⁄3 short-acting

– Pre-dinner dose = 1⁄2 NPH + 1⁄2 short

questions.text: A 40-years-old male was posted for elective cholecystectomy. While intubating, the anesthetist was able to see only uvula with hard & soft palate. Under which Mallampati classification does this patient come?
questions.solution:
Assessment of size of the tongue with respect to Oral Cavity

Class I Class II Class III Class IV
  • Hard palate
  • Soft palate
  • Uvula
  • Fauces - Tonsillar
  • Pillars
  • Hard palate
  • Soft palate
  • Uvula
  • Hard palate
  • Soft palate

  • Hard palate only

questions.text: Inspect the following USG picture of fetal umbilical artery with a doppler window and opine.
questions.solution:
The image is suggestive of absent diastolic flow as there is no flow visible above baseline during diastole.

Absent end diastolic flow in umbilical artery is suggestive of severe fetal compromise.

Management involves strict fetal surveillance, antenatal steroids till 34 weeks or occurrence of reversal of EDF (whichever is earlier) after which pregnancy should be terminated

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents to the emergency room with testicular pain of 5 hours duration. The pain was of acute onset and woke the patient from sleep. On physical examination, he is noted to have a high-riding, indurated, and markedly tender left testis and the patient is apyrexial. Pain is not diminished by elevation. Urinalysis is unremarkable. Which of the following statements regarding the patient’s diagnosis and treatment is true?

choices.text: There is a strong likelihood that this patient’s father or brother has had or will have a similar event
Operation should be delayed until a technetium scan clarifies the diagnosis
The majority of testicles that have undergone torsion can be salvaged if surgery is performed within 24 hrs
If torsion is found, both testes should undergo orchiopexy

questions.solution:
Testicular torsion

  • occurs commonly in adolescents (10-25 years)
  • The underlying pathology is secondary to an abnormally narrowed testicular mesentery with tunica vaginalis surrounding the testis and epididymis in a “bell-clapper” deformity. As the testis twists, it comes to lie in a higher position within the scrotum.
  • Urinalysis is usually negative.
  • Elevation will not provide a decrease in pain (negative Prehn sign); a positive Prehn sign might indicate epididymitis.
  • A 99mTc pertechnetate scan may be helpful in clarifying a confusing case; however, operation should not be delayed beyond 4 h from the time of onset of symptoms in order to maximize testicular salvage.
  • This patient’s presentation warrants immediate operation. The salvage rate for delay greater than 12h rs is less than 20%. Both the affected and unaffected testes should undergo orchiopexy.
  • The differential diagnosis between torsion of the testicle and epididymitis is sometimes quite difficult. On occasion, one has to explore a patient with epididymitis just to rule out a torsion of the testicle.
  • Epididymitis usually occurs in sexually active males. Urinalysis is usually positive for inflammatory cells, and urethral discharge is often present.
  • Spermatocele is a cyst of an efferent ductule of the rete testis. It presents as a painless transilluminable cystic mass that is separate from the testes.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presented with a 9-month history of right groin and anterior thigh pain without injury. The pain intensified at night and was only partially alleviated by NSAIDs and analgesics. On physical examination, she limped with an antalgic gait and had limited ROM of her hip, with 0° to 100° flexion and 0° internal rotation. The pelvic, hip, and lumbar spine radiographs were normal. A CT scan showed an oval, lytic lesion with a 6-mm central nidus at the bottom of the acetabulum with expansion of the quadrilateral plate from the pelvis. Your probable diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
Cortical bone (80%) is the most common lesion site for Osteoid osteoma; intramedullary and trabecular sites are less common, and subperiosteal is rare. The acetabulum is an uncommon but painful location often associated with children. There have been numerous reported cases of Osteoid osteoma in the acetabulum. Juxtaarticular and intraarticular localizations frequently are associated with a delayed diagnosis, as seen in our patient.

  • An osteoid osteoma causes a dull, aching pain that is moderate in intensity but can worsen and become severe especially at night. The pain is not usually related to activity. In some cases, a person will suffer the aching bothersome pain of an osteoid osteoma for years.
  • Depending on the location of the tumor, there may also be swelling.
  • A CT scan provides a cross-sectional image of your bone and can also be helpful in evaluating the lesion. A CT scan will commonly show the nidus or center of the tumor.
  • A biopsy may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis of osteoid osteoma.
  • Most osteoid osteomas will disappear on their own over several years. For some patients, regular use of NSAIDs, such as aspirin, ibuprofen, and naproxen, provides pain relief.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the eye outpatient department with a painless gradual decrease in vision. On examination, the cataract was diagnosed, and surgery was performed. He presented the following clinical picture after 4 days of cataract surgery. Which of the following should not be given regarding the complication that occurred?
questions.solution:
Option B: Intravenous antibiotics

  • The above-given picture shows circumcorneal congestion, corneal edema, and anterior chamber inflammation with hypopyon causing endophthalmitis.
  • The most common early postoperative complication.
  • The sources of infection are airborne infections, the patient's eyelids, sutures, drapes etc.
  • Systemic (intravenous) antibiotics do not have a role in circumcorneal congestion.
  • Supportive therapy - Topical cycloplegics, Anti-glaucoma medication
  • Surgical - Core and total vitrectomy - early surgical intervention has improved outcomes.

Management:

  • Antimicrobial Therapy
  • Intravitreal therapy
  • Antibiotics - Vancomycin, Amikacin, Ceftazidime
  • Antifungals - Amphotericin B
  • Topical/subconjunctival antibiotics

Option A: Intravitreal injection

  • Intravitreal injection is a direct injection into the vitreous.
  •  This treatment method is useful in circumcorneal congestion because it causes relief in symptoms in a few hours.

Option C: Pars plana vitrectomy

  • Pars plana vitrectomy is a procedure that allows the surgeon to access the posterior segment.
  • It is used to treat conditions like vitreous hemorrhage and retinal detachments.

Option D: Topical antibiotics

  • Topical steroids are the first line of treatment for circumcorneal congestion.
  • Systemic antibiotics are not effective compared to topical antibiotics.

questions.text: A young female presents with a history of dyspnea on exertion. On examination, she has wide, fixed split S2 with ejection systolic murmur (III/VI) in the left second intercostal space. Her ECG shows left axis deviation. The most probable diagnosis is:

choices.text: Ventricular septal defect with pulmonary arterial hypertension

questions.solution:
Wide fixed splitting of S2 in association with ejection systolic murmur suggests the diagnosis of atrial septal defect

The presence of left axis deviation in A.S.D., suggests ostium primum type of defect.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. On examination she has normal stature, however, there is no breast development and no pubic or axillary hair. Which of the following may be a probable cause?
questions.solution:
Testicular feminization is a syndrome of androgen insensitivity, characterized by a normal 46 XY genotype; normal female phenotype during childhood; tall stature; and “normal” breast development with absence of axillary and pubic hair.

Gonadal dysgenesis (e.g., 45X Turner syndrome) is characterized by short stature and absence of pubertal development; in these girls, the ovaries are either absent or streak gonads that are non-functional.

Kallmann syndrome (hypogonadotropic hypogonadism) should be suspected in patients of normal stature with delayed or absent pubertal development, especially when associated with the classic finding of anosmia. These individuals have a structural defect of the CNS involving the hypothalamus and the olfactory bulbs. The hypothalamus does not secrete GnRH in normal pulsatile fashion, if at all.

questions.text: A patient of infertility, treated with ovulation induction drugs & Inj HCG for ovulation. After 5 days, she comes to OPD with complaints of abdominal distension with pain, nausea, vomiting. USG reveals subclinical ascites. Which of the following is the next step in management?

choices.text: Outpatient management with limited activity, daily weight record and fluid balance
Hospitalise, input output charting and iv fluid administration
Hospitalise, albumin infusion, input/ output charting

questions.solution:
Patient has history of infertility treatment with clomiphene and HCG and has symptoms after 5 days of hcg, she is a case of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome

Management of OHSS:

Here outpatient management is appropriate, as she has mild OHSS, the patient should be instructed to limit her activity, to weigh herself daily, and to monitor her fluid intake (at least 1 L/day of mostly electrolyte-balanced fluid) and output

Indications for hospitalization include a more severe grade of OHSS with

  • Inability to tolerate oral hydration
  • hemodynamic instability
  • respiratory compromise
  • tense ascites
  • hemoconcentration
  • leukocytosis
  • hyponatremia, hyperkalemia
  • abnormal renal or liver function
  • decreased oxygen saturation

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to the hospital with difficulty swallowing for 3 weeks. He also complains of early satiety and regurgitation at night. On examination, he has bad breath. Following investigation was done for this patient. Which of the following does this X-ray demonstrate?
questions.solution:
Option A: Zenker's diverticulum

The X-ray in the image is a Barium swallow picture showing Zenker's Diverticulum/Pouch.

Zenker's diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum where pharyngeal mucosa herniates through the Killian's dehiscence. Killian's dehiscence is a potential area of weakness between the two parts of the inferior constrictor muscle.

Option B: Foreign body throat

  • Foreign body throat presents with dysphagia and drooling of saliva. It can be identified by radiography or flexible endoscopy.

Option C: Stricture in the lower esophagus

  • Lower esophageal sphincter leads to a sense of obstruction during swallowing. It usually presents with dysphagia and regurgitation of food. Barium swallow study can identify esophageal stricture.

Option D: Post cricoid carcinoma

  • It is associated with Plummer-Vinson Syndrome, the classic triad of dysphagia, iron deficiency anemia, and hypopharyngeal webs.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with bloating, diarrhoea, and blood in his stool for a few months. He also complains of weight loss and anorexia. The patient is a known smoker with a 10-pack-year history. He has been hypertensive for the last 6 months. The doctor advised him to get a colonoscopy. He is diagnosed as a case of Crohn's disease. Which one of the following statements is true about the patient’s current condition?

choices.text: Lesions are continuous and associated with backwash ileitis
CT scan is better for detecting Fistulas or sinuses
Long-standing disease predisposes to cancer of the small intestine and colon
Rectal involvement is present in almost all patients with CD

questions.solution:
Option C: Long-standing disease predisposes to cancer of the small intestine and colon

  • The patient is diagnosed with Crohn’s disease.
  • Patients with Crohn's disease involving parts of the colon are more prone to colorectal cancer.
  • They should be vigilant about screening for cancer. These patients are at higher risk for developing colorectal cancer than the general population.
  • Long-standing colon inflammation can cause continuous turnover of cells in the intestinal lining, which increases the chance of anomalies that may lead to cancer.

Inflammatory Bowel Disease:

Crohn’s disease Ulcerative colitis
→Terminal ileitis →Rectum

→Skip areas

→Continuous

→Backwash ileitis
→ has transmural involvement →Has superficial involvement

→Signs seen

  • Target sign/halo sign
  • Comb sign
  • Rose thorning sign
  • Creeping fat sign
  • String sign of Kantor

→Signs seen

  • Loss of mucosal granularity
  • Lead pipe appearance
  • Collar button sign
  • Loss of haustration

→Earliest finding:

Aphthous ulcer – gives cobblestone appearance in bowel

Note: Cobblestone appearance in the oesophagus- Candida

→Earliest finding:

  • Loss of mucosal granularity
  • Lead pipe appearance
  • Loss of haustration

→Has Pseudo sacculation

→Has rectal sparing/fibrosis/strictures/gut shortening

→ Has Pseudo polyps &

crypt abscesses

Option A: Lesions are continuous and associated with backwash ileitis

  • These continuous lesions with backwash ileitis are more common in ulcerative colitis.
  • Crohn's disease has to skip lesions instead of continuous ones.

Option B: CT scan is better for detecting Fistulas or sinuses

  • MRI scan is more suited to detect fistulas compared to a CT scan.

Option D: Rectal involvement is present in almost all patients with CD

  • The rectum is more commonly involved in ulcerative colitis; Crohn's disease usually is more localized to the terminal ileum.

questions.text: A 20-year-old farmer was admitted 6 h after a branch of a tree struck him on the head during tree-felling. He lost consciousness immediately. His Glasgow coma score was 8 with a 7 mm diameter sluggishly-reacting pupil on the left eye. You suspect an epidural hematoma in this patient but a mass casualty due to a bus accident makes getting a CT to confirm the diagnosis difficult. If you want to perform a Burr hole in this patient, what would be the ideal site?
questions.solution:
Option B: Left temporal region

Burr hole on the side of the dominant hemisphere, i.e. left temporal.

  • The temporal lobes sit behind the ears and are the second largest lobe. They are most commonly associated with auditory processing information and with the encoding of memory. The temporal lobes are also believed to play an important role in processing affect/emotions, language, and certain aspects of visual perception.
  • The dominant temporal lobe, which is the left side in most people, is involved in understanding language and learning and remembering verbal information. The non-dominant lobe, which is typically the right temporal lobe, is involved in learning and remembering non-verbal information (e.g. visuospatial material and music).

Damage to the temporal lobes can result in

  • Difficulty in understanding spoken words (Receptive Aphasia)
  • Disturbance with selective attention to what we see and hear
  • Difficulty with identification and categorization of objects
  • Difficulty learning and retaining new information
  • Impaired factual and long-term memory
  • Persistent talking
  • Difficulty in recognizing faces (Prosopagnosia)
  • Increased or decreased interest in sexual behaviour
  • Emotional disturbance (e.g. Aggressive behaviour)

Option A: Right temporal region

Burr hole on the side of the dominant hemisphere, i.e. left temporal.

Option C: Right parietal region

  • The right parietal-temporal lobe is concerned with non-verbal memory.
  • Right parietal-temporal lesions can produce significant changes in personality.
  • Some common tests for parietal lobe function are Kimura Box Test (apraxia) and the Two-Point Discrimination Test (somatosensory).

Option D: Left parietal region

  • The parietal lobes take up premises in both the right and left hemispheres of the brain.
  • This lobe is particularly important in integrating information from the body’s senses to allow us to build a coherent picture of the world around us.
  • The parietal lobes allow us to coordinate our movements in response to the objects in our environment through the use of visual pathways – allowing us to process what and where things are.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman was injured when an auto pushed her against a hard concrete wall. Vital signs were recorded to be normal but a pelvic fracture was suspected because of severe pain in the lumbar region and she was brought to the critical care center. On examination, her consciousness was clear and hemodynamics were stable. Severe pressure pain was felt at the anterior surface of the pubic bone and near the right sacrum. Macroscopic hematuria was found when a urethral catheter was inserted. A CT Cystography was performed on admission which revealed the following finding. Your probable management for this patient is

choices.text: No intervention needed as it has spontaneous healing
Surgical intervention is mandatory and then secondary healing is allowed

questions.solution:
Note in the image how the contrast dissects around the bladder but does not enter the peritoneal cavity.

In this case, imaging indicates that it is an intraperitoneal bladder rupture as the blood does not enter the peritoneal cavity.

So Simple catheter drainage will be the appropriate management for this patient.

Option A: False statement

Appropriate intervention is needed as it does not heal spontaneously.

Option C: False statement

Emergency laparotomy will be done only in the case of intraperitoneal bladder rupture.

Option D: False statement

In the case of intraperitoneal bladder rupture, surgical intervention is mandatory and then secondary healing is allowed.

Learning objective:

questions.text: A preterm newborn was delivered after a C-section. On assessment, his APGAR score was 1; his birth weight was 1000 g. On Neonatal Resuscitation, HR < 100/min + no respirations → Positive pressure ventilation, no response with PPV →Endotracheal intubation, HR < 60/min → Chest compressions, no response to chest compressions → Epinephrine. What would be the ratio of chest compressions : positive pressure ventilation?
questions.solution:
Option B: 3:1

  • Chest compression: ventilation ratio used in neonatal resuscitation - 3:1
  • Components of NRP resuscitation include: (TABCD)
  • T temperature: Maintain between 36.5 and 37.5 C
  • Airway:
    • Sniffing position
    • Clear secretions if needed
  • Breathing:
    • Free flow O2 (maintain sats 91–95%),
    • PPV (40–60 breaths/min),
    • ETT
  • Circulation:
    • Chest compressions: Ventilation - 3:1 or 90:30;
    • Lower 1/3rd sternum;
    • 2 thumb technique preferred
  • Drugs:
    • Epinephrine,
    • Volume expanders
  • Algorithm states:
    • HR < 100/min + no respirations → Positive pressure ventilation.
    • No response with PPV →Endotracheal intubation.
    • HR < 60/min→Chest compressions.
    • No response to chest compressions → Epinephrine.

Option A: 2:1

  • Compression in neonates can be done with two fingers.
  • The compression should be 30 compressions at the rate of 2 compressions per second (2:1).

Option C: 4:1

  • During the compression, hold the baby's head to avoid dropping the chin.
  • There should be two compressions per second, not four compressions per second.

Option D: 5:1

  • During the compression, the chest should be pushed down about one-third.
  • Five compressions per second (5:1) is not indicated in neonates

questions.text: A 26-year-old G2P1L1 female(Rh-negative pregnancy) presents to you for a routine antenatal checkup. Based on current obstetrics practice, what is the best test for monitoring sensitized Rh-negative mothers?

choices.text: Middle cerebral artery Doppler wave forms

questions.solution:
Middle cerebral artery doppler wave forms

  • Best test for monitoring senstitized Rh negative mother is
  • Serial Doppler study of middle cerebral artery (MCA)-peak systolic velocity (PSV) is the mainstay to assess fetal anemia.
  • A value >1.5 multiples of the median (MOMs) for the corresponding gestational age, predicts moderate to severe fetal anemia.
  • This value (between 24 weeks and 35 weeks of gestation), is an indication for cordocentesis and fetal transfusion or delivery

questions.text: A 23 years old known case of malignant lymphoma who was kept under medical management suddenly presented with facial swelling especially around eyes associated with Dilated neck veins. Patients also presented with generalised symptoms like hoarseness, nasal congestion & headache. What could be the possible cause?
questions.solution:
SUPERIOR VENA CAVA (SVC) SYNDROME

  • Clinical manifestation of SVC obstruction, with severe reduction in venous return from head, neck & upper extremities.
  • MC cause is lung cancer (Small cell and squamous cell carcinoma) along with lymphoma and metastatic tumors responsible for more than 90% of all SVC syndrome.
  • In young adults, malignant lymphoma is the leading cause of SVC syndrome.

Clinical features

  • Patients present with neck & facial swelling (especially around the eyes), dyspnea, & cough.
  • Other symptoms include hoarseness, tongue swelling, headache, nasal congestion, epistaxis, dysphagia, pain, dizziness, syncope
  • Characteristic physical findings are dilated neck veins, increased number of collateral veins collateral veins covering the anterior chest wall, cyanosis, and edema of the face, arms & chest.

Diagnosis

  • Most significant chest radiographic finding is widening of the superior mediastinum (MC right side)
  • CT Scan: Investigation of choice.

Treatment

  • Potentially life-threatening complication of superior mediastinal mass is tracheal obstruction
  • Diuretics with lows salt diet, head elevation and oxygen may produce temporary symptomatic relief.
Treatment Underlying cause
Radiation therapy Non-small cell lung cancer, metastatic solid tumors
Chemotherapy Small cell carcinoma or lymphoma
Surgery All other cases

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is scheduled for tonsillectomy. On the day of surgery, he had running nose, temperature of 37.5 C, and a dry cough. Which of the following should be the most appropriate decision for surgery?

choices.text: Surgery should be done next day and child should be put on I/V antibiotics and paracetamol
Can proceed for surgery on the same day after starting I/V antibiotics and paracetamol
Get X-ray chest done and if normal proceed for surgery
Cancel surgery for 3 weeks and put the patient on antibiotics

questions.solution: Tonsillectomy is an elective surgery done under GA. Intubation during upper respiratory tract infection carries a high risk of laryngospasm and lung complications. Also a chance of haemorrhage is increased during respiratory tract infections. Here antibiotics are given and the surgery postponed for 3 weeks.

questions.text: A pregnant lady in her first trimester presents with vaginal bleeding. On examination, the os is closed and the uterine size corresponds to the period of amenorrhoea. The condition could be:
questions.solution:
The patient has presented with bleeding with no history of passage of products. On examination os is closed and uterine size corresponds to POG which suggests that the sac is intrauterine and still present inside the uterus, hence a diagnosis of threatened abortion can be made.

This patient is likely to respond to bed rest and progesterone therapy for pregnancy support

questions.text: The frequency used in B scan used for posterior segment examination is
questions.solution:
USG PARAMETERS

Ultrasound B scan- Brightness 2D , A scan- Amplitude one dimensional (spikes).

· 50 MHz – used UBM for anterior segment.

· 8-10 MHz – used for A-scan, B-scan.

· 5 MHz –Abdominal.

Funnel Shaped Tractional Retinal detachment on B scan

questions.text: A 45-year-old single female, with a 20 pack-year smoking history, presented with a one-week history of a right breast lump and green nipple discharge. On physical examination, a large palpable non-fixed mass near the right areola was present. Also had a history of recurrent breast abscess. Most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Zuska’s Disease (Recurrent Periductal Mastitis)

  • Condition of recurrent retroareolar infections and abscess.
  • Symptoms Breast pain/lump, nipple discharge, and areolar pain/lump.
    Clinical findings Palpable breast mass, tenderness, erythema, warmth, breast swelling, skin thickening, and/or axillary lymphadenopathy.
  • Smoking has been implicated as a risk factor.
  • Managed symptomatically by antibiotics with incision and drainage procedure.

questions.text: A 20-years old nulliparous woman is on oral contraceptive pills. She is currently diagnosed as having pulmonary tuberculosis. Which anti-tubercular drug decreases the effect of OCP?
questions.solution:
Drugs reducing the effectiveness of OCP Drugs which increase the plasma level of steroids of OCP
  • Rifampicin
  • Carbamazepine
  • Phenytoin
  • Antifungals like Induce synthesis of cytochrome

Griseofulvin P450 enzymes in liver.

Ketoconazole

Itraconazole

  • Ampicillin Kill gut bacteria and cause hydrolysis
  • Tetracycline of steroid glucuronides in intestine.
  • Ascorbic acid
  • Acetaminophen

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presented to ER with a second-degree thigh burn, following the use of a Toshiba satellite laptop for approximately 5 h. The burns sustained were in close proximity to the extractor fan of the laptop. He is wheelchair-bound and has impaired sensation of the lower limbs. This is due to incomplete quadriplegia following a C6 level fracture, which he sustained in a road traffic accident in 6yrs ago. On examination, he had two clear blisters on the left thigh-approximately 4 cm × 3 cm and 3 cm × 2 cm in size, surrounded by mild erythema. Blisters were de-roofed, silver-based dressings were applied and advised to change regularly. Follow-up in clinic 4 weeks later, revealed the development of Marjolin ulcer in the pre-existed burn wound due to poor wound care. The most common cancer that can develop in this patient is:
questions.solution:
Marjolin’s ulcer

  • This is a squamous cell carcinoma that arises from a long standing benign ulcer (venous ulcer) or burn wound scars
  • It is slow growing and painless
  • Lymphatic metastasis is unusual as the lymphatics are already destroyed or occluded by previous chronic lesion of the skin

questions.text: A 45-year-old female complains of progressive lower limb weakness, spasticity, urinary hesitancy. MRI shows intradural enhancing mass lesion. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in a 45 years old female with progressive lower limb weakness, spasticity, urinary hesitancy and intradural enhancing mass lesion on MRI is meningioma.

MENINGIOMA

  • MC primary brain tumor: MeningiomaQ (35%) >Glial tumorsQ (30%)
  • Meningiomas are the MC intracranial, extra-axial dural-based neoplasmQ.
  • Predominantly benign tumors of adultsQ, more common in womenQ.
  • Derived from meningomesothelial cells of arachnoidQ
  • Mostly occur along the superior sagittal sinusQ
  • Most are slow growing & encapsulatedQ

PATHOLOGY

  • Round encapsulated mass showing characteristic enplaque pattern of growthQ
  • Tumor may range from firm to fibrous to finely gritty and may show extreme calcification & psammoma bodiesQ

CLINICAL PRESENTATION

  • Motor deficit in 90% (spasticity & lower limb weakness), sensory deficit in 60% or sphincter dysfunction of bladderQ.
Radiological findings in Meningioma
  • Nearly all meningiomas enhance intenselyQ following contrast administration.
  • Abnormal vascular markingsQ
  • Enlarged foramen spinosumQon the side of lesion
  • Dural tailQ
  • Calcification (20-25%) in the tumorQ
  • Invasion of bone cause localized bony hyperostosis/ mixed osteoblastic & osteolytic response less commonly. It may show ‘sun ray spicules’ & local bone expansion with pneumatization so called ‘blistering’Q
  • Signs of increased intracranial tensionQ

TREATMENT

  • Surgery is the treatment of choice for symptomatic meningiomasQ.
  • Extent of resection is the most important factor in the prevention of recurrence.
  • Simpson grading system is used for meningioma resectionQ
  • Recurrence after gross total resection occurs in 11-15% of cases.

questions.text: There are more than 400 blood groups, we consider only the ABO blood group, because:

choices.text: Presence of antibodies in the serum when the RBC lacks the corresponding antigen
A & B antigens are secreted by cells which are not in thecirculation only.
Soluble blood group antigens cannot block binding of organisms to polysaccharides.

questions.solution:
• Preformed ABO antibodies are present in a person’s serum, when his RBCs lack the corresponding antigen
  • In other blood groups preformed antibodies are not present
  • The ABO blood group system is important because essentially all individuals produce antibodies to the ABH carbohydrate antigen that they lack.
  • The first blood group antigen system recognized in 1900,wasABO, the most important in transfusion medicine.
  • The major blood groups of this system are A, B, AB, and O.O type RBCs lack A or B antigens.
  • These antigens are carbohydrates attached to a precursor backbone, and may be found on the cellular membrane either as glycosphingolipids or glycoproteins, and are secreted into plasma and body fluids as glycoproteins.
  • In most people, A and B antigens are secreted by the cellsand are present in the circulation.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false regarding scleral rupture?

choices.text: Seidel's test can be used to know site of rupture as it can elicit aqueous leakage
Traumatic rupture usually occurs at weak points, like at insertion of recti muscles
It can cause angle recession glaucoma

questions.solution:
Scleral rupture:

- Most dangerous as it can cause immediate loss of vision.

- Caused due to trauma by blunt object, often bycounter-coup injury

- Usually occurs at recti muscle insertion > equator

- Tissue extrusion occurs & peeking of pupil is seen

- Seidel's test can be used to know site of rupture, as it can elicit aqueous leakage [tear film with fluorescein dye under cobalt blue illumination]

- Angle regression glaucoma is d/t blunt trauma resulting in [anterior face] ciliary body rupture [widening of ciliary body band].

questions.text: A 35-year-old cricket player presented to OPD with complaints of headache and palpitations. O/E - He has a standing BP 190/100 mm Hg and sitting BP-180/100 mm Hg. He also has an irregularly irregular rhythm, double apical impulse, and bilateral basal crepitations. But no murmurs could be auscultated and heart rate could not be determined. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Condition Features
Left atrial Myxoma More common in a young female with symptoms of myxoma platypnea and low cardiac output since the tumor limits the blood flow into the left ventricle.
Mitral regurgitation Ruled out as no murmur was auscultated in the patient
Cor pulmonale Ruled out as primary lung disease or findings of RVF are absent
LVH

Points in favor of diagnosis:

  1. Hypertension can lead to LVH causing double apical impulse.
  2. HTN can lead to diastolic dysfunction and impacts the atria leading to atrial fibrillation and irregular pulse
  3. Basal crepitations can be explained by atrial fibrillation.
  4. BP changes in standing and supine position are normal (less than equal to 10mm Hg)

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient was admitted with a history of road traffic accident in the casualty. His Glasgow coma scale was 6/15. A definitive airway should be secured to prevent this patient from aspiration of gastric contents. The technique that could not be used in this case is?
questions.solution:
Definitive airway- airway that prevent pulmonary aspiration of gastric contents, allows central of ventilation and permits high FiO2 concentration. Tracheal intubation is the gold standard for airway management which provides maximal protection against aspiration of gastric contents and allows positive pressure ventilation with high airway pressures than face mask or supraglottic airways.ET tube, nasal tube. Tracheostomy, Cricothyroidotomy are definitive airways

Non definitive -Do not prevent from gastric aspiration and lower FiO2 is delivered. Examples include Laryngeal mask airway, oropharyngeal airway, Nasopharyngeal airway
